story:
Who We Are

Class Act Performing Arts Studios provides high calibre training in dance, drama, musical theatre, voice, and music theory. Our experienced and highly-trained instructors give our students the knowledge and training they need to succeed. For more information on our studio, feel free to go to www.classactstudios.ca.

We offer out students a number of opportunities to hone their skills through performances like The Nutcracker. During The Nutcracker, our students will have the opportunity to dance with professionals from Coastal City Ballet as well as highly-trained locals that have been hand picked by our instructors. 

The Impact

At Class Act Studios we believe that it is important for as many children as possible to have the opportunities to experience and interact with various components of the arts. 

This campaigns goal is to raise money to sponsor children who are facing financial barriers to come to a performance of The Nutcracker with their families or schools. We believe that it is important for children to experience the arts as an important part of their personal and intellectual development. 

With your help, the money we raise here could go towards sponsoring a child and their family, a class from a community school, or a group of children being supported by a charity. 

By helping us reach our goal, you are ensuring that more children with financial barriers can attend The Nutcracker! The more you give, the more children we can help!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to donate, please share this link with others that you know that might be interested or come to our performance!

We are extremely grateful for any support!

story:
Emma's Parlor: creating a life ecstatic

Emma's Parlor got into the NOLA Fringe!!! You can help us get there by contributing here, or by attending one of our fundraising performances in Philadelphia.

Emma's Parlor is inspired by Howard Zinn's play about the life and times of Emma Goldman. Our adaptation is a parlor "trick" or paper theater performance that begins with Emma's emigration to the U.S. in 1885 and moves through her life as a factory worker, anarchist, and lecturer. Our toy theater and puppets employ illustrations from the late 19th and early 20th century. We also use everyday objects one might find in a parlor, of that same period as playing spaces. A phonograph becomes a cafe filled with anarchists, a birdcage becomes a prison, and a laundry wringer becomes a ... (well we must preserve some of the mystery). We are proud to quote Philadelphia City Paper in saying this show "embodies the notion of innovation in performance."

Lorna and Martina are delighted to have Emma's Parlor be one of 24 shows selected to perform at the New Orleans (NOLA) Fringe Festival 2013. Their paths have crossed many times in Philadelphia theater and puppet slams. Emma's Parlor marks their first full collaboration. Lorna comes from a background in theater and 12 years as a resident puppeteer at center for Puppetry Arts in Atlants, GA. Martina started a career as an architect then in 2003 took the exit for puppetry as a designer/builder at Mum Puppettheater in Philadelphia.

Since taking Emma's Parlor on tour to The 10th International Toy Theater Festival at St. Ann's Warehouse this June, Lorna and Martina have been commissioned to create an entirely new piece "Loudoun Abbey" by Stenton Museum with PEW funding.

Your contributions will help Lorna & Martina with:

  • performer insurance fees
  • gas and car rental
  • posters and postcards
  • materials for puppets and traveling show trunks
  • rehearsal and studio space rental
  • sound equipment and software
  • 4% goes to back to indiegogo if we make our goal and 9% goes back to them if we do not

Your Impact

Your contributions to this campaign will allow us to take Emma's Parlor and the story of Emma Goldman, a free spirited thinker who was exiled from the United States because of her outspoken views, to new audiences. We are developing three new scenes and one specialty puppet never before used just for NOLA Fringe 2013. Your support is directly contributing to making our artistic vision a reality. 

Where in NOLA we'll be: 

Our Venue is Backyard Ballroom - located at
3519 Saint Claude Ave.,New Orleans, 70117

Thursday, November 21st, 2013 @ 9pm
Friday, November 22nd, 2013 @ 5pm
Saturday, November 23rd, 2013 @ 7pm
Sunday, November 24th, 2013 @ 9pm

$8 with $3 Fringe button available at the door or at  www.nofringe.org.

Where in Philly we'll be:

Sunday, October 13th at 7:30pm and 9:30pm
233 S. Melville St. Philadelphia PA 19139

Mary Kalyna's house:
Saturday, November 2 at 7pm

High Point Cafe - Allens Lane Train Station
Thursday November 7th at 7:30pm

Other Ways You Can Help:

We understand that you might not be able to contribute monetarily, spreading the word and making some noise about our campaign is a HUGE help too. So please like us on Facebook, get the word out and fringe on ... there are Indiegogo share tools to help in these efforts.  Thank you so much, in advance! Lorna Howley and Martina Plag for more info about us please visit www.studium-praxis.org.

A little about toy theater

Toy theater, also called paper theater and model theater, is a form of miniature theater dating back to the early 1800s in Europe. Toy theaters were often printed on paperboard sheets and sold as kits at the concession stand of an opera house, playhouse, or vaudeville theater. Toy theaters were assembled at home and performed for family members and guests, sometimes with live musical accompaniment. Toy theater saw a drastic decline in popularity with a shift towards realism on the European stage in the late 19th century, and again with the arrival of television after World War II. Toy-theater has seen a resurgence in recent years among many puppeteers, authors and filmmakers and there are numerous international toy theater festivals throughout the Americas and Europe.
 
Mass produced toy theaters are usually sold as printed sheets, either in black and white to be colored as desired, or as full-color images of the proscenium, scenery, sets, props and characters. The sheets are pasted onto thin cardboard, cut out, and then assembled for the purposes of the reenacting of a play. Figures are attached to small sticks, wires, or configurations of strings that allow them to move about the set. Some toy theaters and figures are enhanced with moving parts and special effects, and it is common for performances to include live or pre-recorded sound effects and music.

story:
About Act III

Since 2008, Act III Theatre Ensemble has worked to provide professional level experiences for both audiences and participants by bringing shows to UCLA's campus that are innovative, exciting, and important. All of are shows are produced, directed, designed, and performed by students with professional ambitions in the world of theatre. In order to make powerful theatre as accessible as possible to the UCLA community, we do not charge for admission to our shows.

About Assassins 

With this show composer Stephen Sondheim lays bare the lives of nine individuals who assassinated or tried to assassinate the President of the United States, in a one-act historical "revusical" that explores the dark side of the American experience. This show supports Act III’s mission to continually challenge audiences, and bring the UCLA campus shows unlike anything they have ever seen. This show forces audiences to think about mental health, gun control, and American politics throughout history in a different way.

Assassins will be Act III's twelfth musical to date, and will be the most ambitious yet. Assassins features a cast of 16 strong singer/actors, playing incredibly complex characters from American history, a full pit band of 15 instrumentalists, and a design/production crew of over 20 students. The show will take place in Schoenberg Music Hall, a 520 seat theatre on the UCLA's campus. This will be the largest venue Act III has ever performed in. Act III is thrilled to have the opportunity to provoke conversation, spark debate, and create change through such a powerful, political, and relevant show. However, the size of the production comes with higher prices. Everything from printing, to rental equipment, to the venue is over triple what Act III usually fundraises. 

What We Need 

The highest priced line items on the budget for Assassins are the facility fees for Schoenberg Hall, and the rental fees for the sound, lighting, props, and costumes for the show. Any and all donations make a huge difference for this production. Everyone working on Assassins is working passionately and professionally. As an ensemble, Act III would hate to see the hard work of our artists not come to fruition due to a lack of funding. Every dollar you donate goes towards making the vision of these actors, directors, and designers come to life. 

The Impact

$25 Covers the rental fee of one script.

$50 Covers the costume of a character. 

$100 Covers the rental of one actor's microphone during our run.

$150 Covers our lighting rental fee.

$275 Covers the cost of the rights for one performance.

$450 Covers the printing costs of show programs.

$500 Covers the rental insurance needed to secure props and costumes.

$640 Covers the facilities fee for one day in Schoenberg Hall.

Why This Show

Assassins is our most ambitious show to date, due to consistently successful shows over the past five years, Act III is ready to make the next step in developing as an ensemble. We want the quality work Act III is doing to be seen by more students and community members. This show has the power to launch Act III into more widespread campus recognition. 

 The show brings basic humanity to light. Additionally, the show has the power to create educational conversations about gun-control, national security, mental health, and American history. As gun violence has been such a huge part of our country’s culture over the past decade, we believe the campus NEEDS to see this show. 

How To See The Show

Assassins show times are:

Saturday, March 1st at 8pm

Sunday March 2nd at 2pm and 7pm.

*Admission is free of charge

visit www.actiiitheatreensemble.com for more info

story:
Join over a hundred Bay Area writers, directors, actors, and fine artists to become a part of one of San Francisco's most exciting new theater festivals! 

Who are you?

The San Francisco Olympians Festival is an annual event that lasts for twelve nights (thirteen, if you count our opening party!) with a focus on the creation of new scripts for the theater in addition to providing a showcase for Bay Area fine artists, actors and writers.

The Festival was started in 2010 by Stuart Bousel, and featured 12 new full length plays, each one based on one of the twelve Olympian gods of Ancient Greece. In 2011 the festival returned with 32 plays, ranging from five minute shorts to full lengths, each one based upon an Ancient Greek sky god or mythical figure who had become a constellation, moon, etc. In 2012 we debuted 25 one acts, each night pitting a play about an Olympian god against a play about a Titan, the race of gods who sired the Olympian gods, and were then overthrown by them. 

This year we are excited to premiere 36 new plays by 30 local writers- 16 of whom will be contributing work to the festival for the first time! The plays range from shorts to one acts to full lengths, and each one explores a different aspect of the Trojan War, the apocalypse of Ancient Greece. It will play 12 nights, November 6-23, at the Exit Theatre in San Francisco, and if previous years are indicative of a trend, (every year we've broken our own records), we expect this to be the largest festival yet in terms of participants and audience!

Why do you need so much money?

Well, a bigger festival requires a bigger base of support and this year we're looking to raise $10,000- a really big number! Why so much? Well...

  • 40% of the money we raise goes to keeping the doors of the theater open, the lights turned on and the water running- all really necessary! The rest of the money we raise is split two ways...
  • The first half goes to marketing and materials: postcards, posters, programs, high quality printings of the work created by our fine artists, the catering for our opening night party and of course, all the photocopies of these brand new scripts we need for the readings.
  • The second half goes towards achieving this year's lofty goal of paying everyone who works on the festival a stipend of some kind. In previous years actors and writers were paid, and we held raffles to raise some funds for the artists, but our entire production team and crew, including our box office manager and all of our directors, were volunteers. This year we'd like to change that by creating enough funds to offer everyone a small thank you for the hours, days and weeks they'll put into this project. If we meet our goal, we'll be able to do this, and maybe even have enough left over to put some money away for next year- something else we've never been able to do before!

Most importantly, if we manage to raise all of our funds, we'll be able to keep our ticket price (which is only $10) low, ensuring that the wide variety of audiences looking to experience these new works can do so affordably.

Okay, but why should I support you?

When you support this festival, you're not just supporting the 30 writers whose work will be presented this year, but also the 80+ actors we predict this festival will use (last year we hit 91- a new record for us!), a dozen directors and a dozen fine artists, the staff of the festival and the theater where we work, the theater itself, the neighborhood it is located in, and the cultural life of the city that is our home. Events like the San Francisco Olympians Festival are part of what make the Bay Area a unique and inspiring place to be, a leader in the arts and a center for intellectual experiment and advancement.

But our impact is not just local- it's national. The San Francisco Olympians Festival has been quickly gaining momentum since its first year, with six plays that were first given a public reading in the festival having gone on to full productions: 2010’s Hermes (No Nude Men Productions, Dramaworks, Bread and Water Theatre), Juno En Victoria (Wily West Productions), and Salty Towers (Thunderbird Theater Company); 2011’s Cassiopeia (Eat Street Players), Chronus (Bread and Water Theatre), and You’re Gonna Bleed (DivaFest). Many others have received additional readings on local and national stages: 2011’s Joe Ryan (Impact Theatre), Pleiades (Atlantic Stage) and Selene, or Someone Like The Moon (Exit Theatre); 2012’s Caenis and Poseidon (Playwrights’ Center of San Francisco). Additionally, Exit Press has released a collection of five plays from year one of the festival, Songs of Hestia, now available for purchase on Amazon.com and at bookstores across the country. So when you support our festival you're also supporting American Theater, Literature and Art and adding to the cultural heritage of generations of artists and audience yet to come.

Thank you for giving whatever you can give, for passing this campaign on to others you know who may want to support us, and for helping this festival continue to grow and make the world a better place through art!

Find out more about the festival at www.sfolympians.com.

This year's line up: 

November 6: Greeks Bearing Gifts

AJAX MAJOR by Charles Lewis III

AJAX MINOR- Barbara Jwanouskos

NESTOR- Robert Estes

POLYXENA- Peter Hsieh

CHRYSEIS- Carol Lashof

BRISEIS- Carol Lashof

OENONE- Ashley Cowan 

November 14: The Brothers (Part Two)

November 15: The Seer

CASSANDRA- Claire Rice 

November 16: The Survivor

AENEAS- Colin Johnson

GOLDEN APPLES I- Helen Noakes

THE SHIELD- Meg O'Connor

THE HELMET- Meg O'Connor

THE SPEAR- Neil Higgins

THE SWORD- Tracy Potter

THE SHIPS- Tracy Potter

THE BOW- Sunil Patel

GOLDEN APPLES II- Allison Page 

November 21: The Battlefield

THE WALLS- Madeline Puccioni

THE PLAINS- Jeremy Cole

November 22: The Problem 

HELEN- Sam Hurwitt

November 23: The Solution

THE HORSE- Stuart Bousel

story:
Hello! My name is Aeshna Mairead and I’m the founder of Silk Lotus Dance. The greater Burlington area is in need of a space where the local belly dance community can come together for classes, workshops and performances.  My dream is to provide this space and reach out to the community to share this art form, providing inspiration and promoting self-confidence to students of all ages, shapes, sizes and experience. This space will also be open to teachers and students of other dance and movement art forms such as burlesque, poi, hooping, and stage combat.

We need about $15,000 for studio equipment and supplies to be relatively functional and provide a quality arts environment. Let’s face it, does the work ever really end? $15,000 is just the beginning! I have big dreams and I need your help to achieve them! The bulk of the money will be put towards a sound system, mirrors and lighting for the main dance studio and studio fit-up. We also need to make sure our legal ducks are in a row and that we have all of the necessary insurance and paperwork filled out. If we don’t reach our minimum goal, any money raised will still be put towards smaller but still necessary things, like chairs, paint or curtains. And any extra will be put in the bank and used towards obtaining decor, merchandise for sale and making things more comfortable in the future. Also, for bringing in special guest teachers!

And what do you get for helping me?

You get to be a part of this amazing journey that for me seemed to begin only yesterday. It all started when I was a shy, severely overweight, young woman in need of something. I attended a belly dance fitness class and I was hooked. I sought out class after class and saw my self-confidence rise and the weight drop. But those classes were hard to find. I want to make it easier for others to find classes and share the majesty of belly dance. I want to be able to offer more classes! (You also get some nice perks that you can find listed over on the right side of the page.)

If you can’t donate monetarily, please help by spreading the word! Share this campaign on Facebook or Twitter, talk about it with your friends, just get it out there! I can't make this happen without you! Thank you!

story:
Our Journey

22.6 million people in the United States use illicit drugs.  It costs $400 billion a year in the United States alone.   Addiction kills 350 Americans a day.  And addicts are not the only one affected by their use.  Their family and friends are also impacted.  While there are apps on the market for people seeking recovery, there are none for their family and friends.  

My journey into the world of addiction began in 2010 when I realized my daughter was an Oxy addict.  I became aware of how it affects all classes and income levels.  Yet the stigma of addiction keeps most families quiet.  Surprisingly, when I mentioned my daughter’s issues to someone, more times than not, they also had someone involved in the struggle.  

There are 23.5 million people living in recovery. Take this number and multiply it by everyone caught up in the fight, not only the one working for recovery, but their extended family and friends and those trying to help them, then you begin to understand how immense is the population impacted.  Addiction has to be the leading cause for this decade.  Drastic improvement will occur over the next few years as there is more discussion, more openness, different treatment options, change in government policies, and better networks of those affected.

When I first was introduced to this world, my immediate concern was for quality treatment - what options were there and which were best for detox, residential treatment, sober living facilities, and intensive outpatient treatment. Initially, I wanted to help others by developing a referral system for treatment programs and the differences in them but I discovered there are so many and, instead of finding answers and support, there were only more questions and issues to explore.

 

 

In 2012, I had a major shift in my focus.  While I was attending the “2012 Social Slam, The Evolution of Digital Media for Marketing” conference in Knoxville, I heard the words “just start”.   So I did.

I collected the links where I had looked for information and organized all these resources into one place so others could come and learn and share -Links for awareness, Links where answers could be found to questions and needs - A place that would allow these individual communities and their information to come together.

This place is now an Android app “You are Linked to Resources for Families of People Seeking Recovery”.  

What started as a simple idea last May and was working on our cell phones last June has developed into a much bigger project.


     August 2012  

The 100 original links, have grown to over a 1,000  links.




March 2013

 

The app contains information about:

Education

The Education section will link the user to web pages with information on drugs and addiction.  Some of the many topics covered are overdoses, codependency and enabling, and financial help for intervention.  Parents who do not have children who are using drugs will be interested in the topics of Drug Information and Signs of Addiction.

Self-Care

The Self-Care page is split into four sections; financial, mental, physical, and spiritual self-care. The financial section will provide information on ??rehab treatment and health care, free programs. The mental section will have links to web pages focused on inspiration.  Gratitude Attitude, Inspirational Quotes, and Successful Recovery stories will all be included in the mental section of the Self-Care page. Hundreds of successful long term recovery stories are included in the app and social media to help reduce the stigma of addiction.

The physical self-care page will focus on the famly's physical care - web pages about Nutrition and Fitness are included as well as how to handle stress. The Spiritual self-care section will have links to Podcasts, online sermons and meditations.

 Shop

The shop section of our app will link the user to online shops and websites. Here, the user will have links to books and DVD’s. 

Clean was released in April 2013.

 

The shop will also connect users to recovery gifts, including jewelry and clothing and android cell phone and tablet apps.

 

Meetings

The meeting section links to multiple different organizations such as Celebrate Recovery, Smart Recovery and Families Anonymous.  These sites link the user to meetings near them.  This section also includes online programs and chatrooms for families.  

Recovery Advocacy

The recovery advocacy section offers links to resources about the stigma of addiction.  It also includes how addiction is interpreted by governmental programs, such as legislation, crime, and regulation of drugs by the FDA.  This section also links the user to other families who have lost a loved one or who have a loved one in recovery who write blogs, Facebook pages, or websites.  Also included in this section is a place to remember those we have lost to addiction.  This graphic is an example of a posting on Facebook about the new policy from the White House.

 

The Android app with 1000+ links will cost around $2.99.  We are still determined to have a free version of our app with around 100 links.  It does not include information about treatment programs or referral to treatment programs.  Unlike most free apps, ours will not have any ads.  We will continue to add content to keep in information up-to-date and look for ways to make the app more user-friendly and accessible.  

 “You Are Linked to Resources for Families of People Seeking Recovery” is not just a new app.  “You Are Linked” is also about networking communities built by others that share the common trait of having a loved one who is seeking recovery or who has died - linking the various bits and pieces (including people) in one place.  This campaign has become as much about the uniting the community of addiction and sending more traffic to the websites, Facebook pages, Pinterest, and Twitteraccounts that already exist.

 

You are Needed

We need funding to staff the continuation of “You are Linked to Resources for Families of People Seeking Recovery” so that we can:

1.  Complete the initial testing of the links (just over half way there)

2.  Continue to monitor and maintain the links

3.  Complete the beta testing of the app

4.  Develop a free version of 100 links

5.  Maintain the social media sites that provide free access to material in the app

Pinterest (2600+ pins) -http://pinterest.com/urlinked


 

Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/youarelinkedtoresources



 

Twitter -https://twitter.com/URLinkedTo

 If we surpass the goal, the  money will be applied towards the app on the Apple platform.

If you are unable to share financially, we still need your help.  Please share the information including by posting on your Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest or by emailing.  Help remove the stigma associated with addiction.  Help educate those struggling, their families, and the general public.

Please help us “Link” this community together.

 

Thank you so much for checking out our project!

 

Check out these screen shots of the app!

       

 

 

Meet the Team!! 

Watch the video below to learn more about the brains behind the operation!

http://www.youtube.com/embed/XkqV6Fe0qb0

story:
NYU Renegade Theatre's production of Zanna Don't! is raising money to cover production costs including but not limited to:

Royalty rights - These are the rights we need to simply get this show in front of an audience
Rental fees - Including rehearsal scripts/scores, rehearsal space, chair rentals, etc.
Costumes
Set
Props

NYU Renegade Theatre is 100% SELF-funded, fundraised, and produced. We get no stipend or monetary contribution from NYU. That means that we need YOUR HELP in order to reach our fundraising goal of $500. Your contribution will be greatly appreciated by everyone in the cast and on the creative team, and you may receive rewards! (see perks)

story:
HELLO THERE!

Ladystache is: a sketch comedy duo. More specifically Allison Hogg and Stephanie Tolev. We have been preforming comedy in Toronto and across North America for the past four years. Some of our highlights include the Toronto Sketchfest, Montreal Sketchfest, Just For Laughs Showcase, Chicago Women are Funny Festival and our own show Ladystache Gone Wild. We genuinely like each other and enjoy nothing more than to make each other and audiences laughs. And now the next step...

EDINBURGH FRINGE!

Ladystache is going to: Edinburgh Fringe Festival! This is the most popular and prestigious fringe festival in the world. Performers from all over the world gather in Edinburgh for the month of August to present their comedy, theatre, dance or solo acts, etc. It provides a great opportunity to showcase your talent, get reviewed by magazines and generally meet people and have a good time. And good times tend to cost some money so...

WE NEED YOUR HELP!

We have worked hard to get together a collective of sketches that we are certain will delight and entertain our European crowds. In order to do that we are in need of a little bit of funding to help get us there. Money raised will be used towards our flights and some promotional materials to help get butts in seats. Once those butts are in the seats we promise to make the faces attached to those butts laugh. We really appreciate any donation you can contribute to help two funny women spread the funny to Scotland. 

Please feel free to spread this on to all of your friends, family, coworkers, distant cousins, twitter followers, wealthy entrepreneurs, old high school teachers, etc.  

We thank you. The people of Scotland thank you. The beer tents at the festival thank you.

story:
Our Story

(Hello my name is Nadia Brown and I am the writer and director for the stage play "Get Your Life Back" I began showcasing my skills to my classmates, teachers and friends in school programs. At the tender age of 10 years old, I earned the coveted part of the defense attorney in a mock trial presentation with the honorable Judge Cummings. I was said to be an instant success receiving rave reviews and winning the trial. Even at that age, my creative banter and scripting skills shone brightly which propelled me to other lead roles.

The next audition was for Inman Middle School’s Black History Play as leading character Ruby. Playing the role of a slave was a challenging yet provoking task which I engaged the crowd with ease and told the story in an emotionally charged show. My innate ability to become the character and speak from their emotional position caused me to steal the show. Wow I thought! I found my passion and began acting in every dramatic endeavor that I could find. As time moved forward, I then auditioned for North Atlanta’s High School of performing Arts. Giving all that I had in me, I discovered that I was not accepted that time around and even at a young age, I found myself at a pivotal crossroad in my life.

Devastated by the decision, I gave up my dream for acting and pursued other ideals. I continued to excel in school and graduated from AMC College in Atlanta, GA with a degree in Cardiovascular Technology and remained successful in my career. After a decade of other professional pursuits, I found myself working with a well known personality, not realizing this would be the beginning of a journey back to my passion. I was asked to write, produce and direct a massive stage play entitled “Get Your Life Back” to be performed for the city of Atlanta but to no avail the show was cancelled. As a result, I re-enrolled into acting classes to perfect my craft and made a decision that I would still experience the life of an actress, play write and director. So here I am once again to present to the World the stage play "Get Your Life Back" under new management..The second time around is always a treat this play will touch millions in a way that is unexplainable.

 

The Impact

Live Life Production presents Get Your Life back which is a play written to Inspire people to Get up and Live despite their situations because it's apart of Life..When "Life" happens we can't pick and choose when, where, and how we want it to happen, we just have to have a stable mind to deal with the circumstance wheter it's a death, divorce, bad relationship, child abuse, rape, domestice violence, or abandonment. No matter what your tradegey may be it's not the end of your Life..

For instance, Live Life Productions was birthed after I experienced what seemed to be one of the toughest seasons/trails of my life. Through my experience and what I now know was my transformation into the strong young women that I am today. "Get Your Life Back" was created so that people of any race, creed, nationality, and denomination can know that life doesn't have to end after a major family crisis or the pressure that life can bring but to recognize that while in the crisis that your life is just beginning.

 

Just as a butterfly goes through a re-birthing after the cocoon, when the old is shredded off and the new is created into a beautiful butterfly that can fly as high as the sky's limit. Well I discovered that after my transformation and re-birth that the skies has no limit and One can obtain the impossible, and One can walk into the unexplainable and that with the help of GOD One would be known as the "Who Would Have Ever Guessed". "Get Your Life Back" will give you a sense of freedom, to know that you can LIVE LIFE again no matter what your circumstance.

Productions from Live Life Production will LIBERATE, EDUCATE, CREATE, and leave one INSPIRED to LOVE and LIVE LIFE!!!!!!

 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to bring this play into full productions "Lights, Camera, Action" It will cost a grand total of $20, 000.00

  • $5,000.00- Marketing commercials on mainstream radio, fliers, and postcard
  • $4,516.00-Woodruff Arts Center main stage rental which also includes tech fees, housemanager fees (during performances only), and stage manager fees (only during performances only)
  • $1,500.00-Wardrobe and make-up for 16 cast members
  • $3,500.00- Props including backdrop rentals
  • $3,000.00- 10 Lapel Microphone rentals
  • $500.00- Van rental for hauling equipment and props this price also includes mileage
  • $500.00- Craft services
  • $1,400.00- Misc. (medical supplies, gas, child care, pre and post production)

 

If my goal from this campaign isn't achieved I will still move forward in pursuing investors from my church, local business owners, selling candy  or even washing cars if I have to all for the sake of people getting their life back...This campaign will continue until every dime is raised to ensure that "Get Your Life Back" is seen on the stage and all over the world performing in one city at a time...

 

The achievement of this production is very important to me because part of the proceeds will go to help 2 non-profit organization one in Garborone, Botswana to help children that has been exposed to physical and mental abuse..I had a chance to visit South Africa this past fall on a missions trip and the kids at the orphanage really touched my heart and I made a vow that day that I would do anything I can to help and bring awareness to this epidemic that is taking place in Botswana...to learn more about childline Botswana please visit www.childline.org.bw.

 

The second non-profit organization is called "Educating Youth Abroad" and it was created so that kids of all ethnic backgrounds could experience traveling the world while being educated at the same "The World is like a book if you don't travel you only get to read one page".

 

So please please there is so much work to be done so let's get started...

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please I need all the help I can get with this campaigning so please share along with me on Twitter, Facebook, Email, Church, Work, Bus, Train well you get the point..any amount will help to get this production funded and on stage so that people can "Get Their Life Back"

 

The picture above was taken in Garborone, Botswana with the Board Members of Child-line Botswana..so please let's make it happen....Thanks for your Love and all of your Support..

$500.00- Van rental for hauling equipment and props this price also includes mileage
$500.00- Craft services
$1,400.00- Misc. (medical supplies, gas, child care, pre and post production)
 
If my goal from this campaign isn't achieved I will still move forward in pursuing investors from my church, local business owners, selling candy  or even washing cars if I have to all for the sake of people getting their life back...This campaign will continue until every dime is raised to ensure that "Get Your Life Back" is seen on the stage and all over the world performing in one city at a time...
 
The achievement of this production is very important to me because part of the proceeds will go to help 2 non-profit organization one in Garborone, Botswana to help children that has been exposed to physical and mental abuse..I had a chance to visit South Africa this past fall on a missions trip and the kids at the orphanage really touched my heart and I made a vow that day that I would do anything I can to help and bring awareness to this epidemic that is taking place in Botswana...to learn more about childline Botswana please visit www.childline.org.bw.
 
The second non-profit organization is called "Educating Youth Abroad" and it was created so that kids of all ethnic backgrounds could experience traveling the world while being educated at the same "The World is like a book if you don't travel you only get to read one page".
 
So please please there is so much work to be done so let's get started...
 

Other Ways You Can Help
Please I need all the help I can get with this campaigning so please share along with me on Twitter, Facebook, Email, Church, Work, Bus, Train well you get the point..any amount will help to get this production funded and on stage so that people can "Get Their Life Back"
 
The picture above was taken in Garborone, Botswana with the Board Members of Child-line Botswana..so please let's make it happen....Thanks for your Love and all of your Support..

story:
It is the time of the #MeToo movement! It is the time of #TimesUp. The time when many old constructs designed to subjugate women are beginning to crumble. In the arts, more and more women are speaking up and speaking out for their rights and it is filtering across sectors. For the bold women who are taking a stand, it may seem like they are forging new territory, but many have come before them. Let us say their names. 

  • I am a performer and teaching artist who is currently pursuing her Masters of Arts in Arts Management and Entrepreneurship at the New School in New York City. When not in school learning I am in New York city schools as a theater teaching artist. My passion is using storytelling to light a spark of inspiration in children young and old. 
  • Move Towards the Light is a one  woman show that looks to connect with the spirit of women pioneers, who in the midst of a storm, stayed true to their own course.  These women, each in their own right, have fought and stood up for the human spirit in female form. Each, living in a challenging time in U.S. History, summoned the courage to face indignities, atrocities and poverty to triumphed in bringing African Americans one step forward.  This show is geared towards 5th - 8th graders and is as much a call to action in the present as it is an homage to dynamic women from the past. 
  • Let's bring dynamic storytelling for young people to increase representation of stories that reflect the multitude of contributions of people of color. 

The Culmination of Two Years of Study and 10 years experience! 

  • Move Towards the Light is the culminating project, capstone project for my masters degree, but with your help it will have a life well beyond the end of my school career. Because it is currently a school project, there is no outside funding. This is where you come in! I am asking for $1500 to give birth to the show.  Here is how the money will be spent - 
    • $400 for period costumes
    • $200 for props
    • $200 for set materials
    • $250 for projection designer
    • $300 for insurance
    • $50 for transportation 
    • $350 for technical crew
    • And more costs ....
  • Check out the perks including a Behind the Scenes docu/journal of the process!
  • If I don't reach my goal, as of the funds that will be contributed will still go towards the creating the show. The show must go on or I don't graduate! Help me get out of school! 

This show goes straight out to the schools with two FREE performances!

The development of this project will culminate in free performances in New York City for two local schools. As the play continues to develop, the plan is to perform it in schools located in all five boroughs of New York and as well as New Jersey. Move Towards the Light creates an on-going conversation about an individual's responsibility for making change within ones' life and in the community. 

  • At the conclusion of the campaign, you will be able to track the progress of the show in my web posts. This show will be the template with which I create a series of plays based on dynamic and daring historical women. Even though we are looking back, the baton is always passed forward to the children so that they too can become change makers. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • If you can donate - amazing you are a rockstar! Please donate AND share the campaign. 
  • If you can't donate - can you be a rockin' backup singer?! Please SHARE the campaign. 
  • If you have resources or additional ideas - we are a village- let's work together.

story:
What is "The Pull of the Moon"?

"The Pull of the Moon" is a one act play written by Paige Zubel. The play focus on college students and couple Erin and Kaleb who are struggling with the lasting effects of trauma. Erin has been sexually assaulted by an unnamed aggressor, and does not know how to recover from it. Instead, she lashes out and drags Kaleb down with her. Framing their conflict is Peter, a college professor, giving a lecture on the cycle of waves. Peter insists there is no such thing as rebirth in the water, but Erin and Kaleb have to find a way to rebuild once their emotional waves crash down around them.


"The Pull of the Moon" has received staged readings at the Marque Theatre (Brooklyn) and from Ignition Productions (Houston).


Meet the Team

Paige Zubel, the playwright,  is a recent graduate of the University of Houston where she received her BFA in Playwriting and Dramaturgy. She is an internationally produced playwright, but the opportunity to have her play "The Pull of the Moon" at the Manhattan International Theatre Festival will be the play's Manhattan premier!

Zubel has collaborated with Houston native Jonathon Steiger. Steiger has brought together a fantastic team in NYC to bring this show to life, but we need your help!

With your support, Houston theatre can make a statement in NYC that we are a theatre city that produces great artists. Your support also provides young artists with the chance to create new, innovative art in America's most renowned theatre city!


Why Do We Need $900?

"The Pull of the Moon" has accepted a slot in the Midtown International Theatre Festival (MITF) in New York City. Because the playwright is based in Houston, the play is considered "out of town" and we therefore need to pay a $900 participation fee.

Every donation is greatly appreciated, and we will honor EVERY DONOR in our program to show our thanks!

Donors who give certain amounts will receive a special designation in the program that will be seen by hundreds of New York theatre lovers.

Ripple Makers - $25-49

Tide Makers - $50-99

Wave Makers - $100+

All funds go towards paying the participation fee required by MITF. If more than $900 is raised, those donations will go towards the production of "The Pull of the Moon" (technical elements, rehearsal spaces, paying our performers for their time, etc.).

 

Your Impact

Both Zubel and Steiger are recent college graduates pursuing their passion for the arts. We know the arts are not a lucrative field. Because of this, we are unable to pay the $900. Your contribution will make this great opportunity a reality. We will be able to bring Houston theatre to the forefront of New York City, and grow as artists.

Your contribution will also bring the topic of sexual assault to the surface, and open a conversation on how we as a society can help fix this prevalent issue.

Any donation is greatly appreciated; all waves begin with a ripple effect.

  

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that people don't always have a dollar to donate. If you'd to like to help in other ways, please spread the word! Help us take Houston theatre to New York City!

story:
What We Are Doing

We are extremely proud to have the opportunity to premiere Ebon Kojo: The Last Tribe at Baltimore’s Charm City Fringe Festival in November. This will be the first major production under our organization Afro House. 

Why This Is A Really Big Deal 

Ebon Kojo: The Last Tribe means so much to us. It is the story of our family, the biography of Scott, Alisha, Judah, and Ra Patterson, told through the wild imagination of an unapologetic sci-fi nerd.

Premiering the work at the Charm City Fringe Festival serves as an important step towards meeting our goal of touring The Last Tribe both nationally and internationally. Yes, our dream is BIG!!! For this leg of the journey Afro House is building its creative team, reaching out to the media to help create a buzz around the work and contacting organizations whose mission centers around the themes of the piece: space exploration, environmentalism and father/son relationships. Engaging communities in a conversation around these themes is incredibly important to the work of Afro House.

Afro House, Four Years Strong

We began Afro House with little more than a hope and a prayer, but through hard work, and your support, we have reached this point (and with our marriage still intact!!). This December Afro House will celebrate its four year anniversary. Afro House was created out of our shared vision for an organization that explores untapped and underdeveloped facets of the human story. The last four years have been filled with amazing opportunities to do work that is powerful and transformative. 

How You Can Help

Your support, whether it is in the form of money or in-kind donations, will help Afro House cover production costs, which include sound, lighting and costume design, building the set, and purchasing props. Through your donation, The Last Tribe will grow wings and fly.

Thank you for soaring with us. Your support continues to take us to new and impressive heights.


Fiscal Sponsor Information

Afro House is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Afro House must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
A paragon of theatre since its premiere, the text called “Hamlet” by William Shakespeare holds transformational power.  We seek to strip away previous associations, interpretations- until we find what is essential. 

The Players:

 

 

We are asking here for the support we require to let this play be: nothing more and nothing less. 

Producing independent theatre is not possible without generosity and support of our audience. If you are reading this, then you are almost certainly part of our audience and by extension, our community.

There is no one other than you.

Our expenses are posted here in the interest of total transparency:

story:
See bottom of this section for a transcription of the video!

*****

Who we are and what we are up to:

Hanlon McGregor is trans playwright and performer originally from Nova Scotia with a BA in theatre acting from Dalhousie University. Hanlon has taught and worked in dance and theatre for over two decades. Hanlon gender transitioned in his 40s and is proud to be creating theatre that he hopes is relevant to the trans community and the larger world.

Mihaly Szabados hails from Hungary and has an extensive background in film, tv, and theatre, and is thrilled to be spreading the message of human connection and empathy through stories that centre on voices that have not been given enough bandwidth, such as those of women, trans folks, and people of colour. Hanlon wrote Unexpectedly Trans with co-writer and director Mihaly in 2016 and 17 and it opened as a workshop at the Halifax Fringe in 2017. Unexpectedly Trans was the inspiration for the short film premiering this year called Holding Hands with the Awkward. 

HOLDING HANDS WITH THE AWKWARD (the short film)

Tsholo Khalema is a trans actor who joined us to make Holding Hands with the Awkward and take on the role of the Phil the pharmacist and also the thief. He is pleased to be involved and we are pleased to have him! Tsholo will also be taking on the role of Tyler in the new workshop play we are bringing called Bubble Trans Pride. Syrus Marcus Ware joins the cast to play trans man Tyler who is friends with Dan, played by Kit Boulter; These two have each other's back through the various awkward moments life can bring for transgender individuals. Claire McGregor also appears with Tsholo in the in the pharmacy scene.  

BUBBLE TRANS PRIDE (the play workshop)

Syrus Marcus Ware is joining Hanlon to co-write Bubble Trans Pride. Syrus is a visual and performance artist, activist, and Vanier Scholar.  He is also in rehearsal for Out the Window, a play that is opening in June as part of the Luminato Festival in Toronto. 

Hanlon and Syrus are proud and pleased to have received a Recommender Grant from the Ontario Arts Council via Buddies in Bad Times Theatre to begin writing Bubble Trans Pride, this grant has allowed us to work with amazing playwright/performer Diane Flacks (Waiting Room, Unholy) as our mentor and we feel blessed and inspired. 

Themes of Bubble Trans Pride include ways we do and do not belong as we transition and also the personal cost of activism for a trans Black Lives Matter member and activist. 

CAST - Mihaly will be directing and acting in the role of Bob, the bouncer and Tsholo will be performing the role of Tyler in this workshop.  We will be introducing more cast members who are local Halifax actors shortly. 

From Skype rehearsals to a very trans-Canadian cast (pardon the pun please), we have a lot of exciting and fringy things going on. We believe Halifax audiences are going to enjoy the challenging, funny, and moving elements of the work we are bringing and we look forward to sharing them!

What We Need & What You Get 

We need to get our actors and playwright to Nova Scotia and back - so to do that we need flights to be covered. We need to feed folks while they are there. We will also need funds for promoting the show, costume pieces, filming the work so we have an archival record and various other odds and ends that seem to pile up (getting in from the airport, moving set pieces around, etc). 

We estimate that we will need at least $3,000.00. 

If we don't reach our entire goal we will first be covering the costs of just getting the actors to Halifax and back - the flights. 

We are still working out what perks might be available. Stay tuned! 

 

The Impact

Your money will help us make a piece of theatre happen and also help us premiere a film we worked very hard to produce. These will both be full of trans themes and represent trans folks and trans POC. This piece can only grow with the help of an audience and taking the piece to Halifax Fringe is our next step. 

We tried to do our pieces locally - applying for  both the Hamilton Fringe and the Toronto Fringe two years running - but with such a small number of spots and a huge number of shows in the lotteries - we've been unsuccessful. However, we are lucky enough to be included in the Halifax Fringe for a second year and this allows us to take our pieces forward. 

The play we took last year is being made into a pilot to pitch to producers. The play we bring this year will also be honed and hopefully make it to being produced in Toronto and also possibly made into a film, tv-, or web-series. Every bit of support gets us closer to the goal of making work that can be shared both on stage and screen and eventually reach a wide audience. 

Hanlon says, "When I was transitioning I consumed every bit of theatre, film, tv and youtube content I could find, and I know the importance of having trans representation. It is vital to be able to see ourselves, our stories reflected in the world."

It is also important for potential allies to hear trans stories, as it increases the chance for understanding and real change in our culture. 

Risks & Challenges

One of the biggest risks is the expense of getting the shows to NS and getting bums in seats once we are there - unlike other kinds of theatre, there is no travel funding for fringe work. 

It's also tricky to self produce because a lot of government funding is hard to get because there is stiff competition - and although we have received some funding - we have prepared many applications that were not able to be funded - and every minute spent preparing a grant application is a minute that could instead be used to write or create, but it's almost all on our own dime and we need to live in the meantime. For this reason getting into fringe allows us to be produced and therefore we can focus on making the art - if we can get support to get there. 

Breaking into the festivals is also taking time, and although we were honoured to be shortlisted for Rhubarb Festival this year, we did not get selected. We are hopeful to be successful in the future, but we need to keep making and developing work in the mean time. 

One of our big challenges this year is that part of the cast is in Halifax (in part to avoid even more travel costs - but also to work with some amazing folks of course!!!) This means we have to be really creative about how we rehearse - Skype is going to be our friend! And we will be putting things together quickly at the end of August! This is one that money may or may not help but it is definitely going to have us (and hopefully you) at the edge of our seats to see how it all comes together!!! As one of our actors said, this project is "Fringy as hell!" And I think it will be in all the best of ways. 

Other Ways You Can Help

• If you can't help us in the way of money, we can always use a donation of a good or service that we could offer to others as a reward for their contribution - get in touch and let us know if you have some kind of prize to contribute!

• Word of mouth - goodness. We always need help getting the word out - both about the show and about this campaign. Please forward this campaign far and wide!

• Rehearsal space in Toronto in July/August or Halifax final week of August

• Drives in from the airport in August or back to the Airport in September - we have some covered but let us know if you are also around and able to drive someone.

• Food for the artists while in Halifax - gift cards for Bulk Barn, Loblaws, etc. could be helpful-

• Lodging in Halifax - we think we have lodging, but we may need more. Do get in touch if you have space between Aug 25th or so and Sept 10!

• Car rental points or coupons with Enterprise for moving set pieces (if we have them). 

We will update this area of 'things we need other than money' as we get closer! 

Now please go donate if you can! And share share share - if you feel called! 

Thanks all!

 

Transcription of first video:

“Hi I’m Hanlon McGregor. I’m a trans playwright, actor, director, and I am also making films these days.” 

“My name is Tsholo Khalema and I’m an actor, aspiring director and a film and theatre photographer and I’m super stoked to be part of this project” 

“My name is Mishy and I’m and actor-director and a founder of Iza’s? Productions” 

Hanlon: “Right now I want to talk to you about a new project I’m doing called ‘Bubble Trans Pride’ and I’m working on it with my co-writer, my writing consultant Syrus Marcus Ware who is involved in a lot of Black Lives Matter projects and also is an amazing visual artist, activist” 

Tsholo: “This project is so inspiring, it’s a pleasure to be part of this because first it encompasses a lot of what I want to do and a lot of what I want project out there in the world as an artist. So it talks about trans issues, it talks about queerness as a whole, and really talks about personally my own different intersectionalities throughout the queerness and the blackness and so forth” 

Hanlon: “Part of what this project is about is talking about how in our queer community, and in the greater community, a lot of activists are paying a toll. They’re paying a toll for the good of a lot of other people, and one of my questions in writing this project is ‘what is the personal cost of that activism?’ And also one of the other questions I’ve asked is ‘what does transition promise, versus what does it deliver? So, what are the ways we look for belonging in our communities? And sometimes we find that on the other side of transition and for some people it’s not crossing to another side they land somewhere in the middle. Are we finding the belonging that we seek? Are we finding that sense of community and in what ways are we not finding that sense of community, and in what ways do we need to kind of consider the community that we’re building?” 

Mishy: “We have similar interests and we like a lot of things similar, and we like artistic ways, and like to change the world with arts. Hanlon asked me if I can read his monologue. And I started to read it and give some feedback, and then turned into “Unexpectedly Trans” like the whole concept.” 

Hanlon in film clip as Dan:  

“This is our Hamlet moment (repeated, layered). Yours (repeated, layered) and mine (repeated, layered)” 

 

Tsholo: “It’s just really important to tell these kind of stories. Again these kind of stories are not often heard and as artists, it’s really difficult to get funding. So we’re asking to please support this project, it’s gonna be amazing! It tells a different story than what we’ve heard. And I ‘m just looking forward to just going out there and sharing these characters with you” 

Clip from short film Holding Hands with the Awkward, Tsholo as the theif: 

“Tampons. Not anymore!” 

Mishy: “I we are building a company. That’s what I believe we are. We are gathering people together, just me and Hanlon first, and now we have Tsholo, we have a couple of people. We have a DOP we use all the time. (Carl Greene) We have a stunt person now, and Ingrid Hart, so we are building slowly. Slowly building up this company and hopefully we can tell, we want to tell stories that never been told” 

Hanlon: “We need practical things like we need to get Tsholo to Nova Scotia so that he can act  

Mishy in the background: “How 'bout me? How ‘bout me?” 
 
Hanlon: “(laughs) We need to get Mishy to Nova Scotia too so he can direct and act” 

Excerpt from the new play being rehearsed: 

Mishy as Bob: “Whoa (laughs)! Mad skills” 

Tsholo as Tyler: “I try!” 

Bob: “Is it for black trans power or something?” 

Tsholo: “Nailed it!” 

BOB: “Yay! (High fives)” 

Tyler: “Yay, yeah” 

Hanlon: “Like, it’s really, it’s not a lot of money in the grand scheme of things, but if we don’t get it, we can’t do the project so that’s why we need your help” 

Mishy: “We want catharsis, we want people to change, we want people to cry, to laugh. I think it’s gonna be a great project, please support us” 

“And I think it’s a pretty important thing, I think it’s gonna have a lot of positive benefit” 

Tsholo: “(Laughing) I haven’t posted it yet, I’m waiting 

“Amazing””
story_txt:
See bottom of this section for a transcription of the video!
*****
Who we are and what we are up to:
Hanlon McGregor is trans playwright and performer originally from Nova Scotia with a BA in theatre acting from Dalhousie University. Hanlon has taught and worked in dance and theatre for over two decades. Hanlon gender transitioned in his 40s and is proud to be creating theatre that he hopes is relevant to the trans community and the larger world.
Mihaly Szabados hails from Hungary and has an extensive background in film, tv, and theatre, and is thrilled to be spreading the message of human connection and empathy through stories that centre on voices that have not been given enough bandwidth, such as those of women, trans folks, and people of colour. Hanlon wrote Unexpectedly Trans with co-writer and director Mihaly in 2016 and 17 and it opened as a workshop at the Halifax Fringe in 2017. Unexpectedly Trans was the inspiration for the short film premiering this year called Holding Hands with the Awkward. 
HOLDING HANDS WITH THE AWKWARD (the short film)
Tsholo Khalema is a trans actor who joined us to make Holding Hands with the Awkward and take on the role of the Phil the pharmacist and also the thief. He is pleased to be involved and we are pleased to have him! Tsholo will also be taking on the role of Tyler in the new workshop play we are bringing called Bubble Trans Pride. Syrus Marcus Ware joins the cast to play trans man Tyler who is friends with Dan, played by Kit Boulter; These two have each other's back through the various awkward moments life can bring for transgender individuals. Claire McGregor also appears with Tsholo in the in the pharmacy scene.  
BUBBLE TRANS PRIDE (the play workshop)
Syrus Marcus Ware is joining Hanlon to co-write Bubble Trans Pride. Syrus is a visual and performance artist, activist, and Vanier Scholar.  He is also in rehearsal for Out the Window, a play that is opening in June as part of the Luminato Festival in Toronto. 
Hanlon and Syrus are proud and pleased to have received a Recommender Grant from the Ontario Arts Council via Buddies in Bad Times Theatre to begin writing Bubble Trans Pride, this grant has allowed us to work with amazing playwright/performer Diane Flacks (Waiting Room, Unholy) as our mentor and we feel blessed and inspired. 
Themes of Bubble Trans Pride include ways we do and do not belong as we transition and also the personal cost of activism for a trans Black Lives Matter member and activist. 
CAST - Mihaly will be directing and acting in the role of Bob, the bouncer and Tsholo will be performing the role of Tyler in this workshop.  We will be introducing more cast members who are local Halifax actors shortly. 
From Skype rehearsals to a very trans-Canadian cast (pardon the pun please), we have a lot of exciting and fringy things going on. We believe Halifax audiences are going to enjoy the challenging, funny, and moving elements of the work we are bringing and we look forward to sharing them!

What We Need & What You Get 
We need to get our actors and playwright to Nova Scotia and back - so to do that we need flights to be covered. We need to feed folks while they are there. We will also need funds for promoting the show, costume pieces, filming the work so we have an archival record and various other odds and ends that seem to pile up (getting in from the airport, moving set pieces around, etc). 
We estimate that we will need at least $3,000.00. 
If we don't reach our entire goal we will first be covering the costs of just getting the actors to Halifax and back - the flights. 
We are still working out what perks might be available. Stay tuned! 
 

The Impact
Your money will help us make a piece of theatre happen and also help us premiere a film we worked very hard to produce. These will both be full of trans themes and represent trans folks and trans POC. This piece can only grow with the help of an audience and taking the piece to Halifax Fringe is our next step. 
We tried to do our pieces locally - applying for  both the Hamilton Fringe and the Toronto Fringe two years running - but with such a small number of spots and a huge number of shows in the lotteries - we've been unsuccessful. However, we are lucky enough to be included in the Halifax Fringe for a second year and this allows us to take our pieces forward. 
The play we took last year is being made into a pilot to pitch to producers. The play we bring this year will also be honed and hopefully make it to being produced in Toronto and also possibly made into a film, tv-, or web-series. Every bit of support gets us closer to the goal of making work that can be shared both on stage and screen and eventually reach a wide audience. 
Hanlon says, "When I was transitioning I consumed every bit of theatre, film, tv and youtube content I could find, and I know the importance of having trans representation. It is vital to be able to see ourselves, our stories reflected in the world."
It is also important for potential allies to hear trans stories, as it increases the chance for understanding and real change in our culture. 

Risks & Challenges
One of the biggest risks is the expense of getting the shows to NS and getting bums in seats once we are there - unlike other kinds of theatre, there is no travel funding for fringe work. 
It's also tricky to self produce because a lot of government funding is hard to get because there is stiff competition - and although we have received some funding - we have prepared many applications that were not able to be funded - and every minute spent preparing a grant application is a minute that could instead be used to write or create, but it's almost all on our own dime and we need to live in the meantime. For this reason getting into fringe allows us to be produced and therefore we can focus on making the art - if we can get support to get there. 
Breaking into the festivals is also taking time, and although we were honoured to be shortlisted for Rhubarb Festival this year, we did not get selected. We are hopeful to be successful in the future, but we need to keep making and developing work in the mean time. 
One of our big challenges this year is that part of the cast is in Halifax (in part to avoid even more travel costs - but also to work with some amazing folks of course!!!) This means we have to be really creative about how we rehearse - Skype is going to be our friend! And we will be putting things together quickly at the end of August! This is one that money may or may not help but it is definitely going to have us (and hopefully you) at the edge of our seats to see how it all comes together!!! As one of our actors said, this project is "Fringy as hell!" And I think it will be in all the best of ways. 

Other Ways You Can Help
• If you can't help us in the way of money, we can always use a donation of a good or service that we could offer to others as a reward for their contribution - get in touch and let us know if you have some kind of prize to contribute!
• Word of mouth - goodness. We always need help getting the word out - both about the show and about this campaign. Please forward this campaign far and wide!
• Rehearsal space in Toronto in July/August or Halifax final week of August
• Drives in from the airport in August or back to the Airport in September - we have some covered but let us know if you are also around and able to drive someone.
• Food for the artists while in Halifax - gift cards for Bulk Barn, Loblaws, etc. could be helpful-
• Lodging in Halifax - we think we have lodging, but we may need more. Do get in touch if you have space between Aug 25th or so and Sept 10!
• Car rental points or coupons with Enterprise for moving set pieces (if we have them). 
We will update this area of 'things we need other than money' as we get closer! 
Now please go donate if you can! And share share share - if you feel called! 
Thanks all!
 
Transcription of first video:
“Hi I’m Hanlon McGregor. I’m a trans playwright, actor, director, and I am also making films these days.” 
“My name is Tsholo Khalema and I’m an actor, aspiring director and a film and theatre photographer and I’m super stoked to be part of this project” 
“My name is Mishy and I’m and actor-director and a founder of Iza’s? Productions” 
Hanlon: “Right now I want to talk to you about a new project I’m doing called ‘Bubble Trans Pride’ and I’m working on it with my co-writer, my writing consultant Syrus Marcus Ware who is involved in a lot of Black Lives Matter projects and also is an amazing visual artist, activist” 
Tsholo: “This project is so inspiring, it’s a pleasure to be part of this because first it encompasses a lot of what I want to do and a lot of what I want project out there in the world as an artist. So it talks about trans issues, it talks about queerness as a whole, and really talks about personally my own different intersectionalities throughout the queerness and the blackness and so forth” 
Hanlon: “Part of what this project is about is talking about how in our queer community, and in the greater community, a lot of activists are paying a toll. They’re paying a toll for the good of a lot of other people, and one of my questions in writing this project is ‘what is the personal cost of that activism?’ And also one of the other questions I’ve asked is ‘what does transition promise, versus what does it deliver? So, what are the ways we look for belonging in our communities? And sometimes we find that on the other side of transition and for some people it’s not crossing to another side they land somewhere in the middle. Are we finding the belonging that we seek? Are we finding that sense of community and in what ways are we not finding that sense of community, and in what ways do we need to kind of consider the community that we’re building?” 
Mishy: “We have similar interests and we like a lot of things similar, and we like artistic ways, and like to change the world with arts. Hanlon asked me if I can read his monologue. And I started to read it and give some feedback, and then turned into “Unexpectedly Trans” like the whole concept.” 
Hanlon in film clip as Dan:  
“This is our Hamlet moment (repeated, layered). Yours (repeated, layered) and mine (repeated, layered)” 
 
Tsholo: “It’s just really important to tell these kind of stories. Again these kind of stories are not often heard and as artists, it’s really difficult to get funding. So we’re asking to please support this project, it’s gonna be amazing! It tells a different story than what we’ve heard. And I ‘m just looking forward to just going out there and sharing these characters with you” 
Clip from short film Holding Hands with the Awkward, Tsholo as the theif: 
“Tampons. Not anymore!” 
Mishy: “I we are building a company. That’s what I believe we are. We are gathering people together, just me and Hanlon first, and now we have Tsholo, we have a couple of people. We have a DOP we use all the time. (Carl Greene) We have a stunt person now, and Ingrid Hart, so we are building slowly. Slowly building up this company and hopefully we can tell, we want to tell stories that never been told” 
Hanlon: “We need practical things like we need to get Tsholo to Nova Scotia so that he can act  
Mishy in the background: “How 'bout me? How ‘bout me?”  Hanlon: “(laughs) We need to get Mishy to Nova Scotia too so he can direct and act” 
Excerpt from the new play being rehearsed: 
Mishy as Bob: “Whoa (laughs)! Mad skills” 
Tsholo as Tyler: “I try!” 
Bob: “Is it for black trans power or something?” 
Tsholo: “Nailed it!” 
BOB: “Yay! (High fives)” 
Tyler: “Yay, yeah” 
Hanlon: “Like, it’s really, it’s not a lot of money in the grand scheme of things, but if we don’t get it, we can’t do the project so that’s why we need your help” 
Mishy: “We want catharsis, we want people to change, we want people to cry, to laugh. I think it’s gonna be a great project, please support us” 
“And I think it’s a pretty important thing, I think it’s gonna have a lot of positive benefit” 
Tsholo: “(Laughing) I haven’t posted it yet, I’m waiting 
“Amazing””

story:
Sapience Dance Collective is three female artists who choreograph, direct, produce, dance and make art together in Seattle and around the world.

We do it for the love of it and over six years audiences keep coming back for more.  

As you saw in the video, this year will include four major performances:

  1. CONVERGE - dance festival featuring over 50 Northwest artists (choreographers, dancers, musicians, and videographers)
  2. Dancing About Architecture - our largest site specific work to date at City Hall
  3. On the Boards - Open Studio
  4. Dance and live choir - with the Everett Chorale

**However, you may not know, that even with a sold out show every night, ticket sales can only cover half of the costs.**

I did not believe this myself at first, but when you add up the costs of the venue, small stipends for many artists, printing costs for programs and posters, the cost is real. 

Yet, the benefit for those who experience the work is lasting in their hearts and minds during and after the performance. A great dance show can change a life. 

Your help, as someone who sees the great value of  dance, is necessary to bring a stellar series of performances to life this year!

Please click now to make your gift. You can make exceptional art happen and we can't do it without you. 

If we don't reach our goal by 2/22/15 at midnight we will not be able to make this season happen.


Thank you so much for taking the time to find out about what we are doing and thank you for a gift in any amount toward our goal. 

Yours, 
Sarah, Amy, Lilah
And the many, many artists we work with.

Sapience Dance Collective is fiscally sponsored by Shunpike, a 501c3 organization.

story:
1919. The artist Florine Stettheimer retreats to her upstate family home after a disastrous first exhibition in New York. One year later, her socialite sisters host a soiree to unveil Florine’s latest work. The guests are famous members of the art world elite – and they can’t wait to judge.

The Unveiling is my biggest play so far - it's a ten-character period piece. Yes, I said ten characters. Yes, I also said period piece. And to answer your third, unspoken question: yes, I'm crazy. 

I need your support to make this play happen.

Your financial support will go towards:

9 hardworking Actors                                                                                                                                     A passionate Director                                                                                                                                         An innovative Producer                                                                                                                                     A dedicated Stage Manager                                                                                                                         And an inspired Production Team, including Set, Costume, Light, and Sound Designers.                                                                                                                                                       

Your donations will also help us acquire the material to physically realize our modest, yet daring production - and Rehearsal Space.

In return, you'll get some pretty sweet, personalized gifts.

Most importantly, your love will truly make this show happen. Your love means helping to spread word about the production and this campaign!
If you would like to make a tax-deductible donation, please contact me directly and we can arrange this separately. 

Thanks for all your love and support. 

And please - check out my rad video - filmed and edited by the invaluable Wes Jones!

story:
Who We Are: 

Founded and directed by Marie-Christine Giordano, MCGD premiered in 2002 with a commission from L'Espace Moncor in Switzerland. Since then, the company has created 10 full-length evening pieces and with headquarters in Brooklyn, Giordano maintains a teaching schedule, offering technique classes to professionals, nonprofessionals and Brooklyn public school children. MCGD is a non for profit (501)(c)(3) and your donation is tax-deductible to the full extent provided by law.

After a very successful spring season at BAM Fisher in early June of 2017, the company is currently focused on producing this technique video demonstration. The video will demonstrate the core principles of the Giordano's Alignment  and structured training class developed by Giordano over the years. We are teaming up with the Gibney Dance Center Creative Services&Digital Technology department in NYC, who will be filming and editing the film in collaboration with MCGD. 

This video will increase our ability to reach out and to educate professional dancers, nonprofessionals, and public school children. Additionally, we will send it to universities and colleges across the country in order to apply for teaching residencies. Here in NYC, we will use it to enhance our image and visibility within the dance community, and as a result make our dance technique more accessible to all. 

"Ms. Giordano is clearly a choreographer committed to constructing a personal dance vocabulary.”  -Gia Kourlas, The New York Times.

Where Your Support Goes: 

It goes without saying that the impact of your support is invaluable.

Your donation will be used to contribute to:

Artistic Pay: This project will provide the opportunity for three dancers to experience the making of a professional dance video as well as display their expertise in the technique. It is vital we provide them with adequate compensation for their time. This includes time spent not only during the shoot, but the hours of preparation and planning Marie-Christine will input need to be accounted for as well. 

Location: The filming will take place at Gibney, in one of their spacious, newly renovated studios. While we are excited to be in a new studio, it comes at a cost. Your help will give us literal space to move in! 

Videographer/Editing: We are working with the fabulous film team at Gibney. We will pay for their services which include both filming and editing of the video. Marie-Christine will be present and deeply involved in all editing sessions. 

 

With your help we can make this video demonstration a smashing success! Thank you for checking out what we're up to and taking the time to read this campaign. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We value your donations immensely, but you can also contribute by spreading the word through social media, word of mouth, etc. Please share this campaign with your friends and colleagues. Stay connected with our activities by liking our Facebook page and following us on Instagram.

Once the video is completed please check it out and share!!

The mission of MCGD is to use the medium of dance, which we see as an expressive, healing, and unifying art form, to convey messages of life affirmation, beauty, and community that go well beyond language and cultural differences. We explore the complex landscape of the human heart through performance, teaching, outreach, and other programs.
