story:
LONG LOST JOHN: A LENNON FAMILY STORY 

Sat. Aug. 4 (8:30 p.m.), Mon. Aug. 6 (8:30 p.m.), & Sat. Aug. 11 (1:30 p.m.)
The Theater at 14th Street Y | 344 E 14th St, New York, NY 10003

Purchase tickets HERE
Visit our Facebook page to keep up to date with our progress
Learn more about the Broadway Bound Theatre Festival

 

The Play

John Lennon was born during a Nazi air raid on Liverpool, an omen of things to come as tumultuous events would shape his young life. Abandoned by his father, he's ripped away from his devoted mother to be raised by his aunt. Depressed, he's saved by a guitar strummer named Paul McCartney and 1950’s Rock 'n Roll.

Backstory

I fell in love with The Beatles in junior high. I was one of those fans.  I devoured books about the band, and constantly quoted their lyrics. I loved their music, their idealism and their humor.

So I was surprised to learn that John Lennon had suffered terrible losses as a child. Personal tragedies can be devastating at any age, but all the more so for a young person. I became fascinated by John's story, by the influences, the family and friends that nurtured and guided him.

What I found was a powerful cast of characters, all doing the best they could under the pressure of extremely difficult circumstances. But more than that, I found patterns of behavior, and a universal story that applies to all of us. That's the heart of our play "Long Lost John."

Where We're At

We're thrilled to tell the story of "Long Lost John!"

The Broadway Bound Theater Festival is the perfect next step. It's both an incubator of script and story, as well as a platform to develop and produce our show. We're so proud to be a part of it.

To guide "Long Lost John" through to production, we need to raise $7,000. All of this money will go directly to the show. We've assembled a talented team of actors and theater pros who are as passionate about telling this story as we are. And we want you to join our team.

BUDGET

  • $3,600: Actors & Creative Team (Stage Manager, Designers, Techs)
  • $1,200: Rehearsal Space
  • $500: Advertising/Marketing/Key Art
  • $350: Printing Costs (Scripts, Program Inserts, Press Kits)
  • $300: Archival Filming & Photography
  • $300: Costumes/Sets/Props
  • $250: Insurance
  • $500: IndieGoGo Fees (5%) + Transaction Fees (3%)

TOTAL NEEDED: $7,000

Joining us on the path entitles you to some unique perks, such as sneak peeks into our creative process. Get a backstage tour of the show. Join us in the theater. Or meet up with us after a performance. If you can't make it in person, we have signed cards, posters and copies of the script we'd love to send your way.

Where We're Headed

As a writer and researcher I've worked on projects for SNL Studios and National Public Radio (NPR). I've loved contributing to serious documentaries for PBS and comedy shorts for the internet. But nothing I've every worked on has had the pure heart of "Long Lost John."

John Lennon's true childhood story of heartbreak and resilience is grander than anything I could make up. And there are real lessons to be learned from his example and the story of his family.

That's why we're partnering with several charitable organizations that provide services to families dealing with loss. In the spirit of The Beatles themselves, it's our way of lending a hand, and giving back.

Arrival

We don't have much time! Our first performance is less than a month away!

We've got a truly incredible team ready to go. This includes Melissa Zakri Zareh, graduate of NYU's Educational Theater grad program, and an accomplished events producer as the head of our team. We have a cast of truly talented actors already in rehearsals. And we have a production team with a proven track record of success.

We ask that you contribute to our campaign.  Your donation is gas in our creative tank. Please help us cross the finish line. 

Meet Us There

There are lots of ways you can come along for the ride.

Please get the word out about "Long Lost John!" We'd love to have your support no matter what form it takes. We'd be truly grateful to have you aboard.

We'd love to hear from you!  LostJohnShow [at] gmail [dot] com | Facebook
story_txt:
LONG LOST JOHN: A LENNON FAMILY STORY 
Sat. Aug. 4 (8:30 p.m.), Mon. Aug. 6 (8:30 p.m.), & Sat. Aug. 11 (1:30 p.m.)The Theater at 14th Street Y | 344 E 14th St, New York, NY 10003
Purchase tickets HERE Visit our Facebook page to keep up to date with our progressLearn more about the Broadway Bound Theatre Festival
 
The Play
John Lennon was born during a Nazi air raid on Liverpool, an omen of things to come as tumultuous events would shape his young life. Abandoned by his father, he's ripped away from his devoted mother to be raised by his aunt. Depressed, he's saved by a guitar strummer named Paul McCartney and 1950’s Rock 'n Roll.
Backstory
I fell in love with The Beatles in junior high. I was one of those fans.  I devoured books about the band, and constantly quoted their lyrics. I loved their music, their idealism and their humor.
So I was surprised to learn that John Lennon had suffered terrible losses as a child. Personal tragedies can be devastating at any age, but all the more so for a young person. I became fascinated by John's story, by the influences, the family and friends that nurtured and guided him.
What I found was a powerful cast of characters, all doing the best they could under the pressure of extremely difficult circumstances. But more than that, I found patterns of behavior, and a universal story that applies to all of us. That's the heart of our play "Long Lost John."

Where We're At
We're thrilled to tell the story of "Long Lost John!"
The Broadway Bound Theater Festival is the perfect next step. It's both an incubator of script and story, as well as a platform to develop and produce our show. We're so proud to be a part of it.
To guide "Long Lost John" through to production, we need to raise $7,000. All of this money will go directly to the show. We've assembled a talented team of actors and theater pros who are as passionate about telling this story as we are. And we want you to join our team.
BUDGET

$3,600: Actors & Creative Team (Stage Manager, Designers, Techs)
$1,200: Rehearsal Space
$500: Advertising/Marketing/Key Art
$350: Printing Costs (Scripts, Program Inserts, Press Kits)
$300: Archival Filming & Photography
$300: Costumes/Sets/Props
$250: Insurance
$500: IndieGoGo Fees (5%) + Transaction Fees (3%)

TOTAL NEEDED: $7,000
Joining us on the path entitles you to some unique perks, such as sneak peeks into our creative process. Get a backstage tour of the show. Join us in the theater. Or meet up with us after a performance. If you can't make it in person, we have signed cards, posters and copies of the script we'd love to send your way.

Where We're Headed
As a writer and researcher I've worked on projects for SNL Studios and National Public Radio (NPR). I've loved contributing to serious documentaries for PBS and comedy shorts for the internet. But nothing I've every worked on has had the pure heart of "Long Lost John."
John Lennon's true childhood story of heartbreak and resilience is grander than anything I could make up. And there are real lessons to be learned from his example and the story of his family.
That's why we're partnering with several charitable organizations that provide services to families dealing with loss. In the spirit of The Beatles themselves, it's our way of lending a hand, and giving back.

Arrival
We don't have much time! Our first performance is less than a month away!
We've got a truly incredible team ready to go. This includes Melissa Zakri Zareh, graduate of NYU's Educational Theater grad program, and an accomplished events producer as the head of our team. We have a cast of truly talented actors already in rehearsals. And we have a production team with a proven track record of success.
We ask that you contribute to our campaign.  Your donation is gas in our creative tank. Please help us cross the finish line. 

Meet Us There
There are lots of ways you can come along for the ride.
Please get the word out about "Long Lost John!" We'd love to have your support no matter what form it takes. We'd be truly grateful to have you aboard.
We'd love to hear from you!  LostJohnShow [at] gmail [dot] com | Facebook

story:
STORM

The work fleshes out Gustav Holst's powerful Planets Suite, coming up on a 100 year anniversary of its 1918 premier. The characters in "STORM" exhibit extreme emotional states, but ultimately represent the varying beautiful and petrifying emotions which can all be found in a single human being.

Showtimes: Thursday, September 14 at 7:30 and Sunday, September 17 at 2:30 and 4:30
Tickets at:    http://www.danceboxoffice.com/?page_id=1107

Photo by Keith Reid Photography

Asya Zlatina was born in Moscow, Russia and grew up training in the DC/Baltimore area. She graduated with a B.A. in Dance and Psychology from Goucher College, and joined Koresh Dance Company in 2008. She serves as an adjunct of dance at Stockton University and holds an M.S. in Non-Profits Administration from Drexel University. She premiered her first Fringe Festival show, "BARRY: Mamaloshen in Dance!", in 2016. "STORM" will be her second show. 
See her story here:

http://www.judischekulturbund.com/russia/

 

Inside the Rehearsal Process...Art is No COCA-COLA!

Photo by Mike Hurwitz

Art is a process. We have no conveyor belt to create shows faster, and no tools to make human dancers double the amount of performances per week. We take time to develop our final product and work as starving artists against a natural increase in productivity which exists in other fields.  

Your support affects the richness in our city's landscape.  
Every dollar is greatly appreciated.
With every dollar, you become  an integral part of cultivating the arts and dance in Philadelphia.

Where Does the Money Go?

Your contribution to this project directly funds our access to:

  • THE PERFORMANCE VENUE
  • STUDIO RENTALS FOR THE CREATION PERIOD
  • PRINTING SHOW PROGRAMS
  • MARKETING MATERIALS
  • COSTUMING
  • OUR BREAD AND BUTTER--Feed the dancers! We are so skinny. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? You can support by sharing this campaign with friends who can, and posting in social media. 

Thank you!

ASYA

Photo by Hector Vazquez

story:
Hi friends! We're so excited to launch this project and share it with you! This is the most expansive, out-of-the box artistic endeavor we have ever worked on and we need YOUR help to make it happen!! Please check out what it’s all about and support us:

The Theatrical Culinary Project is an immersive play and dining experience featuring culinary sensation, co-host of The Chew & Top Chef finalist, Carla Hall 

Created by director Marlo Hunter and actor & producer Sasha Eden 

Set in a restaurant, the lines of reality and fiction are blurred as the audience dines on a four-course meal while submerged in a multi-layered play written by           award-winning playwrights:

Courtney Baron (MCC’s A Very Common Procedure) 

Hilary Bettis (NNPN’s Ghosts of Lote Bravo) 

Daniel Pearle (LCT3’s A Kid Like Jake)

Currently in development with an upcoming two-week workshop July 28th-August 7th, the goal is an immersive production in a tailor-made venue that ignites all five senses and fuses the theatrical and culinary arts into one cohesive experience. 

Read our artists' bios



Start with 1 part Marlo Hunter 

In 2008, award-winning director & choreographer, Marlo Hunter’s site-specific theater company, Eating Their Words, was leading a new wave of immersive projects in New York City theater. Combining her two passions, developing new plays and experiencing great food, Marlo partnered with notable playwrights and chefs throughout New York City to produce one-night-only events, inviting foodie and theater-loving audiences alike to exquisite three-course meals matched with three great plays. After two years of producing these events, working with Pulitzer, Tony and James Beard award-winning playwrights, actors, and chefs, Marlo dreamed of expanding her vision from a one-night-only event into a full production.

Add 1 part Sasha Eden 

In 2011, Marlo met actor & producer, Sasha Eden, co-founder of the critically acclaimed Off-Broadway company, WET Productions. Marlo had attended a number of Sasha's productions, and was inspired by her creation of bold new work and her commitment to gender parity. By following the mission of WET, to produce media that challenges female stereotypes and advocates for equality, Sasha had furthered the careers of numerous women artists in the entertainment industry.

Upon meeting Marlo, Sasha was struck by her talent, entrepreneurial spirit and keen artistic eye. They began to crack open the idea for an expanded version of Eating Their Words: what if the series of short plays could coalesce into one larger story with a connective arc? What if the theater were designed to operate as a restaurant, thereby building the conceit within a naturalistic framework? What if the audience was submerged within the play itself, dining on a tasting menu that serves as a muse for the stories unfolding around them? And lastly, a non-negotiable: what if, at the center of it all, there was a female chef?

Add 1 part Chef Carla Hall 

And so it happened that in 2013, while Sasha was watching Top Chef, it dawned on her that Chef Carla Hall, her favorite contestant ever, would be the ideal match for this project. Nimble, savvy, collaborative, full of creativity, Carla was perfect. Serendipitously, two weeks later, Sasha met Carla on an empty subway car in the middle of the day. Feeling as if she was struck by lightening (in a good way), Sasha introduced herself to Carla. As fortune would have it Carla shared Marlo and Sasha's dream to merge the theatrical and culinary arts…. and so the collaboration began.

Add 3 cups each of Courtney Baron, Hilary Bettis and Daniel Pearle & stir vigorously

This past spring, after an extensive search, Sasha and Marlo invited playwrights Courtney Baron, Hilary Bettis, & Daniel Pearle to join the creative team. Each writer is matched with a course on Carla’s menu, and their plays are inspired by the essence of the food in that given course. These plays will reflect the different economic, emotional, and historical perspectives found in this restaurant, from patrons, to front and back of house staff. And, of course, Carla's menu tells a story in tandem with the plays. 

Now let it simmer...

Our team spent four days in a creative think tank this past spring getting to know one another as collaborators, and now we are off to build the play during our summer workshop.

Building this play requires that we work with one another through a series of workshops, as the plays and the food are integrated to tell one story.  Our upcoming two-week summer workshop process will begin on July 28th with a residency at SPACE on Ryder Farm, a non-profit arts organization in Brewster, NY. SPACE provides a retreat outside of the city, for artists to live and develop new work. The Theatrical Culinary Project was awarded a five-day residency at SPACE, where we will focus exclusively on the development of the scripts. Following Ryder Farm we will return to New York City to integrate Carla's food and menu into the structure of the plays, work with an ensemble cast, continue script development, rehearse with our entire team, prep for a four course meal and reading, and close with an intimate presentation for a handful of audience members, to assess the impact the immersive experience has on the piece. 

By September our cast size will be solidified, we will understand the type of space that will enhance the storytelling, have a solid estimate of food and service costs, and an estimated timeline for continued development, all of which will enable us to create a marketing and business plan for building partnerships that will help us move The Theatrical Culinary Project forward. 



The Theatrical Culinary Project  is built by a team of 22 generous people, with a belief in a common artistic goal. The budget for the summer workshop requires a lean minimum of $45,000 to build.  Following the workshop we will need to raise an additional $25,000 to cover costs for continued development. We turn to you, our invaluable community of supporters, champions, partners and friends, to help us raise the first $30,000 on Indiegogo and propel us toward our overall goal!

Our workshop budget covers: 

  • Artists' fees for 22 people
  • Insurance
  • Food & Supplies
  • Printing of scripts
  • Transportation
  • Ryder Farm supplementary fees 
  • Venue 1: A commercial kitchen with a dining room
  • Venue 2: A rehearsal space 
  • And more... 

We are fiscally sponsored by the 501(c)3 non-profit organization, Fractured Atlas, and your contributions are tax deductible to the full extent of the law! Every dollar you donate, from $10 to $5,000, will help us reach our goal.

Fiscal sponsorship from Fractured Atlas allows us to raise tax-deductible funds for the play, piece by piece, finding support from individual donations and grants that are exclusively committed to nurturing the developing work. 

Here's a pie chart to make the breakdown of our expenses more appetizing:  

                             


We've got some delicious perks for your generosity!  Chef Carla Hall is opening her very first eatery, Carla Hall's Southern Kitchen, right here in New York, slated for fall 2015!  What does that mean for you?  Our perks include gift certificates for Carla Hall's Southern Kitchen, invitations to a public reading of the work, signed copies of Carla's original menu for The Theatrical Culinary Project, an exclusive book of recipes from Carla's TCP menu, and tickets to Bravo's Watch What Happens Live hosted by Andy Cohen. Plus our top tier donors are rewarded with an invitation to our August 6th presentation that includes a private four course meal and a reading of the new play performed by notable actors. 




Please contribute to TCP!  Other ways you can help are:  

Share this campaign with your network!  

Like our Facebook page!  

Follow us on Twitter @TCPfoodplay

Check out our Website: www.TheatricalCulinaryProject.com


Credits:

Logo Design: Kayla Silber

Videography & Editing:  AJV Media 

Music For Video: "Faster Does It" Kevin MacLeod (incompetech.com) 

Licensed under Creative Commons: By Attribution 3.0
http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/

story:
Short Summary

 

Cameron Lombard & Donlynn Fischer are the South African Junior Ballroom & Latin Dance champions.  They have not lost one competition since their partnership started 3 years ago.  They were finalists on SA GOT TALENT 2012.

What We Need & What You Get

 

We are in dire need of ballroom dance dress for the upcoming SA Championships on 11-13th December.  She has been making use of 2 dresses for the last year and a half and I always notice the admiration for other girls on her face as they are more privileged and able to afford a dress for every competition.  Unfortunately we as parents are struggling financially but really want to keep our kids in the sport they are so passionate about and cannot spoil their dream because of our financial situation.

The Impact

 

To  have a new dress for the championships will really light up Donlynn's heart and will be grateful for any contribution you are able to make to reach our amount required.

Risks & Challenges

 We all believe that if you look good, you feel good and if you feel good, you do good.  This will really inspire Donlynn to shine even more that was she already has.  We as parents will be forever grateful.

Other Ways You Can Help

We will be very grateful for any form of assistance anyone can offer in this regard.

story:
The Festival
Sewam American Indian Dance group is honored to be the first Native American Indigenous group to be invited to present at the Cultures of the World International Dance Festival in Gannat France. The festival has over a 40-year history of presenting cultures from around the world and has been awarded a non-governmental organization partnership with UNESCO, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, for the safeguard, development and promotion of traditional cultures around the world. Other groups in the 2014 program include Pampa y Huella from Argentina, Wadaiko Group Saidi from Japan, Baku Group of Azerbaijan and the Massai from Kenya to name a few. While the festival provides housing and meals while there, we are responsible for all travel and extras in getting our people there and back home.

What an honor to be included in this program!

Though we have been invited to present in other international venues, this is our first acceptance of an offer, as we felt that this particular festival could provide a rich opportunity for cultural exchange. The 10-day program provides more than dance performance presentations; we will also be participating in educational workshop events, dance workshops with youth, lecture programs to discuss arts, regalia and traditional cultures and more. The opportunity to do more than just perform, to share more on an intimate human level, we feel is the right first steps to take onto the international stage. Festival website: http://www.cultures-traditions.org/

Sewam American Indian Dance
Eddie Madril, an award winning dancer and educator, founded Sewam American Indian Dance in 2011 to bring the music, art and culture of Native American dance to audiences everywhere.  A founding member and dancer of Four Winds American Indian Dance group, Eddie Madril is a member of the Pascua Yaqui tribe and is an active member of the Native American community as a dancer, singer, educator, playwright and filmmaker, sharing the power and beauty of Native American culture across the country for over 30 years. Sewam American Indian Dance specializes in the dances of United States Plains Indians including such dance styles as Men’s Fancy Dance, Women’s Jingle Dress dance, Men’s Northern Traditional dance, Women’s Fancy Shawl dance and the Hoop dance, among others. Sewam as a group and as individual artists, has performed across the country, inspiring audiences and sharing the power and beauty of Native American people in many settings, including theatrical presentations, community performance, and educational presentations on arts and culture.

Eddie Madril, Anecita Hernandez, Michael Bercier and Sara Moncada will be traveling to France for the festival.

What We Need

The Gannat Festival is providing full housing accommodations to our group, plus 2 meals a day. All other travel and food expenses are out of pocket. We are fundraising for airfare and other travel expenses for the 12-day adventure, including a “salary” for each artist who will be taking time off from day jobs in order to attend.

Expenses Estimate
Round Trip Airfare – San Francisco / Paris France
Researched Estimate $1,700 per person -- $1,700 x 4 = $6,800

Additional Travel – Train/Taxi/Shuttle
Researched Estimate $100 per person -- $100 x 4 = $400

Out of Pocket Food -
Estimate - $20 per person, per day at 10 days (not including travel days) -- $20 x 4 = $80 x 10 = $800

Lost Wages – we all hold full time jobs that we will be taking a leave of absence from. Our desire is to provide some small “salary” to support each dancer and our families in even a small way.
Goal - $300 per person -- $300 x 4 = $1,600

Total Project Support Needed - $9,600


What Your Help Means
Is more than we know how to describe. Dancers and artists have always struggled financially, to share their art. In this day an age, with artist grants and funds being less and less accessible, it is even harder. Please consider a donation or fiscal support for any artists that catch your eye, your help makes it possible for us all to keep dancing.

dance workshops with youth, lecture programs to discuss arts, regalia and
traditional cultures and more. The opportunity to do more than just perform, to
share more on an intimate human level, we feel is the right first steps to take
onto the international stage. Festival website: http://www.cultures-traditions.org/
Sewam American Indian DanceEddie
Madril, an award winning dancer and educator, founded Sewam American Indian
Dance in 2011 to bring the music, art and culture of Native American dance to
audiences everywhere.  A founding member and dancer of Four Winds American
Indian Dance group, Eddie Madril is a
member of the Pascua Yaqui tribe and is an active member of the Native American
community as a dancer, singer, educator, playwright and filmmaker, sharing the
power and beauty of Native American culture across the country for over 30
years. Sewam American Indian Dance specializes in
the dances of United States Plains Indians including such dance styles as Men’s
Fancy Dance, Women’s Jingle Dress dance, Men’s Northern Traditional dance,
Women’s Fancy Shawl dance and the Hoop dance, among others. Sewam as a group
and as individual artists, has performed across the country, inspiring
audiences and sharing the power and beauty of Native American people in many
settings, including theatrical presentations, community performance, and
educational presentations on arts and culture. 
Eddie Madril, Anecita Hernandez, Michael Bercier
and Sara Moncada will be traveling to France for the festival. 
What We Need
The
Gannat Festival is providing full housing accommodations to our group, plus 2
meals a day. All other travel and food expenses are out of pocket. We are
fundraising for airfare and other travel expenses for the 12-day adventure,
including a “salary” for each artist who will be taking time off from day jobs
in order to attend. 

Expenses EstimateRound
Trip Airfare – San Francisco / Paris FranceResearched
Estimate $1,700 per person -- $1,700 x 4 = $6,800

Additional
Travel – Train/Taxi/ShuttleResearched
Estimate $100 per person -- $100 x 4 = $400

Out
of Pocket Food -Estimate
- $20 per person, per day at 10 days (not including travel days) -- $20 x 4 =
$80 x 10 = $800

Lost
Wages – we all hold full time jobs that we will be taking a leave of absence
from. Our desire is to provide some small “salary” to support each dancer and
our families in even a small way.Goal
- $300 per person -- $300 x 4 = $1,600

Total Project Support Needed - $9,600
What Your Help MeansIs more than we know how
to describe. Dancers and artists have always struggled financially, to share their
art. In this day an age, with artist grants and funds being less and less
accessible, it is even harder. Please consider a donation or fiscal support for
any artists that catch your eye, your help makes it possible for us all to keep
dancing.

story:
Summary

We are a multicultural group of New York theater artists. We have come together to produce the world premiere of Saviana Stanescu's USELESS, a production that will be directed by José Zayas.

Saviana Stanescu (www.saviana.com) is an award winning Romanian-American playwright. Her work has been widely produced throughout the U.S. and internationally. She has received several awards, including the New York Innovative Theatre Award for Outstanding Full-Length Script, and the John Golden Award for Excellence in Playwriting.

José Zayas has directed over 70 productions in New York, regionally and internationally. He is the Resident Director at Repertiorio Español, and has won numerous awards, including the Ovation Award for Best Direction and several HOLAs.

The rest of our team is:

Cast: Ana Grosse*, Andy Phelan*, Steven Rishard*
Set Design: Susan Zeeman Rogers
Lighting Design: Ryan O'Gara  
Sound Design: David Margolin Lawson
Costume Design: Lisa Renee Jordan                                                                                     Stage Manager: Tierney Nolen                                                                                              Technical Direction: Markus Paminger
Graphic Design: Luciano Crossa
Video Production and Editing: Audrey Ross
Video Soundtrack: Claudio Morsella
Producers: Lucy Di Rosa and Ana Grosse
(*Appears Courtesy of Actors’ Equity Association)

USELESS is a story about love, dreams and human trafficking. Using dark humor, it spins an unusual yarn about the American dream. The play investigates the relationship between a couple of Eastern European immigrants involved in kidney trafficking (Kora, who was formerly sex-trafficked and later saved by her now husband Chris), and Omy, a mentally-challenged young man from a poor country brought to the U.S. for his kidney. Omy affects Kora and Chris in a profound way, triggering unexpected outbursts and changes. He becomes a sort of mirror for their unfulfilled dreams, hidden fears and desires, and ultimately makes them connect on a deeper level. The play intersperses heightened realistic scenes with dreams, nightmares, and daydreams that offer a glimpse into the characters' inner lives and alternate realities.

USELESS will have ten performances at IRT Theater from August 14-24, 2014.

Tickets to the show are available on Brown Paper Tickets.

What We Need and What You Get

Our goal is to raise $5,000. These funds will allow us to pay our creative team and to fund the creation of the physical production (set and props, costumes, theater expenses). We have already secured the performance and rehearsal spaces and a portion of the fees for the artists. We are committed to giving our artists the funding and resources to be as creative as they wish, and are channeling our efforts to allow them to express themselves as fully as they can, so that they may breathe life and energy into Saviana's text in a way that does the play justice.

We are working with a small budget and everyone is dedicated to making this production the best that it can be. We believe very deeply that everything we are putting into this production will allow the play to have a continued life on stage, so that everything that is being put into the play now is an investment in the future of this thought-provoking piece.

Our perks are geared towards allowing our funders to experience USELESS, to be involved in the production and to join us in celebrating the fruits of this labor.

Please note that all donations are tax deductible in the United States.

The Impact

Like the characters in our play, many of us are immigrants. As a collective, we have origins in Romania, Puerto Rico, Argentina, Italy, Belgium, Brazil, Uruguay, Mexico, Canada and the United States. We are moved and delighted and challenged by USELESS, and we would like our community to have the opportunity to experience it as well.

At the core of the play is a dark story of characters who have been coerced or duped into selling pieces of themselves, or into selling others, in order to lift themselves out of their grim realities and to fulfill their dreams.

While the events in the play are fictional, they are taken from experiences that are all too real: according to the UN Office on Drugs and Crime, human trafficking is the third most profitable illicit trade, after that of arms and drugs. It generates about $217 billion US in revenue annually, and is linked to other organized crime - human smuggling, drug trafficking, and money laundering. Astoundingly, victims come from 127 countries and are transported to and used in 135 of the world's 196 countries ("International Laws to Combat Human Trafficking," 2004).

While we are telling a story of struggles that many of us face every day, i.e., meeting financial commitments, fulling dreams, we are doing it through the lens of characters who make specific choices and are trapped into situations that few of us can imagine. It is important to us that the characters in the play are not portrayed as villains or heroes. Saviana explores the human experience in its rich complexity, seeing the light in the dark sides of the mind, and the darkness in the moments of beauty. Ultimately, she is conveying the message that making a loving human connection may be the only way to fight violence and evil acts, and to prove that humanity is USEFUL.
 

Risks and Challenges

Our investment in USELESS is substantial. Many of us have been working on the play for three years, including multiple readings and workshops at the Lark Play Development Center, Ensemble Studio Theatre and Queens Theatre. We are investing so much of ourselves in this work because we are passionately committed to it and would like to accomplish something noteworthy with it.

Because we don't have angel investors and are raising all of the funds for this production ourselves in a limited time span, we are in a challenging but exciting position to lock arms with our community in order to make USELESS come to life. Now we are relying on you to help us reach our financial goal. We cannot fulfill our vision and meet this goal without you. We are deeply grateful for your support!


    Other Ways You Can Help

    We understand that not everyone who reads this is in a position to contribute financially to the campaign. If you feel that you cannot contribute at this time, we invite you to:
    • Like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter (@UselessThePlay). Like and share our posts, retweet our tweets. Doing all of these things makes a huge difference in the number of people who will discover us online.
    • Share this campaign with your friends over social media or by email.
    • Make a date with your friends to see the show!

Other Ways You Can HelpWe understand that not everyone who reads this is in a position to contribute financially to the campaign. If you feel that you cannot contribute at this time, we invite you to:

story:
Help Tight Theatre take their first piece on a summer tour of festivals including the Edinburgh Fringe. Pussy explores what it means to be a woman in today's society, combining popular culture, physical theatre and humour. It is a wholly original piece, devised and performed by five Bristol drama students. 


"With 'Pussy' Tight Theatre have created something that feels almost tangible. It is a fun and accessible piece that is also blurring the lines between dance and theatre in a really exciting way. I'm really looking forward to seeing more of the show and indeed the company - I think Tight Theatre are going to be creating some bold and daring work in the future."

Matthew Dwyer, Pleasance Theatre programmer 


"I really enjoyed the energy and power of the performers - it felt like a totally committed effort which carried my belief in the work from start to finish. I really enjoyed what I read as - dynamic use of colour, huge variety of sound and image, and an exciting ambiguity. What made the piece really zing for me was a sense that the subject matter never strayed from direct experience - but never felt self-indulgent... Which feels like a dead-hard balance to find - so bravo!!"

Impermanence Dance Theatre


Summer tour: 

1st-2nd June - Scratch night, White Theatre, Bristol. 

10th June - Edinburgh preview, Pleasance Theatre, London. 

3-6th July: Avant Garden Festival, Brentwood, Essex. 

10th-13th July: Brainchild Festival, Bentley Country House, East Sussex.

4th-19th August: Edinburgh Fringe, Laughing Horse - Counting House Ballroom. 


All proceeds will go towards making the show fantastically full of feminist fun! Any questions please email tightheatre@outlook.com 


Pussy. Five girls - one stage. It's not about cats.

story:
'The Furies' by Aeschylus

This summer, Ethrael Theatre is bringing an anarchic, electric adaptation of Aeschylus' classic. Following on from their successes with the original, promenade, musical adaptation of Hugo's 'The Hunchback of Notre Dame' in Durham Cathedral, and critically acclaimed production of Martin Sherman's 'Bent', Ethrael Theatre will be performing 'The Furies' in C Nova in Edinburgh from the 16th to the 31st August.

The Play

Orestes, has just slain his mother, Clytaemnestra, for the murder of his father, Agamemnon. When the Furies want Orestes’s blood to pay for the crime of murdering his mother, the gods have other plans. This original, musical adaptation of the tragedy follows Orestes as he attempts to flee the vengeance of the formidable Furies, encountering gods such as Athena and Apollo along the way.

The Furies combines haunting, original music with beautiful dance in this unique adaptation. This daring and ambitious work combines imaginative lighting, a strong ensemble, and a well-balanced fusion of music and speech to create a visually and aurally striking performance. Originally performed in Durham Castle’s Norman Chapel, the production is now transforming C nova into an engaging, fascinating, and innovative space in which the Furies are brought to life.

Praise for 'The Furies', Durham, 2013

‘Rivals the best of the classical plays performed’

**** DurhamTheatreReview.com

‘An intense theatrical experience which swept me up and absorbed me in the plot’ Bubble

Praise for Ethrael Theatre

‘The most visually stunning student production I have ever seen, or am ever likely to see’ Bubble

‘Among the most memorable performances I have seen’ Palatinate

‘A cohesive performance that would not have looked out of place in London’s West End’ First Night 

The Company

Ethrael Theatre is experimental and ambitious, consistently challenging the norms of fringe theatre and now seeking to do the same on a national scale. Ethrael Theatre is led by its Artistic Director and Founder Leo Mylonadis and by its Executive Producers, Matilda Hunter and Lauren Hitchman. More information about Ethrael's history and its previous shows can be found on its website: http://www.ethraeltheatre.co.uk/

Funding

'The Furies' is kindly sponsored by the Phillip Foster Company and the Buntingford Kitchen. Other than our sponsors' support, the Edinburgh Fringe will be an entirely self-funded venture. Our main expenses consist of:

  • Venue Hire
  • Equipment Hire
  • Costume, Prop and Scenery Hire and Construction
Your Support
Your support will mean that we can perform at the festival confident in our financial stability. In order to produce the highest quality performance, we need to be able to invest in the highest quality costumes and technical equipment and your help can be the deciding factor in us doing so! Ethrael Theatre has a strong track record with producing high-quality, innovative theatre, and we aim to proudly display such a tradition at the Fringe Festival.

This festival is many of the cast and crew's debut Edinburgh Fringe performance. Many members of the troupe are only just launching into the professional theatrical world, and the chance to perform at the world's largest theatre festival is truly invaluable.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please follow us, like us, and share us on the following platforms:

Book Tickets to see 'The Furies' at the Fringe!

Ethrael Theatre Twitter

Ethrael Theatre Facebook

'The Furies' Facebook Event

story:
The Original “Alternative Facts”

“If you want to tell people the truth, make them laugh, otherwise they'll kill you.”
-Oscar Wilde

Our show begins in a church basement, where disgraced spies, along with the unwitting audience, gather for a support group meeting. The action soon shifts to Frankfurt Airport, where a mysterious Iraqi defector claims he built secret Iraqi bio-weapons labs. At CIA headquarters, our other characters are contending with their own ambitions, rash decisions, inflexible bosses, unrequited affections and unremitting boredom, when a fax arrives from Germany, and with it a golden opportunity. If the defector's story holds up, it will be the ticket out of the basement and into a corner office. It's all fun and games until the looming cataclysm changes everything.

How You Can Help

It takes a village to put on a show, especially an Off-Broadway musical. By sending a donation, large or small, you are helping buy costumes, build the set, maintain props, advertise the show and many many other expenses that are necessary to have a successful theatrical run. But most importantly, you are helping us share this relevant story. Baghdaddy is the first of a wave of political art that is going to break big across the media landscape.

To recognize your contributions, we have prepared many different perks! Everything from musical demo tracks to opening night tickets (along with a VIP invitation to the cast party) are available to show our gratitude for your donation.

Please note that we will reach out to schedule the tickets to a performance of your choice as we get closer to opening.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Regardless of your ability to contribute, this is a story that needs to be heard today. If you know anyone who loves John Oliver, Stephen Colbert, or even political memes, they will love this show. 

http://baghdaddymusical.com/

You can like us on Facebook:

https://www.facebook.com/yourbaghdaddy/

Or follow us on Twitter:

https://twitter.com/YourBaghdaddy

If you would prefer to make a tax deductible donation to support the show, send a check to:

The New Musical Foundation
455 W 37th St. #2004 
New York, NY 10018

Thank you for helping us bring this important and relevant story back to the stage. Art is resistance, and this is a substantial work of art, leveraging the talents of dozens of artists who can't do their work without you.

The Making of a Musical

The creation of Baghdaddy began in 2006, when producer Charlie Fink read his old friend J.T. Allen's unproduced screenplay, "Curveball". Charlie concluded the only way people could accept this incredible true story if it were a musical comedy. As Oscar Wilde famously said, "if you want to tell people the truth make them laugh, otherwise they'll kill you". In 2010 Marshall Pailet (Claudio Quest, Triassic Parq) & A.D. Penedo (The Three Times She Knocked) wrote a successful one act version of Baghdaddy (then called Who's Your Baghdaddy? or How I Started the Iraq War) that won "Best Show" at the DC Fringe Festival. But for years afterward, the show stubbornly resisted several attempts to re-write it as a full length Broadway style musical. Then the authors had an idea that transformed the show: tell the story inside a support group that has been formed by the disgraced spies who passed along the false intel that was used to justify the invasion of Iraq. The characters now tell their story inside of the group, inventively conjuring each scene in the spare church basement to search for redemption. 

In September, 2015, The New Musical Foundation presented a limited 10 week engagement of Baghdaddy at the off-Broadway Actor's Temple. Critics and audiences loved the show. The creative team vowed to bring it back. Little did we know today's environment would make the original alternative facts so relevant again.

More of our rave reviews:

Hamilton may have the hype, but it's not the only show in town to leave you in astonishment... Baghdaddy has bad-ass style with a bad-ass cast that pulls off one of the most bad-ass musicals I've seen in a very long time. - Manhattan Digest

A whip smart musical comedy that’s sure to leave you laughing and thinking for days. Pailet and Penedo make this work is nothing short of brilliant, they harness musical comedy in an intelligent, creative, and witty way that makes this shocking, true story, palatable. This is not only impressive, it is deeply important. - Theater is Easy

Leaves the audience laughing, but – like all good satire – thinking as well. - Voice of America

This high-energy production is graced with a multi-talented, sophisticated humor and hilarious and audacious storytelling. Penedo and Pailet use comedy to remind us of a tragedy, and they do it brilliantly. Go see Baghdaddy. It is totally unique. - Electronic Link Journey

This is an ensemble effort and all eight members of the cast are excellent. There are laughs aplenty, but the humor is black. How could it be otherwise? - Theater Pizazz

A great musical that is interesting, informative, and above all, fun. The songs are great, the acting phenomenal, and the jokes, most importantly, landed without any trouble. - The Knockturnal

Expertly crafted with strong storytelling and characters each with a sense of redemption. Baghdaddy is a fascinating story with a strong ensemble that is accessible and engaging. Baghdaddy is a musical comedy, yes comedy, that brings new light to America's darkest times. - Theater in the Now

War, apparently, is a laughing matter. Baghdaddy is a quirky musical that's surprisingly entertaining. The songs makes you laugh as well as think. You'll leave the theater smiling, and perhaps a bit angry, but you don't have to be a Democrat to love this show. - Asbury Park Press

If you wanna understand the final takeover of make believe over reality, you need to go see Baghdaddy. It provides a reminder of what happens when your government wants to imbibe fantasy and fanaticism over empiricism and reason-- while forcing you to laugh your arse off. - Crooks and Liars

Other Ways You Can Help
Spread the word! Regardless of your ability to contribute, this is a story that needs to be heard today. If you know anyone who loves John Oliver, Stephen Colbert, or even political memes, they will love this show. 
http://baghdaddymusical.com/
You can like us on Facebook:
https://www.facebook.com/yourbaghdaddy/
Or follow us on Twitter:
https://twitter.com/YourBaghdaddy
If you would prefer to make a tax deductible donation to support the show, send a check to:The New Musical Foundation455 W 37th St. #2004 New York, NY 10018Thank you for helping us bring this important and relevant story back to the stage. Art is resistance, and this is a substantial work of art, leveraging the talents of dozens of artists who can't do their work without you.

The Making of a Musical
The creation of Baghdaddy began in 2006, when producer Charlie Fink read his old friend J.T. Allen's unproduced screenplay, "Curveball". Charlie concluded the only way people could accept this incredible true story if it were a musical comedy. As Oscar Wilde famously said, "if you want to tell people the truth make them laugh, otherwise they'll kill you". In 2010 Marshall Pailet (Claudio Quest, Triassic Parq) & A.D. Penedo (The Three Times She Knocked) wrote a successful one act version of Baghdaddy (then called Who's Your Baghdaddy? or How I Started the Iraq War) that won "Best Show" at the DC Fringe Festival. But for years afterward, the show stubbornly resisted several attempts to re-write it as a full length Broadway style musical. Then the authors had an idea that transformed the show: tell the story inside a support group that has been formed by the disgraced spies who passed along the false intel that was used to justify the invasion of Iraq. The characters now tell their story inside of the group, inventively conjuring each scene in the spare church basement to search for redemption. 
In September, 2015, The New Musical Foundation presented a limited 10 week engagement of Baghdaddy at the off-Broadway Actor's Temple. Critics and audiences loved the show. The creative team vowed to bring it back. Little did we know today's environment would make the original alternative facts so relevant again.
More of our rave reviews:
Hamilton may have the hype, but it's not the only show in town to leave you in astonishment... Baghdaddy has bad-ass style with a bad-ass cast that pulls off one of the most bad-ass musicals I've seen in a very long time. - Manhattan Digest
A whip smart musical comedy that’s sure to leave you laughing and thinking for days. Pailet and Penedo make this work is nothing short of brilliant, they harness musical comedy in an intelligent, creative, and witty way that makes this shocking, true story, palatable. This is not only impressive, it is deeply important. - Theater is Easy
Leaves the audience laughing, but – like all good satire – thinking as well. - Voice of America
This high-energy production is graced with a multi-talented, sophisticated humor and hilarious and audacious storytelling. Penedo and Pailet use comedy to remind us of a tragedy, and they do it brilliantly. Go see Baghdaddy. It is totally unique. - Electronic Link Journey
This is an ensemble effort and all eight members of the cast are excellent. There are laughs aplenty, but the humor is black. How could it be otherwise? - Theater Pizazz
A great musical that is interesting, informative, and above all, fun. The songs are great, the acting phenomenal, and the jokes, most importantly, landed without any trouble. - The Knockturnal
Expertly crafted with strong storytelling and characters each with a sense of redemption. Baghdaddy is a fascinating story with a strong ensemble that is accessible and engaging. Baghdaddy is a musical comedy, yes comedy, that brings new light to America's darkest times. - Theater in the Now
War, apparently, is a laughing matter. Baghdaddy is a quirky musical that's surprisingly entertaining. The songs makes you laugh as well as think. You'll leave the theater smiling, and perhaps a bit angry, but you don't have to be a Democrat to love this show. - Asbury Park Press
If you wanna understand the final takeover of make believe over reality, you need to go see Baghdaddy. It provides a reminder of what happens when your government wants to imbibe fantasy and fanaticism over empiricism and reason-- while forcing you to laugh your arse off. - Crooks and Liars

story:
La pièce:  ¨Là¨  de Serge Boucher 

L’histoire se déroule au casse-croûte Chez Denis, qui compte bon nombre d’habitués, à différentes époques. La trajectoire de vie des personnages évolue au même rythme que celle du Québec, avec les faits d’actualité se rattachant à chacune des décennies visitées par le texte.

Si seulement les murs pouvaient parler, qu’auraient-ils à nous raconter? Un regard drôle et touchant sur la vie avec des personnages attachants.

Qui sommes-nous :

Nous sommes un groupe de comédiens qui suivent ensemble une formation à l’École d’Acte 1 Productions. Cet OBNL participe grandement au développement professionnel et à l'épanouissement de nombreux acteurs de tous les âges.

Nous travaillons actuellement à la production du spectacle "Là" qui sera présenté au Théâtre Prospero à la fin de notre session de cours, soit en mai 2017.

Ce dont nous avons besoin :

Votre contribution nous aidera grandement à concrétiser la réalisation de notre projet. En effet, nous avons besoin de financement afin de défrayer les coûts de réalisation des décors et des différents accessoires nécessaires pour notre spectacle.

Avec votre soutien, nous pourrons ainsi réaliser un projet unique. Nous souhaitons offrir au public un spectacle de qualité et lui faire découvrir l’univers coloré de ces personnages et de ce très beau texte.

Notre équipe :

Metteur en scène : Hugo Turgeon

Directeur de production: Philippe Boutin

Coordonnatrice de production: Catherine Rochefort

Scénographe : Patrick Barnwell

Costumes: Christine Filteau

Comédiens : Sara Barbusci, Josée Beaulieu, François Beaupré, Christine Delage, Chanel Grondin, Frédéric Khawam, Sophie Lauzière, Stanley Hilaire et Jean Jr Ouellette.

Représentation : Au Théâtre Prospero, le 27 mai 2017.

story:
The Story

An inmate in extreme isolation experiences moments of introspection and reasoning, and the self doubt of a man incarcerated for life. Through blame, regret, and ultimately forgiveness he reclaims his identity and learns, though too late, the error of living a life blind to the privilege of family and love. 

Originally titled ‘Trapped’, this concept was born in 2007 in Cape Town, South Africa. Having noticed how many of my friends regret various things from their past, I wanted to address this in a script written specifically for the stage. Some worked to much, some had lost relationships due to lack of presence by always being on there phones or computers, and some lost parents to illness whom they wish they had spent more time with.

I did extensive research on which members of the public may have the most regret, but was unsatisfied with my findings. It didn’t quite resonate with me to the extent that I had anticipated.

Last year I stumbled upon several letters written by inmates that touched me in such a profound way. These men expressed regret in the most touching way and with this in mind I was adamant on finishing this project.

5863 explores one man’s loss of freedom, and through regret, blame, the heavy burden of guilt, and ultimately forgiveness, we get to explore where in our lives we may have the opportunity to make some changes.


Finding the right producer and director

I was approached by French intuitive, actress and director Dominique Sire about another project she wanted to collaborate on, and after a brief discussion about 5863 she was on board. Being hugely gifted at script structure and performance direction, Dominique came on board as co-director.

                                            

Finding the right director and producer was essential, and gold was struck when I was introduced to Angela Grillo. Being a theatre veteran, and member of The Eclectic Company Theatre, our collaboration started straight away and hasn’t lost momentum.  


Risks and challenges How do you create a piece that is universal yet still authentic to my voice and concept?

It’s always risky to portray a lesson of such magnitude in a way that will attract an audience of all ages and walks of life. The choice to use a federal prison as the setting for this piece was important to me to maximize the concept of entrapment, sending the audience back into their lives willing to examine and recognize where changes could be made.

It was difficult to include so many emotions and a lifetime of blindness into one hour, yet still end on a hopeful, positive note. This character reclaims his identity and forgives himself for mistakes made, which will profoundly resonates with it’s viewers.

We wanted to tell this story in the most visceral way by adding elements of multimedia to give real life to the character’s dreams and memories as he transcends imprisonment.


The Theatre & Design Team  

                                            


Not only is The Eclectic Company Theatre a non-profit theatre company and under 99-seat in Los Angeles, it is the perfect space for intimate work like 5863. The company and members also coincide with Angela’s visionary style of directing. The Eclectic Company Theatre’s mission is “to create a diverse collaborative community, to promote artistic freedom, to present original and established works, and to provide support for new and seasoned theatre producers. ECT is a collaborative collective of actors, writers, directors, producers, and technicians whose vision is to nurture individual artistic expression and to present innovative, socially relevant work to the Los Angeles theatre community.”

                     

Many of our team members are also members of ECT! Adrienne Pearson is our Associate Producer. Adrienne has worked on multiple projects with Angela, including their last show PRAYER: A Song Cycle. MZ, our Stage Manager and Ryan Siebrasse, Set Designer/Technical Director, both who have just wrapped up Spoon River: An Anthology, ECT’s previous play. Phil Sokoloff, ECT’s Publicist and Rochelle Perry will be our Photographer. There is a lot that goes on behind the scenes in order to get a show off the ground; other ECT members help with set building, house managing, selling tickets, promoting, Jon Mullich keeps our website looking great. But we wouldn’t be able to create original work and produce the variety of shows we do if it wasn’t for our entire Management Team who helps to keep a theatre like ours alive! Thank you to our new President, Natasha Troop for leading the way!

Other creators we have paired up with outside the theatre include Liza Esposito, playing the GIRL, Melanie Gray as Sarah, graphic designers Jacob Semans and Harpal Sodhi, Sound Designer Susan Joseph, Christina Schock is consulting on make-up. Edward Kiniry-Ostro, has created an original violin piece for 5863 and Kouichi Okamoto / Kyouei Design, who is a Sound producer/product designer from Japan. Angela found his unique work while sourcing pendulum sounds.


Creating and putting up a play, a piece of art - takes a lot of hands and imagination. We are grateful and overjoyed to be collaborating on 5863 with such an eclectic group of artists. Now we get to share it with all of you and you get to be a part of it as well. By helping fund 5863, you become a Producer! And you will help with the most challenging aspect of producing a play - raising the money.


Why is theatre important and why is this play important?

Live theatre challenges. Live theatre raises heartbeats and raises questions. Live theatre promotes change. Live theatre entertains. 5863 gives you an opportunity to ask yourself what you truly care about. We have the choice of how we would like to live our lives, even in prison. And you have a choice to support live theatre! To experience 5863 and to see theatre! To be a part of expression and freedom.

Through our research on the stories of rape and abuse throughout the prison systems in America, we felt it was important to raise questions in 5863 regarding basic human rights.  We will be giving back a percentage of our ticket sales to Prison Activist, which supports prisoners by giving resources to all inmates no matter what.

Funding will also go towards our design team – these are only paying jobs if we raise the money to pay them. A set which can be used again as we look ahead to future theatre festivals. The 5863 image, which has been printed into posters and postcards for promotional material in order to sell tickets. All the other little things add up too: props, costumes, make-up (it ain’t cheap making our handsome actor look like a prisoner), videography. Did we mention this is a multi-media piece? Because it is! And that adds to the bill- filming/editing, recording voice-over. It’s not as expensive as shooting a movie, but the little things add up.

If you can’t donate, you can help spread the word by sharing on FB, coming to the show, telling friends, or forward that email!

We look forward to sharing this experience with you. Thank you for your energy and generous donations.


5863 opens April 24 at the Eclectic Company Theatre in Los Angeles, CA. 

                         

                              

                               5312 Laurel Canyon Blvd., Valley Village, CA 91607

                                                               (818) 508-3003

story:
About These Troubled Times

"..."Humorous true-to-life writing and excellent performances..." - Darryl Reilly, theaterscene.net

Monarch Theater NYC produced These Troubled Times in summer of 2014 with Ryan Repertory Theater Company in NYC's own Coney Island, and now we're taking the show on the road to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival - and you can help!  Our audiences loved:

  • Our comedic and irreverent exploration of homophobia, religion, and the meaning of family.
  • OUR ALIENS!
  • Playwright and actor Troy Diana dressed in drag as the bible-beating and God-fearing Mrs. Raymond.

Yup, you read correctly:  gay people, aliens, and a God-fearing old lady being played by a man.

Help us get to Edinburgh!

Before heading to Edinburgh, we'll also be performing the show at the East to Edinburgh Festival at 59E59, giving all of our New York friends, family, and fans a chance to see the show.  Get your tickets here!

Our fundraising goal is $5,000, and we cannot reach it without you. 

Your generous donations will help us pay for travel to Edinburgh, accommodations, rehearsal space, rental of the theater, pay for the actors and staff, marketing and PR.  Every dollar donated will move our project forward, and we can't wait to share it with you! 

Why is this play important?

From playwright Troy Diana:

I wrote These Troubled Times in a playful manner.  It is meant to be fun, but with that said, I believe it comments on an important factor in our everyday lives:  fear.  And even more specifically, the fear of the unknown.  We can see it in Mrs. Raymond's treatment of Charles, probably the first openly gay person she's met.  We can see it through all the characters in their speculation of what it actually is that has invaded their small town of Clearwater, FL.  And lastly, we can witness it through Charles' speculation of how best to protect his niece and nephew.  If this play can make audiences laugh and leave with a better understanding about acceptance, I have done my job.  I am so excited to share this piece with an international audience!

Can't donate?  Help us anyway!

Can't make a monetary donation?  No sweat!  Sharing our campaign link via Facebook or email would be AMAZING.  Help us get the word out!

story:
Our Story

Throughout our careers at Wesleyan University, we have been lucky enough to work on excellent theatrical productions in various roles, including performing, stage managing, production assisting, costuming, directing, and choreographing. As we come to the end  of our time at Wesleyan, we want to employ all of our accumulated theater experience, and also stretch our boundaries just a little bit, by producing a show from the ground up. Our vision is to create an entirely student run, independently produced, full-length outdoor production of A Midsummer Night's Dream. Our goal is to create a traditional-style Shakespearean show, that maintains the integrity of the text as written, while simultaneously striving to create an atmosphere which is social, joyful, and highly entertaining, making the play more accessible to a contemporary audience without distracting from the importance of the language itself. Our hope is that by independently producing Midsummer, we will learn what it really takes to put on a show from the bottom up. We are also excited to create an artistic piece that is exclusively ours, with no limits or regulations on our creative processes. We know that this will be challenging, and we embrace it. In anticipating the challenges that will surely arise as we make the transition from college life to the real world (especially pursuing careers in theater), we hope that this smaller-scale endeavor will be a valuable learning experience.
Our production is scheduled for Friday April 24th, Saturday April 25th, and Sunday April 26th at 6PM in the Russell House Garden at Wesleyan University in Middletown, Connecticut. It will be free and open to the public, and we will encourage audiences to bring lawn chairs and picnic dinners!

What We Need

In deciding to independently produce this show, we have committed to being as resourceful as possible in terms of finding and creating costumes, set pieces, and props. As much as we can, we hope to utilize recycled and borrowed items instead of buying new ones. In addition to significantly minimizing our budget, this will grant us even more room for creativity. Though we plan to be as strategic as possible in terms of accumulating the pieces that we need, having a secure financial base will be criticial. After careful research, we have created a budget that encompasses every element of our show- from  actor's scripts to lion suits. It is outlined below:

What We Need & What You Get

Printing: Flyers and scripts ($36). Colored Posters ($62.50)
Costumes: 15 actors, each playing multiple roles ($1,000)

Lighting: note: since the performances will be outside, we will need to purchase our own lighting equipement that is specifically designed to illuminate outdoor spaces. White Lights ($100), Colored lights ($66), Lanterns ($140), Light bulbs, ($42)

Props: Accounted props include twine, flowers, a very specific broom, fairy accessories, a wooden sword, wigs, donkey head, and a lion suit ($533)

Total: $2,513

*Any extra funding will be used to enhance our costumes and lighting, and to create a high-quality video of the production. 

Risks & Challenges

Since early September, we have been working to establish the foundations for our production. We have already fully booked rehearsal space and our performance location (as well as a bad weather alternative). We have assembled a full team-- including a costume designer, lighting designer, and assistant directors and stage managers. At this point, our main risk is not raising enough money to purchase necessary items-- especially lights, scripts and posters, and costumes. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We totally understand if you are unable to contribute financially. If you are still interested in supporting our project, there are other ways! Here's how: 

  • Spread the word about our campaign! Post it on social media and tell your friends. The more awareness, the better!
  • If you think you might have any lighting, costume, or prop pieces that we might be able to borrow, we will be forever grateful! For a full props, costume, and lights list, please email arudess@wesleyan.edu

It will be free and open to the public, and we will encourage audiences to bring lawn chairs and picnic dinners!  What We Need In deciding to independently produce this show, we have committed to being as resourceful as possible in terms of finding and creating costumes, set pieces, and props. As much as we can, we hope to utilize recycled and borrowed items instead of buying new ones. In addition to significantly minimizing our budget, this will grant us even more room for creativity. Though we plan to be as strategic as possible in terms of accumulating the pieces that we need, having a secure financial base will be criticial. After careful research, we have created a budget that encompasses every element of our show- from  actor's scripts to lion suits. It is outlined below:

What We Need & What You Get
Printing: Flyers and scripts ($36). Colored Posters ($62.50)
Costumes: 15 actors, each playing multiple roles ($1,000)

Lighting: note: since the performances will be outside, we will need to purchase our own lighting equipement that is specifically designed to illuminate outdoor spaces. White Lights ($100), Colored lights ($66), Lanterns ($140), Light bulbs, ($42)
Props: Accounted props include twine, flowers, a very specific broom, fairy accessories, a wooden sword, wigs, donkey head, and a lion suit ($533)
Total: $2,513
*Any extra funding will be used to enhance our costumes and lighting, and to create a high-quality video of the production. 

    Risks & Challenges Since early September, we have been working to establish the foundations for our production. We have already fully booked rehearsal space and our performance location (as well as a bad weather alternative). We have assembled a full team-- including a costume designer, lighting designer, and assistant directors and stage managers. At this point, our main risk is not raising enough money to purchase necessary items-- especially lights, scripts and posters, and costumes. 
    Other Ways You Can Help We totally understand if you are unable to contribute financially. If you are still interested in supporting our project, there are other ways! Here's how:   Spread the word about our campaign! Post it on social media and tell your friends. The more awareness, the better! If you think you might have any lighting, costume, or prop pieces that we might be able to borrow, we will be forever grateful! For a full props, costume, and lights list, please email arudess@wesleyan.edu

story:
WHO WE ARE

Water People Theater raises the curtain in Chicago with the premiere of “MUSAS” written by Néstor Caballero, a fictional encounter between Mexican Painter FRIDA KAHLO and American Poet SYLVIA PLATH. 

Water People Theater is an Organization devoted to introducing plays to the American and Hispanic Community audiences as well as inspire exchange of ideas in the multi-ethnic community. We focus on fostering creativity and art excellence, providing programs and activities that encourage public awareness, participation, and appreciation of Fine Arts through high quality Bilingual (Spanish-English) Theater Plays.

Our work has been recognized twice by the Association of Critics of Entertainment-ACE Award in New York. 

MUSAS will take place from August 13th through August 24th at The Green House Theater in Lincoln Park, Chicago.


MUSAS 

The work proposes a fictional crossroad between two artistic personalities, Mexican painter Frida Kahlo (1907-1954) and the American-born writer Sylvia Plath (1932-1963). The play is an encounter that never happened in reality. The audience confronts the intense experiences of these women in the same space. They will find biographical details and references of their lives, but above all, their relationship with art, love, and death. The play will reveal pieces of their paths marked by a fatal destiny.

Frida's life was defined by pain and love. While recovering in bed from a terrible automobile accident  suffered at an early age, she discovers painting and earns a prominent place in Mexican Art.  Powerful  love and belief in the revolution connects her with Diego Rivera, world famous muralist whom became her husband. Marked by a stormy relationship and intense emotional and physical pain that never fades away, Frida dies at age 47.

Sylvia published her first poem at age eight. Under a beautiful and seemingly perfect life reflected in her verses, underlies darkness and struggle with feelings of self-destruction that haunted her. She married the English poet Ted Hughes, an intense and tumultuous marriage that crumbled despite having two children together.  Sylvia had always struggled with finding her own identity and oscillated between moments of intense joy with moments of deep darkness.  At age 30, she commits suicide.

An extraordinary encounter of two icons of Contemporary Art, in which they share the most intimate and passionate moments of their lives. 


WHAT WILL WE DO WITH YOUR CONTRIBUTION?



WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

For this campaign, we are raising $6,500 out of a $13,000 budget
- Your contribution will help us pay for performance and rehearsal space, actors and director salaries, promotion and publicity, creative fees, Artistic and Technical teams salaries,  and all the other costs a high quality production requires.
- For your contribution you will be a member of our community of supporters and receive multiple benefits depending on your level of support

We are excited to invite you to enjoy this journey as much as we do, and can only be possible through the support of a sensitive audience and the generosity of your time.


THE IMPACT

Differently to many cross-cultural plays, our aim is not to teach the audience about Mexican and American culture, but rather cultivate their soul by immersing them in a common place created by these two extraordinary women. The audience experience is based on the genuine relationship between two unique artists from radically different cultures 


CAST & CREW

A WATER PEOPLE THEATER  Production

MÓNICA STEUER  (PREMIO ACE NYC)  as  SYLVIA PLATH  

REBECA ALEMÁN (PREMIO ACE NYC)  as  FRIDA KAHLO

SAMUEL OCEAN  Guest Musician


Written by  NÉSTOR CABALLERO

Graphic Design  ENDER CAMACHO

Photographer  EMILIO NADALES

English Text  Curator EMMANUEL  AYALA

Strategy & Campaign Advisor  MARIA FERNANDA LARES

Lighting Design  GIULIO PEDOTA

Set Design  PEDRO MELIS

Costume Design  RAQUEL RIOS

Directed by  IRAIDA TAPIAS 


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

- "Like" us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/WaterPeopleTheater

 www.facebook.com/MusasWP

- Join us as an Associated Producer by cultivating a small group of donors for a variety of perks.

-If you are not able to support us financially but are interested in offering goods and services (legal, marketing, set, costume or prop support, etc) or are interested in advertising via our social media pages and/or print program, we'd love to hear from you.

Thank you for your support and WELCOME to MUSAS

Tickets and more Info: http://greenhousetheater.org/portfolio/musas/

CONTACT

Twitter  @musaswp @waterpeoplet  

musaswp@gmail.com

Facebook  www.facebook.com/WaterPeopleTheater

MUSAS August 13th through August 24th at The Green House Theater in Lincoln Park, Chicago.

story:
What we're doing:

In the winter 2013, Essential Theatre Group presented the premiere of Twelfth Night: a folk musical at The Tank, a non-profit home for the arts in midtown Manhattan. This production was the creation of the entire ensemble coming together and working hard for 12 brief rehearsals in a studio with no heat. A new musical by Conly Basham and Tony Lance was born.

In early 2014 we were accepted into the New York International Fringe Festival along with 204 other companies from all over. From August 8-24, over 1,000 performances will occur in lower Manhattan during one of the largest festivals for live theatre in the world.

This comes with a price tag.

What We Need & What You Get

We need you to help us pay actors and artisans involved in the production, rent studio space for rehearsals and cover the cost of promoting the show. With each donation level comes a digital download of our studio album, "What You Will," featuring music from Twelfth Night by Conly Basham. 

This music is currently only available to donors who contribute $40 or more!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Spread the word! View our videos of recording the music on YouTube and share with your friends on Facebook, Twitter and through direct emails. 

    If you are in New York City, COME SEE US AT FRINGE! We have 5 performances of the show to share with you: 

    Saturday, August 9 at NOON
    Thursday, August 14 at 3:45PM
    Sunday, August 17 at 8:45PM
    Thursday, August 21 at 7PM
    Friday, August 22 at 2PM

story:
Summary

5 Day Improvisation Master Class Workshop Intensive

Over the course of 5 – 3 hour sessions, you will work on developing:

Deep Character Development/Developing Multiple Stage Characters within actors can learn how to comfortably improvise a scene or even an entire show.

Development of deeper control of basic improvisational acting skills such as the concepts of:

“Yes-And”; “Upping The Stakes”; “Supporting Your Partner[s]”; “Using The Body To Create Dramatic Connection And Character”; “Commitment To Scene”; “Moving Past Circular Scenes-Creating Scenes With a True Dramatic Arc”; and “Using Traditional Meisner/Method/Presentational Skills To Enhance Improvisation.” 

This will culminate in a Saturday evening showcase

Dates: Tuesday, 31 January – Saturday 04 February 2017

Time: 2-5 pm     Location: Glasgow

5 Day Writing and Acting for Solo Performance Master Class Workshop Intensive

Writing For Solo Performance consists of a series of workshops exploring how Sketch, Stand-Up, Moth Style Storytelling/David Sedaris Style Essay Writing, Slam Poetry, and actual One Person Plays are created and structured. Students will be challenged to write and hone 3 to 5 brand new minutes of original material as a minimum during the week in their chosen genre.

This will culminate in a Saturday evening Showcase.

Dates: Tuesday, 31 January - 04 February 2017

Time: 10-1 pm   Location: Glasgow

60 minute 1 -1 Session with Tim Joyce

Spend an hour with Tim in a professional development session with Tim, developing your script, new acting piece, etc.

Date: Monday, 30 January 2017

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out to others you think may be interested!

About Tim

Tim Joyce has worked as a contributing Writer/Performer with Chicago’s famed Second City as well as currently co-starring in the multiple festival award winning film “Love Meet Hope” with Ed Asner. This film is slated for general release in winter of 2017. While at Second City he wrote for and performed with Tina Fey, Steve Carrell, Steven Colbert, Ruth Rudnick, and Amy Sedaris for three seasons. Tim is the author of four books and five professionally produced plays, including the Jeff Award Nominated “Diner Tales” at Raven Theatre in Chicago in 2006. As a stand-up comic he toured for over twenty years and appeared on television many times including ABC, Fox Television, Comedy Central, WeTV, and Canada’s CTV. As a stage actor he has appeared in over 100 professional shows including 28 productions of Shakespeare plays. His full acting and writing resume is available, as well as his commercial acting resume.

 

His experience as a teacher includes five years as a professor at Buffalo State College, where he taught Intro to Theatre and Solo Performance (An intensive Writing and Performing Class for aspiring playwrights, poets, comics, cabaret artists, and spoken word storytellers). Tim, while a professor at Canisius College, taught Humor In Literature for their English Department. For ten years he was the Stand-Up Comedy Writing and Editing Teacher at the Improv in Chicago and currently is entering his sixth year in the same position at the Funny Bone Comedy Club in Syracuse New York. His experience teaching Improvisation for Actors goes back for over 25 years and includes 15 week-to-fortnight long workshops (before he was hired full time) at Buffalo State; multi-class workshops at ImprovOlympic West in Hollywood, Northwestern University, UCLA, Beaver College in Philadelphia, Solvita Arts in Kissimmee Florida, Brown University, and West Virginia University among others. In 2014 he taught a three day “Writing Satire For Television and the Stage” seminar at Ithaca College in Ithaca New York. This was presented at The Rod Serling Theatre-named for the all-time Television Icon who taught Screen and Teleplay Writing there for many years right up to his death. Tim’s seminar was an integral section of a weeklong for-credit intensive class Keynoted by Saturday Night Live Alum and current NBC Late Night Host Seth Meyers. Tim has taught smaller workshops at venues too numerous to mention and is currently the Improvisational Acting Instructor In Residence at the New Phoenix Theatre in Buffalo, New York.
