story:
New Plays for a Montana Audience

We want to create a new play festival for Montana theatre artists. Last year, we put together the Last Chance New Play Fest pretty much on the fly. This year, we want to take it to the next level. With your support, we can

  • Rent a space
  • Buy paint, and other materials and transform it into a working theatre space
  • Obtain lights and sound equipment for the performances
  • Print posters, flyers, and programs for the audience
  • Compensate the actors and directors

Our thanks to you

All the money we raise will go directly to the festival, but we do want to express our appreciation to our donors. Our thank-you gifts will include:

  • A special LCNPF pin, with the festival logo
  • Festival posters
  • Festival passes that will get you into any performance
  • Donors names in the program or on our website

What we're up to

The LCNPF was started by the Experimental Theatre Cooperative, a production wing of a non-profit organization dedicated to the dramatic arts. Our 501(c)3 designation means we're not in it for the money, we're in it to make theatre happen.

  • Last year's festival, the first, was reviewed as "fresh live theatre"
  • We've got a bunch of writers, actors, and directors ready to make it happen
  • With your help, this year's festival will be even better
In 2016, we've doubled the number of participants. The 2015 festival featured the work of four writers. This year, we have seven Montana playwrights (and an Improv troupe) ready to produce their work on the stage.

Risks & Challenges

Frankly, we're committed to making this happen, no matter how much we raise in this campaign. As playwrights, we want to hone our skills and develop our work, and this festival will let us do that. However, as producers, we would like to see the actors and directors be compensated for their hard work. The more we raise through this campaign, the more likely we'll be able to allocate funds to compensating the artistic staff.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, please help by sharing our campaign:

  • Tell your friends about the Last Chance New Play Fest.
  • Remind them to check out our Indiegogo page!
  • Come see the shows!

story:
Short Summary

Jaime Maseda and Mark McCloughan (that’s us) have been working together as No Face Performance Group since 2007. In that time, we’ve created 15 original pieces that have been performed across the country. 

This summer, we have three exciting opportunities to share our work with new audiences.

First, we’re premiering a new dance called THE TOP at JACK in Brooklyn. This will be the first full-length No Face work to be presented in New York City. A month later, we’ll perform Abbot Adam: Evensong as part of ANT Fest at Ars Nova, again in New York. In August, we’ll travel to Chicago to present THE TOP at Links Hall. 

THE TOP at JACK: May 26-28 http://www.jackny.org/no-face-performance-group.html

Abbot Adam: Evensong: June 29 http://arsnovanyc.com/antfest/june-29

THE TOP at Links Hall: August 6-8 - more details coming soon!

We’re thrilled about these opportunities -- they’re a chance to encounter lots of people who have never seen our work before. However, showing and touring two different pieces in two different cities in just over two months is a huge undertaking -- especially now that we're each based in PHL & NYC. We’ve got to book space to work in, transport sets and objects, cover travel, and of course, pay the artists we’re working with. Your support for this campaign will ensure that we’re able to take full advantage of these three opportunities, and that we’ll have the resources to make sure each of the presentations of our work are in top form.

What We Need & What You Get

We’ve sat down and worked out a budget for what we’re calling our summer season. Here’s where the money from this campaign will go:

-$2200 will cover the creation and premiere of THE TOP in May. We’ve been hard at work putting the finishing touches on this piece, which has been in and out of development for the past two year. We’re working with our longtime designer Andrew Thompson and we’ve brought on the inimitable Mel Krodman as a performer. Money from this campaign will help cover artist fees, equipment rental, and rehearsal space.

-$1000 will cover the remount and presentation of Abbot Adam: Evensong in June. We’re honored to have been selected to present a piece as part of Ars Nova’s ANT Fest. An annual showcase of new work and emerging talent, ANT Fest is an incredible opportunity to work with one of NYC’s most exciting off-broadway companies. Money from this campaign will help cover artist fees, and technical equipment rentals and transport.

-$2000 will cover our tour of THE TOP to Chicago. We’re lucky enough to be presenting this piece at Links Hall. Though this piece has no set, touring it will still require a lot of logistics: travel, housing, and food. Money from this campaign will cover these touring expenses as well as artist fees.

-$500 will help us cover the processing fees for this crowdfunding campaign. 

To thank you for your support, we've got some exciting perks related to these pieces in the right-hand column. Including, but not limited to: exclusive music and sound compositions from the Abbot Adam cycle, dinner with No Face, a personalized video version of THE TOP, and special blessings from Sisters Sibyl and Sistine.

The Impact

This campaign will help us take full advantage of three different chances to show our work to new audiences. With your support, we’ll have the time and space to devote ourselves fully to making each show the best it can be. We’re experienced at self-producing, having worked consistently in Philadelphia for almost 5 years. Now we’re at a critical juncture in our work together, beginning to partner with presenters to share our work with their audiences. Your support at this time would help us leverage this exposure into more opportunities to perform.

Risks & Challenges

It’s not easy to self-produce your work. It takes diligence, planning, and focus. And that’s just the fun part (actually making the show). Self-producing also requires a lot of administrative work: booking space, planning rehearsals, coordinating load-ins and strikes, and of course, fundraising to make all of the above happen. With this campaign, we’re hoping that the knowledge that we have the money we need to cover our expenses will give us more time to focus on doing what needs to be done to make the show a success.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with your friends, family, and anyone you think might be interested in supporting some new performance work and the artists who make it. We’re excited about this summer season and hope you’ll help us make it happen.

photo by Jenna Spitz

In August, we’ll travel to Chicago to present THE TOP at Links Hall. 
THE TOP at JACK: May 26-28 http://www.jackny.org/no-face-performance-group.html
Abbot Adam: Evensong: June 29 http://arsnovanyc.com/antfest/june-29
THE TOP at Links Hall: August 6-8 - more details coming soon!
We’re thrilled about these opportunities -- they’re a chance to encounter lots of people who have never seen our work before. However, showing and touring two different pieces in two different cities in just over two months is a huge undertaking -- especially now that we're each based in PHL & NYC. We’ve got to book space to work in, transport sets and objects, cover travel, and of course, pay the artists we’re working with. Your support for this campaign will ensure that we’re able to take full advantage of these three opportunities, and that we’ll have the resources to make sure each of the presentations of our work are in top form.
   What We Need & What You Get 
We’ve sat down and worked out a budget for what we’re calling our summer season. Here’s where the money from this campaign will go:
-$2200 will cover the creation and premiere of THE TOP in May. We’ve been hard at work putting the finishing touches on this piece, which has been in and out of development for the past two year. We’re working with our longtime designer Andrew Thompson and we’ve brought on the inimitable Mel Krodman as a performer. Money from this campaign will help cover artist fees, equipment rental, and rehearsal space. 
-$1000 will cover the remount and presentation of Abbot Adam: Evensong in June. We’re honored to have been selected to present a piece as part of Ars Nova’s ANT Fest. An annual showcase of new work and emerging talent, ANT Fest is an incredible opportunity to work with one of NYC’s most exciting off-broadway companies. Money from this campaign will help cover artist fees, and technical equipment rentals and transport.
-$2000 will cover our tour of THE TOP to Chicago. We’re lucky enough to be presenting this piece at Links Hall. Though this piece has no set, touring it will still require a lot of logistics: travel, housing, and food. Money from this campaign will cover these touring expenses as well as artist fees. 
-$500 will help us cover the processing fees for this crowdfunding campaign. 
To thank you for your support, we've got some exciting perks related to these pieces in the right-hand column. Including, but not limited to: exclusive music and sound compositions from the Abbot Adam cycle, dinner with No Face, a personalized video version of THE TOP, and special blessings from Sisters Sibyl and Sistine.
The Impact
 
This campaign will help us take full advantage of three different chances to show our work to new audiences. With your support, we’ll have the time and space to devote ourselves fully to making each show the best it can be. We’re experienced at self-producing, having worked consistently in Philadelphia for almost 5 years. Now we’re at a critical juncture in our work together, beginning to partner with presenters to share our work with their audiences. Your support at this time would help us leverage this exposure into more opportunities to perform.

Risks & Challenges  
It’s not easy to self-produce your work. It takes diligence, planning, and focus. And that’s just the fun part (actually making the show). Self-producing also requires a lot of administrative work: booking space, planning rehearsals, coordinating load-ins and strikes, and of course, fundraising to make all of the above happen. With this campaign, we’re hoping that the knowledge that we have the money we need to cover our expenses will give us more time to focus on doing what needs to be done to make the show a success.

Other Ways You Can Help 
Please share this campaign with your friends, family, and anyone you think might be interested in supporting some new performance work and the artists who make it. We’re excited about this summer season and hope you’ll help us make it happen.photo by Jenna Spitz

story:
Meet Our Founders!

The founders of Four Walls and a Stage are four ambitious lesbians who have spent their lives learning about and working in performing arts and media. In addition to being trained, professionals in our fields, we are passionate and active in social issues and hope to use our talents for the greater good. Almost, Maine is our inaugural production and a true testament to our collaborative abilities as we are working closely in directing, producing, and acting in this play.

Landry Allbright

Landry finally got around to starting her acting career at the late age of 2 years old. After learning set life on commercials and print work, she began booking heavy hitter roles in films including Con Air and How the Grinch Stole Christmas and television shows like Six Feet Under, The West Wing, Will & Grace, and Malcolm in the Middle. She eventually went on to receive her BFA in Acting from Emerson College and is now back in LA acting, writing, and directing. Look out for her upcoming films Feral, Getaway Girls, and Kill The Boyfriend. @notlaundry

Sam Henning

Sam's professional career began of her own volition at age 8. She grew up in the New Jersey suburbs of Manhattan where, as a child, she learned from the best, working with directors like Frank Oz and Christopher Ashley. She has a BFA in acting from The Theatre School at DePaul University and a resume of nearly 50 theatrical productions. In addition to numerous new media projects, short films, and music videos, she has been seen on As the World Turns and MTV's Catfish: The Untold Stories. She produces and records a weekly podcast, The Small and the Angsty. @samkhenning, www.samkhenning.com

Colleen Labella

Also from New Jersey, Colleen earned her BFA in Acting from the University of Connecticut and studied at the Tisch School of the Arts at NYU as well as Shakespeare's Globe in England. Colleen's favorite theatre credits include Connecticut Repertory Theatre's productions of Dead Heavy Fantastic and Goblin Market, in which she learned to play with puppets. Colleen continues her professional training at Lesly Kahn at LK & Co. While living in Los Angeles, she has worked on camera in many projects including on Criminal Minds, My-Crazy Ex, and Supreme Justice. @colleenlabella, www.colleenlabella.com

Olivia Saccomanno 

Originally from Northern California, Olivia studied at the Moscow Art Theater School in Russia, through the Eugene O'Neill Theatre Center, and she earned her MFA at the University of Connecticut. Her extensive theatrical resume includes productions of Three Musketeers (Milady), His Girl Friday (Hildy Johnson), Big Love (Thyona), The Winter’s Tale (Hermione), Educating Rita (Rita Susan White), Doubt (Sister James), The Lion in Winter (Alais Capet), and Antigone (Ismene). @oliwankanobe, www.oliviasaccomanno.com

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising $3,000 to cover the costs of putting on Almost, Maine, the first ever production of Four Walls and a Stage.

While everyone involved in this production is a working professional in her field, this is a labor of love and a passion project for us as we lay the foundation for the future of our company.

We are doing this for a little as possible while maintaining a commitment to honor everyone's hard work, passion, and talent in telling this story.

From the filmmaker who shot our funding video to our amazing lighting designer whose resume left our jaws on the floor, we have been incredibly fortunate to have so many industry professionals support us in donating their time and talents for little to nothing in return. However, we still need funding to cover costs that include:

  • Performance Rights
  • Theatre Rental Fee
  • Printing Costs (posters, postcards, programs, etc.)
  • Sets (design, materials, labor, etc.)
  • Props
  • Music Rights
  • Lights (design, equipment)
  • Fundraising Fees

We have put together some perks for different levels of donation as a small token of our gratitude. No matter what you are able to donate, every little bit helps, and every little bit means a whole lot to us.

The Impact

Representation matters.

Almost, Maine is a beautiful story that has been performed countless times. However, like most love stories, it focuses primarily on heterosexual couples. Most of what we see in the media of LGBTQ+ individuals is a very narrow representation, especially with lesbians. As lesbians, we may have a bias here, but we also have a heightened sensitivity to this issue.

With your contribution, you are supporting the LGBTQ+ community and helping to give us a platform to have our stories seen and heard. We believe in the power of art to make meaningful, impactful, positive changes in the world and in individuals.

If we are fortunate enough to have funds left over after this production, it will be used to further develop and advance Four Walls and a Stage in our commitment to human-centric stories focusing on women and the LGBTQ+ community.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot afford to donate, no worries! As a group of Los Angeles artists, we get it. You can still help us spread the word about this campaign and our company, and we would love it if you to came to see Almost, Maine at the Chromolume Theatre on March 9th, 10th, or 11th.

We are online at http://www.fourwallsandastage.com and on Instagram @fourwallsandastage

story:
About:

CoreDance Contemporary is an Australian Modern Dance Company residing in New York City. Founded by Artistic Director Rebecca McCormac in March 2011, the company is comprised of five dance artists who bring different cultural and dance backgrounds to the fore, to form a hardworking and dedicated ensemble.

CoreDances' objective is to investigate choreographically, different and oft times contradictory movement vocabulary through the physicality of one’s kinetics and to explore the realization of this physicality as it takes shape in the space.  Ms McCormac has an interdisciplinary approach to her work drawing ideas both contextually and visually to create work that is engaging for herself and her audience.  CoreDance has been presented at:  APAP New York City Center, The ODC Theatre San Francisco, The Dairy Arts Center Boulder, The Dance Complex Boston, CHI Movement Arts Center Philadelphia, Your Move NJ, Alvin Ailey, New York City Center, Steps on Broadway, DANY Studios, PMT, Dixon Place, White Wave, Triskelion Arts, The Actors Fund Arts Center and Green Space.

Campaign:

CoreDance's "VERTERE" Campaign is being launched to assist the company produce and present its 2019 Spring Season.  This venture is an important goal at this stage in the company's timeline as we are trying to make a name for ourselves in the ever competitive dance industry that is New York City. 

Goal:

Our goal is to raise $2000.00 to help with film production values.  If our goal is not reached the amount obtained will be used solely for the cost of fiming and editing our collaboration with Iris Media Works Director/Producer Conner Thompson.  

Perks:

We are providing an opportunity to observe CoreDance Contemporary in Rehearsal to the first 10 people who contribute $50.00.

Any contribution is helpful, so even if you can't make one of monetary value we would just love it if you could spread the word and make some noise about our campaign. 

You can find us at:

http://coredancecontemp.wixsite.com/dance-company

https://www.facebook.com/CoreDanceContemporary/

https://www.instagram.com/coredancecontemporary/

https://twitter.com/CDC_CoreDance

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCnXa1Ew0ePCoua...

 

To reserve tickets to "VERTERE" please visit:  https://vertere.brownpapertickets.com  

Thanks so much for showing your interest in our campaign.

Artistic Director:  Rebecca McCormac

Dance Artists:  Rebecca Allen, Kathleen Bollana, Luke Muscat Jessica Nolan, and Brittany Piazza

Photo Credit:  Scott Allen

Meet the CoreDance Contemporary team:

Rebecca Allen, Dance Artist:  bec.allen7@gmail.com

Rebecca, originally from Staten Island, New York, graduated with a BFA from SUNY Purchase Conservatory of Dance. While there she performed works by Doug Varone, Ori Flomin, Mark Morris, and John Heginbotham. She also studied in Perth, Australia at the Western Australian Academy of Performing Arts, focusing on contemporary dance and aerial circus silks. Rebecca has danced with Synthesis Dance Project, Copy That Dance, and was a guest artist in Doug Varone's Choreographic Intensive where she had the opportunity to dance with Dance Householder, MATYCHAK, and Sum Bones Co. This is Rebecca's fifth season with CoreDance Contemporary and she is thrilled to continue her journey with the company.

Kathleen Bollana, Dance Artist:  kathleen.bollana@gmail.com

Kathleen Bollana was born in Utica, NY. She began dancing when she was 3 years old at Utica Dance, studying ballet, modern, jazz and tap. She then continued on to SUNY Purchase, as a student in the Conservatory of Dance. She graduated magna cum laude May of 2015 with a BFA in Dance and a minor in Arts Management. Kathleen attended many summer intensives as a student and resident assistant, such as, Nutmeg Conservatory of the Arts, North West Dance Project, NYSSSA Ballet and Modern, North Carolina Dance Theater, and Saratoga Summer Dance Intensive. While at Purchase, Kathleen was sent to Taipei, Taiwan to perform Stephen Petronio’s Lareigne at the Taipei Dance festival, along with studying a semester abroad in Rotterdam, Netherlands at Codarts Rotterdam. She has performed many ballet and modern works, along with many choreographed by Merce Cunningham and Robert Battle. Kathleen has worked with many choreographers, Kirk Peterson, Oliver Wecxsteen, Alexandre Pr oia, Rosalind Newman, Ori Flomin, along with many more over the years. She is currently freelancing and professionally performing with CoreDance Contemporary, Exit 12 and XAOC Contemporary Ballet. 

Luke Muscat, Dance Artist:  lukemuscat@msn.com

Luke Muscat is thrilled to be in his first season with CoreDance Contemporary! Luke received his early training at the Quinte Ballet School of Canada and later as a scholarship student at The Ailey School. His performance highlights include performing with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater in Memoria at New York City Center Theater, Matthew Rushing’s In the Void at the Park Avenue Aromory, the Saint Vincent Project with the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, the Andre Agassi inspired 2016 US Open Mullet Mob sponsored by Lavazza coffee, and Citie Ballet’s Murder at the Strand. Furthermore, Muscat is on faculty at The Mark Morris Dance Center, The Ailey School Junior Division, and the School at Steps on Broadway. He brings the joy of dance into public school classrooms as a teaching Artist with the New York City Ballet Education Department, Alvin Ailey Arts and Education, and the Mark Morris Dance Group. Luke is also the lower school dance teacher at The Hewitt School, a Manhattan independent school for girls. Additionally, Luke is a certified teacher for Primary through Level 3 of the ABT® National Training Curriculum, the Autism Movement Therapy® Method, and received a specialized education in teaching movement to children on the Autism spectrum at the Marquis Studios Teachers Training Institute.

Jessica Nolan, Dance Artist:  http://jessicanolan75@gmail.com

Jessica Nolan began her dance training in Australia and continued upon moving to Canada. In Edmonton, AB she graduated from the Victoria School for the Performing and Visual Arts with a scholarship to attend The State University of New York (SUNY) Purchase. Jessica studied abroad at The Western Australian Academy for Performing Arts. While in the Conservatory of Dance at Purchase she performed works by George Balanchine, Twyla Tharp, Lar Lubovitch, Justin Rutzou and Kyle Abraham. Jessica had the opportunity to perform works by Marie Chouinard, and Manuel Vignoulle. She has performed with MADArt and Periapsis Music and Dance. This is Jessica’s sixth season dancing for CoreDance Contemporary under the direction of Rebecca McCormac. 

Brittany Piazza, Dance Artist:  piazzabrittany@gmail.com

Brittany Piazza was born and raised in Syracuse, New York where she trained in classical ballet, jazz, modern, and tap. She is an alumna of NYSSSA School of Dance directed by Carolyn Adams. Brittany graduated magna cum laude from Adelphi University in May of 2015 with a BFA in Dance. While at Adelphi she performed works by; Jacques Cesbron, Martha Graham, Leda Meredith, Orion Duckstein, Takehiro Ueyama, Jiří Kylián, and Paul Taylor. This is Brittany's fourth season with CoreDance Contemporary and she is thrilled to continue her journey with the company

story:
My friends, thank you for being here!

If we are new friends, let me describe myself for you.

My name is Buck.

I am a writer and performer

of plays and poetry.

A storyteller.

Sometimes, to tell 

favorite stories, 

oldest jokes,

and newest tales,

we have to invent some things along the way...

This campaign is lovingly spread to my friends

in search of support for production costs for The One About Us,

a solo performance on a ladder, coming to Boulder in May 2018.

This includes the cost of parts and labor for the engineers to design and build this

9 foot endlessly looping ladder.

That's right - this campaign is funding the build of a special ladder,

which I am going to climb for the entire performance.

It needs to be a loop on gears, 

and it needs to be specially designed, engineered, and built!

 

The design funded by this campaign is WHOLLY UNIQUE

- as much a work of art as a working machine.

 

Find out more about the story here.

 

In other words...

Your help goes towards the cost to

make the ladder a reality,

source costumes,

support guest directors,

design/run tech,

work in a rehearsal space,

transport the finished product to rehearsal and performance space,

.

.

.

It turns out, a solo performance takes A LOT OF PEOPLE!

.

.

.

For being someone who helps me out,

I am thrilled to give some concrete options for a return of support by offering

a behind the scenes documentary (screening, dvd, or digital versions available,) 

discounted tickets,

producer credits,

credits for the build of the ladder,

permission to climb the ladder!!!!?!?!

 

If we can't complete the fundraiser together...

no sweat. 

There are upcoming 

FUNDRAISER PARTIES

where you are invited to dance, drink, and donate

as well as grants and other funding to get me to my ultimate goal

and bring you

the WORLD PREMIERE

of The One About Us

a Kosmic Joke Play

by Buck Lee!

 

In past campaign missions

I have raised funding for projects of this size -

and I am happy to connect you with some of my beloved fiscal donors of the past.

The most exciting thing to me about this project to fund The One About Us

is inviting others into this dream of mine,

and learning about theirs.

 

This play is going to be performed in theatres across the U.S. after its premiere,

whatever my funding is.

 

I am thrilled about taking this show to the places I have once called home,

to places I have never been,

and to places that will surprise.

 

Even

without the ladder,

without lighting effects,

without costumes,

I will tell this story.

 

If you can't contribute

Know that I am so grateful for any kind of your support,

and always ready to hear about how I can return that to you.

I am grateful if you

share this campaign to your circle of connections,

start a conversation with me,

purchase tickets to my performances,

attend the fundraiser parties,

or ask me questions!

Love,
Buck
story_txt:
My friends, thank you for being here!
If we are new friends, let me describe myself for you.
My name is Buck.
I am a writer and performer
of plays and poetry.
A storyteller.
Sometimes, to tell 
favorite stories, 
oldest jokes,
and newest tales,
we have to invent some things along the way...
This campaign is lovingly spread to my friends
in search of support for production costs for The One About Us,
a solo performance on a ladder, coming to Boulder in May 2018.
This includes the cost of parts and labor for the engineers to design and build this
9 foot endlessly looping ladder.That's right - this campaign is funding the build of a special ladder, 
which I am going to climb for the entire performance.
It needs to be a loop on gears, 
and it needs to be specially designed, engineered, and built!
 
The design funded by this campaign is WHOLLY UNIQUE
- as much a work of art as a working machine.
 
Find out more about the story here.
 

In other words...
Your help goes towards the cost to
make the ladder a reality,
source costumes,
support guest directors,
design/run tech,
work in a rehearsal space,
transport the finished product to rehearsal and performance space,
.
.
.
It turns out, a solo performance takes A LOT OF PEOPLE!
.
.
.
For being someone who helps me out,
I am thrilled to give some concrete options for a return of support by offering
a behind the scenes documentary (screening, dvd, or digital versions available,) 
discounted tickets,
producer credits,
credits for the build of the ladder,
permission to climb the ladder!!!!?!?!
 

If we can't complete the fundraiser together...
no sweat. 
There are upcoming 
FUNDRAISER PARTIES
where you are invited to dance, drink, and donate
as well as grants and other funding to get me to my ultimate goal
and bring you
the WORLD PREMIERE
of The One About Us
a Kosmic Joke Play
by Buck Lee!
 
In past campaign missions
I have raised funding for projects of this size -
and I am happy to connect you with some of my beloved fiscal donors of the past.
The most exciting thing to me about this project to fund The One About Us
is inviting others into this dream of mine,
and learning about theirs.
 
This play is going to be performed in theatres across the U.S. after its premiere,
whatever my funding is.
 
I am thrilled about taking this show to the places I have once called home,
to places I have never been,
and to places that will surprise.
 
Even
without the ladder,
without lighting effects,
without costumes,
I will tell this story.
 
If you can't contribute
Know that I am so grateful for any kind of your support,
and always ready to hear about how I can return that to you.
I am grateful if you
share this campaign to your circle of connections,
start a conversation with me,
purchase tickets to my performances,
attend the fundraiser parties,
or ask me questions!Love,Buck

story:
BACKGROUND & PURPOSE

My name is Taylor Blaze Lindemann, and I am a Senior Honors BFA Theatre major at Millikin University. I have been working on this project for about two years now, which will culminate this semester in a two performance fully-mounted run on April 27th and 28th.

My reasons for starting this campaign is simple; I want this to be the absolute best production it can possibly be, but there are some things that a college student can't afford on a college students budget. Securing a performance space, costuming, make up, props, and various other necessary aspects of the show all come at a price, a price I cannot independently meet without the help of others.

All donations to this campaign will go towards funding the production, which I will use as frugally as possible. Any and all overhead from the production, including any donations at the door, will be promptly donated to Theatre for Young Audiences/USA, a national service organization dedicated to expanding, promoting, and encouraging professional theatre for young people of diverse backgrounds, while also innovating and advancing the art form with them. 

What We Need & What You Get

For the production, there are multiple costs as I identified above, these include:

  • Possible venue cost 
  • Make-up, hair dye, and other cosmetics for the performers
  • Costuming the Actors, including specialty items such as masks
  • Necessary props

As stated before, any and all overhead or proceeds from this fundraiser or the production itself will be donated to TYA/USA.

PERKS! While I can't offer a lot, I can promise these small rewards for your generous donations:

$5 - A personalized thank you e-mail from me, as well as priority entry for your choice of show night, either April 27th or 28th. Priority entry is first come first serve basis.

$10 - Personalized e-mail, priority entry, AND a limited edition Prince Hal coozie, with the following logo:

$25 - Priority Entry, a pair of limited edition Prince Hal coozies, and a personalized video message from the cast.

Impact

This project will give many student theatrical artists an opportunity to work within an avant-garde style not typically explored on a college campus, as well as creating performance and design opportunities that wouldn't otherwise be available to them. It will also introduce it's audience to a new style of theatre which is growing in popularity, and immerse the audience in a world they may or may not be familiar with, expanding cultural understanding and community involvement with varying lifestyles. 

This could truly make a difference in the Millikin and Decatur theatre communities, and show aspiring producers, directors, and performers in these communities that it is possible to create compelling theatre on your own. Thank you, for any help you can give. It means more than you know.

Even if you can't give, I ask that you share this event so that we can make this thing happen. Thank you all.

story:
Short Summary

Created in 2017 by Anna Pillot, Emerging Choreographers Project both features original works by up and coming choreographers, as well as provides free access to concert dance for the New York Capital Region community. Each performance is concluded with a talk back where the audience can engage in a dialogue with the choreographers and performers. 

For the past three years, ECP has been made possible in part due to funds from the Decentralization Program, a regrant program of the New York State Council on the Arts with the support of Governor Andrew Cuomo and the New York State Legislature and administered by The Arts Center of the Capital Region. Due to a break in funding after three years, for 2020 we are looking elsewhere to generate the financial support we need. The project continues to grow year over year, and we need your support to make it all happen.

 

Where Your Contribution Will Go

Costs to produce Emerging Choreographers Project include:

Stipends for the selected choreographers - the most important part of our budget! 

Insurance costs

Theater rental and staffing costs

Administrative and marketing fees

Stage manager and technical director costs

Dance floor rental

Any funding surplus will go towards next year's event

 

The Impact

Emerging Choreographers Project has become an an annual staple in the area community. We are able to support local choreographers and performers who don't always have the ability to present their work as an independent artists, and we are committed to maintaining free admission to ECP performances in order to further generate conversation about dance in the New York Capital Region. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with your friends and family! We are grateful for any and all forms of support.

story:
The Plan

After a successful run in New York City, we're taking our production to the 2019 Edinburgh Fringe Festival, renowned as the largest international arts festival in the world. We are raising $17,298 to bring Hitler's Tasters to Europe. 

 

The Play

Hitler’s Tasters is a dark comedy about the young women who have the “honor” of being Adolph Hitler’s food tasters. Based on true events, the play explores the way girls navigate sexuality, friendship, patriotism and poison during the Third Reich.

Read more here about the real life Taster, Margot Wölk.

 

The Goal

We need help bringing our 7 person team  (4 cast members and 3 production members) to Scotland to perform for the entire month of August! We've already raised $15,000 to cover our venue rental and lodging, and need additional funding for the following:

  • $4,550 - Flights 
  • ​$5,670 - Meals (food for 7 people for 30 days)
  • $5,000 - Marketing (press rep, printing flyers and posters, advertisements)
  • $500 - Rehearsal space
  • $200 - Baggage 
  • $1,500 - Insurance + Fees (incidentals & registration fees)

The Stretch

The amount we're asking for is the minimum budget required. Beyond that, we have a stretch goal of an additional $9,50​9:     

  • $18,298 - Bring a Stage Manager         

Raising this amount will allow us to bring a stage manager! This will cover the additional flight and meal stipend. 

  • $24,298 - Dinner Time       

This amount will allow us a $60 a day food stipend - wiggle room needed with that exchange rate! ($30 = current allotment in our budget)     

  • $26,807 - Jackpot       

This amount guarantees our stage manager can attend + a $60 meal stipend AND we can cover additional fees, including participation in 59E59 Theaters East to Edinburgh Festival in NYC this July as a pre-festival trial run!

The Motivation

To bring this story back to its roots in Europe and raise awareness of these historical women. This play provokes conversation, and we are eager to engage in discussions with an international and diverse audience. 

 

Other Ways To Help

  • Share this campaign with everyone you know! 
  • Follow our Instagram, Facebook, and Twitter: @ht_theplay
  • Comment + Like our social media posts
  • Connect us with your relatives or friends in Edinburgh!

 

Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

Mark Travis Rivera has been choreographing for over ten years. He is the founder of marked dance project, a contemporary dance company for disabled and non-disabled dancers. Now creating under the banner of Mark Travis Dance-- a contemporary-based group of storytellers, Mark is creating his first work since relocating to Oakland, CA for the Queering Dance Festival sponsored by Shawl-Anderson Dance Center. 

His new work, Disclosure  will tackle the stigma and shame associated with HIV. According to the Center for Disease Control, Latino men accounted for 90 percent of new HIV infections among Latinos in 2016, and 88 percent of these were among Latino gay and bisexual men. African American men accounted for three-quarters of new HIV infections among African Americans in 2016, and 80 percent of these were among African American gay and bisexual men. Disclosure will explore the story of revealing one's diagnosis to a lover and the fear that stems from isolation, rejection, and abandonment.   

What We Need & What You Get

  • Mark is offering (2) dancers a $15 travel stipend per rehearsal (5 rehearsals total); plus an honorarium of $300 for time spent rehearsing and $150 honorarium for (3) performances
  • Costumes: $75
  • Space rental: $75 
  • Bringing the total cost to: $1,500.   

The Impact

Your contribution will allow Mark to create a new work that speaks to an issue that is prevailing in our country-- stigma and shame around one's HIV status. It's time to de-stigmatize HIV and inform people about the virus and note that it doesn't make one less worthy of love and belonging. 

Risks & Challenges

  • The subject matter may upset some people 
  • Fundraising $1,500 is a lot of money but Mark has successfully fundraise in the past and believe in his vision for Disclosure. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Mark recognizes that not everyone can contribute financially but spreading the word about the campaign would be appreciated.

story:
Our Story

A Fool's Life is a fantastical tale about a family man coming undone.  This exciting new play is inspired by the    life and short stories of Japanese writer Akutagawa Ryunosuke, often referred to as 'the father of the  Japanese short story', and best known as the author of Rasomon.  Dark, bizarre and absurd, this multi-lingual piece combines puppets, projection and live drumming on a set made entirely of paper.  A Fool's Life is directed by Dan Watson, and features the award winning international creative team of Richard Lee, Claire Calnan, Derek   Kwan, Julian DeZotti, Haruna Kondo, Gaishi Ishizaka Sean Frey, Andre du Toit and Ravi Jain. The play will make one performance on September 23 at the Japanese Canadian Cultural Centre in Toronto, followed by its world premiere at the Theatre Centre in Toronto from September 30-October 8, 2011.

What We Are Asking

Because of the high costs of International travel, and our elaborate set design, Ahuri Theatre is bringing A   Fool's Life to the IndieGoGo community for your support.  Over the past year, the costs of flights have   increased dramatically and we are in need of your assistance to combat them.  We are also  asking for support  in realizing the vision of our unique set and projection design.  Our budget for this project is close to $50,000.  We hope to raise $4,400 here through IndieGoGo.

Ahuri Theatre is an independent company committed to collaboration and exploration with international and  multi-cultural artists in an open, respectful and honest manner.  You can be rest assured that your generous contribution will make a big difference in achieving this goal.  All contributions count not only to the project but   to to the Japanese Community of Toronto.

If you can't contribute to the campaign right now, please consider passing this message along to others who might be interested.

The Impact

This is a very ambitious and important project for our company.  We have been working on it since 2009, and   we are so excited to finally share it with audiences!  It features a diverse creative team of international artists   who will share their incredible talents with Toronto youth across the city through teaching free workshops. They will also help foster an appreciation for Japanese artists through  their stunning performances.  This play  employs a unique set made entirely of paper, as well as one of a kind puppets, and live drumming rarely seen   on stages in Canada.  As one of the only companies in Toronto committed to performing Japanese stories, this production provides an important outlet to introduce Japanese culture to larger audiences, and to celebrate the life and work of this important  writer.  It is also the chance to create a piece of theatre that can travel to Japan where we can make more connections, and encourage more exchange and communication between our two countries.

story:
“A person does not choose ballet; ballet chooses the person” …..Maria Vegh

The 1950′s and all of New York City is under the spell of its flourishing art scene. A young singer named Maria Vegh enters the world famous Juilliard School at age 18. Coming from a small town background out of Allentown PA, Maria is awarded a summer scholarship to study voice. Although she never danced a step in her life she enrolls in ballet classes as a way to gain poise on stage. Standing in the back of the class trying to follow the combinations, her teacher is impressed with her focus and enthusiasm. She offers Maria private lessons telling her the only pay she wants is that someday Maria will pass the learning on to others

Maria Vegh trained and coached a Who’s Who of contemporary dance. Maria’s students don’t merely dance the world’s stages; they dominate them with extraordinary strength, grace and endurance. Other teachers teach movement, but Maria gives her students that extra something: a dancer’s mind and the body to realize what that mind imagines. She has done this consistently for almost 50 years.

As we watch Maria teach children, teenage students and advanced dancers, we will discover the intangible something she transmits. Maria Vegh did not dance a step until she was 18 years old, in 1950. Within three years she became a soloist with Ballet Repertory of New York. Maria beat out more experienced dancers for roles because she could learn the choreography faster than anyone else – and she could do it better. Soon she began teaching others how to do what she did naturally. Maria discovered she could teach as instinctively as she danced, and her students quickly surpassed other dancers.

As much as anyone, Maria Vegh deserves credit for the rise of the American dancer, and the premier place the United States achieved in the world of dance.

Maria Vegh – An American Ballet Story is sponsored by ODC Theater, a non-profit organization.  It is an eyewitness view of the history of dance in America and an exploration of how knowledge is passed from teacher to student

The Impact

This project’s immediate goals are Preservation, Documentation, Outreach and Education.

It is a 3 tiered project that includes an interactive website,  an interactive catalog of Maria’s teachings on DVD, and a documentary film about Maria.

Phase 1 of our project - an interactive website has just been launched and is available at http://www.anamerican balletstory.com. 

We are currently creating an interactive teaching catalog which will be a synthesis of Maria's 50 years of teaching and her work with the National Academy of Ballet and the Harkness Research and Training Program.  The DVD will allow Maria’s work to continue into the 21st century and make it possible to extend her knowledge to many other teachers, dancers, students and anyone who is interested in dance. The content will outline programs for young children, teenage students and advanced dancers.

As someone recently told us, "When you speak of American Dance History you speak of her."

We are seeking support for the following:

We filmed Maria teaching young students over a 13 week period at ODC San Francisco in 2010. There are literally 100's of hours of video to edit.  We desperately need support to pay professional editors and sound technicians. 

Once the teaching DVD is complete we will need funding to market it to dance organizations and dance teachers throughout the world.

Maria is now 79 years old. We’re asking the questions: is it the props she uses – an array of balance beams, hula hoops and toys that makes her dancers more graceful, durable and strong? Or do her theories about circular patterns in movement have deep basis in the human form?  Does her boundless energy and vitality in her late ’70′s come from her own training, or is it her dedication and spirit? What makes her such a remarkable teacher?  We hate to think what will happen if her work goes undocumented and is lost to time.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • We're looking for volunteers to help us fundraise and build social media awareness on Facebook and other sites.
  • Volunteer to host events, socials & meetups in the SF Bay area

The content will outline programs for young children, teenage students and advanced dancers.As someone recently told us, "When you speak of American Dance History you speak of her."We are seeking support for the following:We filmed Maria teaching young students over a 13 week period at ODC San Francisco in 2010. We’re asking the questions: is it the props she uses – an array of balance beams, hula hoops and toys that makes her dancers more graceful, durable and strong? Or do her theories about circular patterns in movement have deep basis in the human form?  Does her boundless energy and vitality in her late ’70′s come from her own training, or is it her dedication and spirit? What makes her such a remarkable teacher?  We hate to think what will happen if her work goes undocumented and is lost to time.Other Ways You Can Help
We're looking for volunteers to help us fundraise and build social media awareness on Facebook and other sites. 

Volunteer to host events, socials & meetups in the SF Bay area

story:
Maine Playwrights Festival
April 25 - May 5, 2013
St. Lawrence Center for the Arts, Portland

Short Summary

Acorn Productions started the Maine Playwrights Festival as part of our mission to nurture theater artists. Now in its 12th year, the MPF is Maine's premiere incubator for new plays. Over the years we have been proud to present hundreds of world premiere plays, some of which have gone on to be produced at Festivals in New York and elsewhere. For playwrights, this is an invaluable opportunity to see their words interpreted by directors and actors and see how audiences react. For the actors it is a unique chance to originate characters that will set the standard for future productions of the work. For the audience it is an introduction to emerging and established playwrights who live and write here in Maine. Who knows...some day one of these playwrights could be accepting a prestigious award for one of their plays and you can say "I was there when they got their start at the Maine Playwrights Festival!"

Your contribution toward our $3,000 goal helps make it possible for Acorn to provide this important service to our community by helping with overhead costs for this vibrant and exciting new works festival.

What We Need & What You Get

Our $3,000 indiegogo campaign goal bridges the gap between our anticipated expenses and our anticipated ticket sales and sponsorship revenue. This funding will be divided among all the essential aspects of the Festival: publicity, technical and directorial staff, tech materials (such as costumes, props, paint, lighting gel, and glowtape for backstage safety), and venue rental fees.

Your contribution is important to us, but we don't want that to be the end of your association with the Festival. We want you to see the plays you support, so we are offering rewards ranging from a ticket to a performance for donations of $50 to all-access passes (attend any and all performances and meet the cast) for donations of $250 and up, and even a chance to appear on stage during the Festival for donations of $1000 or more.

The Impact

Your contribution is essential as we bridge the gap between what it costs to put the Maine Playwrights Festival on and what we bring in from ticket sales. Donations of all sizes matter:

  • Your $25 donation prints ~50 playbills to tell our audience about the plays and playwrights.
  • Your $50 donation purchases ~5 sheets of lighting gel to paint the stage with color.
  • Your $100 donation purchases an ad to spread the word about the Festival and fill the house.
  • Your $300 donation covers the rental cost for one performance.
  • Your $500 donation covers much of the cost to design and print publicity materials for the festival.

Every donation at every level makes a big difference.

Other Ways You Can Help

Contributions of all kinds are needed to get us to our fundraising goal and make the Maine Playwrights Festival a success.

  • Tell all your friends! Pass along the information about this campaign and the Festival. Encourage them to get involved.
  • Volunteer! Contact Michael Levine at acornmike@gmail.com if you would like to usher, help with publicity, or volunteer in some other way.
  • Share this fundraising campaign using the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you!

story:
Theatre Movement Bazaar is touring Track 3 from LA to the UK in the summer of 2013!



Following the success of Anton’s Uncles at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe in 2011 (Outstanding Theatre Award, multiple 5 star reviews, sell out shows) and its subsequent UK tour, Los Angeles-based Theatre Movement Bazaar is collaborating with Greenwich Theatre of London once again to bring TRACK 3, our big hit from early 2013, to share with UK audiences. 

Track 3 will be in residence at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe for 4 weeks and then travel to London to spend 1 week at the Greenwich Theatre.  In order to make this happen, we need to raise $24,000 to cover our portion of expenses for 10 company members. Help us act as your cultural ambassadors on the world stage.

 

Here’s what your donation can do for our artists:

$1500 flies an actor to and from the UK

$500 houses one company member for the entire tour

$100 prints 1000 fancy fliers

$50 feeds one of our actors for two days

$25 launders our costumes for a week

$5 buys a cardboard belt!

 

TRACK 3

The show premiered in January 2013 both at the Bootleg Theater in Los Angeles, and as part of the Studio SCR series at South Coast Repertory in Costa Mesa, CA. Based on the great reviews and enthusiastic audiences, London’s Greenwich Theatre has offered to co-produce Track 3 at Scotland’s Edinburgh Festival Fringe, as well as present the show at their theatre in London. However, Theatre Movement Bazaar needs to raise $24,000 to cover its portion of the co-production costs. 

THE COMPANY

Our mission is to reinvigorate theatre for a contemporary audience. We've been making new theatrical works for over 15 years; deconstructing myths, classic literature and plays, injecting humor, dance, song and heightened physicality to create its unique brand of theatre. Our new show, Track 3, derails Anton Chekhov’s Three Sisters from its Victorian origins for a 21st century existential extravaganza.  It’s a fresh, new perspective on the Chekhov classic.

This is a tremendous opportunity for Theatre Movement Bazaar.  Join our mission. Be a part of re-energizing the theatrical tradition by contributing to our Track 3 to UK campaign. 

We thank you for any support you can give!

story:
Yehoodi.com wants to bring lindy hop to the world in a way it’s never been done before -- a live, television-quality, HD video broadcast of the best lindy hop competition in the world.  With your help, we can do just that.

For 15 years, Yehoodi.com has been providing, free of charge, an online home for the lindy hop community.  We’ve run discussion forums, live events like the Basie Centennial, streaming online swing radio, and audio/video podcasts like the Yehoodi Talk Show, Hey Mr. Jesse and SwingNation.

In all of that time, we have never asked for a dime from our members and viewers.  Today is the first time on all those years we are asking the lindy hop community for support. 

Last year, we went to the International Lindy Hop Championships in Washington DC and produced our first live on-site dance competition show. Using basic production equipment and a skeleton crew, we were able to put on a high quality production that had 23,000+ views over the weekend, with viewers logging in from Korea, Sweden, Australia and many more countries. We heard from hundreds of you how much you enjoyed the live broadcast and the video archive later.  

This year, we think we can do even better. We have an opportunity to create a television-quality, high definition video production from ILHC.  But we need your help.

 Here’s what we need:

  • bad ass equipment

  • a killer production team

 Luckily, we are close to having both. But we need additional funding to get this production going. 

Bad Ass Video Production Tools

The NewTek Tricaster 40 is a state-of-the-art compact video switcher and live production box.  It’s like what we currently use for "SwingNation," but much, much better.  It can:

  • pull in live footage from up to 4 different HD cameras,

  • display HD quality video,

  • play pre-recorded footage,

  • handle titles, transitions, "picture-in-picture" and more like a champ

In short, it will enable us to show ILHC -- and any other swing event in the future -- with HD television quality production values.

To take full advantage of this system, we will also need at least one HD camera capable of interfacing with the Tricaster. 

A Killer Production Team

As we demonstrated at ILHC and continue to do so on our weekly show "SwingNation," we can put out a high quality video production on a shoestring. Our full production crew includes:

  • Producer Manu "Spuds" Smith
  • Managing Editor Rik "Rikomatic" Panganiban
  • Co-host Nicole "Zuckerpunch" Zuckerman
  • Videographer Jim Thorpe 

We have had two seasons of shows to develop our pre-, live and post-production chops, and we think we work pretty darn well together. Your support will make it possible for all of us to be in DC for ILHC.

Yehoodi has been producing online video for as long as it's been available.  Our first online talk show was released in 1998, and we’ve been doing some version of it ever since.  We have the crew, the experience, and the technology to make this happen.

And we should mention, the organizers of ILHC 2013 have graciously invited us to be  their video production partners, for which we are extremely grateful.

Beyond ILHC

This is just the beginning of what we hope is a new era of online video for lindy hop, which we believe can be just as exciting and awesome as dance shows like “So You Think You Can Dance” and “Americas Best Dance Crew.”

We have already been approached by several event organizers to stream their competitions and showcases live to the internet. In particular, the team behind the Frankie100 Centennial Celebration have said that they would love for Yehoodi to be there in May of 2014 to stream some of that historic event to the world.  With your support, that can happen.

Also, if we reach our goal, we will be able to provide the lindy community with a much higher quality version of our weekly lindy hop based show, SwingNation, the only weekly live streamed video podcast that delivers news, events, interviews and featured dance videos for our Lindy Hop audience. The SwingNation show archive will be in the best quality possible for future generations to come.

Funding Goals

Base Goal: $5800. Yehoodi is able to purchase a Tricaster 40 and an HD video camera and fly one crew member to ILHC.

Stretch Goal #1: $9,600. Yehoodi is able purchase a Tricaster 40, three HD video cameras, and support all four crew members to be at ILHC.

 

Ah One, Ah Two...

If you believe that lindy hop is an awesome dance, and that people around the world should be able to see it in the highest quality production, we hope you will consider supporting our fundraiser.

But whether you support this project or not, keep spreading the love of lindy hop to those around you. It’s what Frankie would want you do to.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Holly Rose and I am the Founder and Managing Artistic Director of Rosebud Children's Theatre Conservatory.  I've been involved in theatre my entire life. I just can't get enough!  I was one of those kids who found my voice in theatre.  Without it, getting through high school would've been much more difficult.

 

I studied theatre, got degrees in it, performed in NYC, Chicago, Minnesota, Seattle, etc. now I find that my passion lies in sharing my knowledge and experience with others.  I especially love it when I watch someone's personality come to life on the stage.  The friendships that we make in theatre are like none other and are lifelong.

 

By contributing to our small non profit theatre, you are ensuring that:

-kids and teens to participate in the program, 

-we can hire high quality theatre professionals who know what they are talking about and are also good positive people.

-everyone who wants to attend a production can do so.

-our production values are of integrity.  We don't need super flashy, just the basics.

-the kids who don't have a "home" in other areas of life (academics, sports, etc.) can find it here with us.  Everyone needs a place in which to belong.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need at least $1500 to go to printing of posters and programs; set, lighting and costume supplies.

The perks you can get are photos of the cast & crew, tickets to the show, show poster signed by the entire cast.  You also get the satisfaction of knowing that YOU made it possible for these kids to make new friends, learn about theatre and themselves along the way.

If we don't reach our entire goal, the funds we do receive will be divided up among the categories listed above and each category will have a smaller budget with which to work.  Obviously, bigger is better - but one thing I have learned is how to work WITHIN a budget.  We will make do with less if we need to.

 

The Impact

Our project provides kids and teens with the ability to learn about themselves in a new way.  Our mission statement is to facilitate personal growth and social development through the creativity of the Theatre Arts.

We feel that we accomplish this by delving into the psychology of the characters and their relationships on stage.  The friendships made by the cast members are lifelong.  The kids routinely talk about not being able to wait until next summer to see each other again.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to donate a few dollars, we would appreciate your help by liking our Facebook page and sharing our information!  Word of mouth is our best marketing tool.  www.facebook.com/RosebudCTC

story:
A cast of NYC's brightest new and innovative performers brings you an improvised burlesque stage play on the endearing challenges of their teenage years. June 6, 2013 at 9pm at Coney Island USA, 1208 Surf Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

Starring Heather Whatever as herself, Coco te Amo, Matt Knife, and Wae Messed as her friends, Teasy Roosevelt their history teacher, Bombazeen Bean and Fancy Feast as surly art students, Beelzebabe Siren of Sodom as the Prom Queen, and hosted by Alfie Bunz as the Dean of Discipline. Stage kittening by Zoe Ziegfeld as the Freshman. Audience participation, including prom costumes or revival of your favorite high school look is encouraged!

Cast Photo by Andrew Levengood

story:
Hi, we’re Asae Dean and Jenny Newbry Waters, a passionate artistic team collaborating to produce one of our favorite plays, Fool for Love by Sam Shepard. Asae Dean is a stage director dedicated to producing plays that explore both the personal and political aspects of love and sexuality. Jenny Newbry Waters is an actor who believes in exploring human nature at its most extreme and vulnerable moments, in order to illuminate universal truths. Fool for Love by Pulitizer Prize Winning playwright Sam Shepard, about the electricity of a volatile and unexpected relationship, provides plenty of fuel to fire our artistic energies.

Jenny has wanted to play May in Fool for Love ever since she tackled the opening scene for her first acting class in college. “These characters are vibrating with electricity,” Jenny says.  “It’s as if they have been struck by the lightning of those famous Mojave desert storms where the play takes place.  The electricity simultaneously binds them together and forces them apart, resulting in a snarling, messy, impassioned avalanche of stunts, driving recklessly to a conclusion that will leave you breathless.”

Fool for Love runs Thursdays through Sundays, April 5th – 21st at Backdoor Theatre in Portland, Oregon. The show features local Portland actors Jenny Newbry Waters, Arthur Delaney, Tommy Harrington, and Brian MacEwan. Local actor and producer, Patrick J. Cox, is co-producing the show and local musician, Tobias Ryan, is serving as music director.

Patrick, Tobias, and Asae have worked together on various theatrical projects over the past four years, including Asae Dean Productions’ inaugural show, How I Learned to Drive by Paula Vogel, in September 2012, and Cressida, an adaptation of William Shakespeare’s Troilus and Cressida, in January-February 2013.

In order to produce this third show of our season, we need your help.

Box office ticket sales will offset a portion of our production costs and provide stipends for our actors and design/production team, but we also need to raise $3,000 to cover a portion of our initial production costs, including our venue rental fee, performance royalties, publicity materials, costumes, and props. Your contribution is crucial to the success of this production, so we’re asking for your help. In exchange for your support, we're offering a myriad of incentives and gifts at several giving levels.  Please help bring this important story of electric love, betrayal, loyalty, and survival in the Mojave desert to Portland audiences. Thanks!

Unable to contribute? There are other ways you can help. 

1) Come see the show! We would love to have you there. Tickets are available at the door and online.  Information at www.asaedirects.com

2) Invite friends and family to the show! We would love to have them there.  You can read about the show and see publicity photographs shot by local artist Ari Grey at www.asaedirects.com

3) Share this campaign. We love seeing others spread the word! It helps a lot. Thank you, thank you.

Thanks!
Unable to contribute? There are other ways you can help. 
1) Come see the show! We would love to have you there. Tickets are available at the door and online.  Information at www.asaedirects.com
2) Invite friends and family to the show! We would love to have them there.  You can read about the show and see publicity photographs shot by local artist Ari Grey at www.asaedirects.com
3) Share this campaign. We love seeing others spread the word! It helps a lot. Thank you, thank you.

story:
Something is rotten in the state of Denmark. Corruption. Murder. The loss of innocence. A displaced generation. What is the price we pay?

Featuring special guest artists Alec Baldwin, Kate Mulgrew and Anthony Rapp, Fundamental Theater Project shines a contemporary light on this classic tale.

 

WHO ARE WE?

Fundamental Theater Project was launched in April 2010. Over the past year, we have collaborated with established industry professionals and emerging artists creating a trans-atlantic theater community focused on the fundamental attributes of theater. After a successful benefit reading of Hamlet in November 2010 starring Alec Baldwin and Kate Mulgrew, we are developing an 80-minute contemporary adaptation of Shakespeare’s classic that resonates with audiences today.

 

The 2011 Edinburgh Fringe Festival marks our first international production. We need your help getting our company members "across the pond."

 

FTP in the Guardian UK: http://www.guardian.co.uk/culture/2011/apr/21/a...

FTP in the New York Times: http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/25/theater/to-be...

 

A LOST GENERATION

Every generation has had to pay the price for the mistakes of its predecessors: http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/02/world/europe/...

 

This New York Times article was the initial spark for centering our production of Hamlet around the idea the Lost Generation of today. A population of educated, eager young citizens are faced with the realities of the previous generation’s mistakes and coruptive practices. With this production, FTP discusses what our generation’s role is in the current economic and political climate? Do we take action? If so, what action do we take?

 

ELSINORE IN 3D

Today nearly every movie released can be viewed in 3D, inviting the audience to share in the action onscreen. In our staging, Hamlet is physically surrounded by the company of actors, feeling the intimacy and pressure of the action as well as observing the manipulations of those around him. Incorporating a blend of film footage and projected images, we add another dimension to the audience’s experience of the text and physical action. In addition to our 2D images and 3D actors, we are hoping to produce some segments in 3D film.

 

THE PLAYERS

Our production will feature a rotating cast of both established and emerging actors, including Spencer Aste, Kate Mulgrew, Nicola Murphy, Anthony Rapp, Sam Underwood, Jennifer Van Dyck, Jonathan Walker and a special appearance by Alec Baldwin as the Ghost of Hamlet’s Father.

 

HOW CAN YOU HELP?

Our total budget for the production is $80,000, of which we have already raised $20,000. Our goal is to raise $20,000 of the remaining $60,000 online to offset the cost of travel, accommodations and living expenses for the cast and company during the month of August in Edinburgh.

 

$1,000 – Airfare for one company member from New York City to Edinburgh, Scotland

$2,000 – Airfare and accommodations in Edinburgh for one company member

$2,750 – Airfare, accommodations and living expenses for one company member

 

In addition to supporting FTP here on indiegogo, you can also make a tax-deductible donation by making checks payable to: ROYAL FAMILY PRODUCTIONS and in the memo line write FUNDAMENTAL THEATER PROJECT

 

Mail to:

Fundamental Theater Project

527 W.46th St. Apt 19

New York, NY 10036

 

HOW ELSE CAN YOU HELP?

Air Miles - A donation of 60,000 air miles will send one company member to Edinburgh.

Connections - Do you know:

     - Someone who works in the corporate airline industry?

     - Supporters of young artists?

     - Someone who could furnish us with UK cell phones

     - Companies that would sponsor our printing needs?

Materials - We need:

     - MacBook Pro laptop

     - Film equiptment (3D rig, camera, sound, etc.)

     - A projector

 

For more information about this and our past projects, visit www.fundamentaltheaterproject.com

story:
Persephone's Fall is a massive undertaking with a cast of 4 musicians, 9 adult dancers, one child dancer, and many talented people helping with the overall design of the production. The music for this show is being composed and performed live by the immensely talented group The Ghosts Project.  Thus far, the development has been a wonderful collaborative experience, with each artist bringing a new layer and nuance to the final story.

The most well known version of the Persephone and Hades tale is very dark. We are telling a different version. There are interpretations of the myth in which Persephone chooses to travel to the Underworld, in which the focus is on the growth and development of Persephone from a protected child to a strong-willed woman, ultimately the Queen of the Underworld. That was the story that captured my imagination. I love studying human relationships and I felt this iteration had so many intriguing ones. We start our tale with a lonely and proud Demeter, one of the only deities left to dwell in the mortal world. We see her relationship with her beautiful young daughter and how it does not change as that daughter reaches adulthood. Demeter is overly protective, and is so often the case, that intense love begins to smother her daughter. When Persephone meets Hades she is intrigued and eager to step outside of her small world.

Hades himself is fascinating in that he is a strong, powerful figure, king over all of the Underworld. But what a lonely place over which to rule, full of ghosts and spirits. Just as Persephone needs room to breathe, Hades’s Underworld needs that touch of breath.  The Underworld has many sides to it, elements that Persephone must accept and understand in order to make her choice about whether to stay or go.

There’s the River of Souls overseen by Charon, and the glorious Elysian Fields. There’s the Furies, not keen on being supplanted by this woman, who challenge her to prove she is capable of ruling them. Finally there is Tartarus, where the souls of the wicked dwell in torment. Persephone cannot be merely an observer to these places, she has to understand them and accept them. She must make her choice to stay or go on her own terms. Ultimately she breaks the rules and finds a way to live in both worlds.

As fantastical as the setting is for this tale, and that setting is something we relish playing with, the tale itself is as simple as a woman finding balance in her life between the various loves and demands she bears.

We need your help to bring this story to the stage.  All funding will go directly to production costs. These costs include theater rental, costumes and masks, technical fees, and artist payments. We deeply appreciate any help you can give. Even the smallest donations add up! More than anything, we’d love your help spreading the word about the show. Without a vibrant audience, no story is truly complete!

To learn more about the cast and what we've done so far, check out our blog - Persephone's Notes.

Dancers:

  • Hillary Andrews
  • Thomas Bell
  • Ben Dobmeyer
  • Sarah Kelly Kerr
  • Jena Michele Kovash
  • Stephen Loch
  • Cara O’Grady
  • Sally O’Grady
  • Olivia Packwood
  • Rose Shields

Musicians:

  • Regeana Campbell
  • Aileen Loy
  • Paul Mercer
  • David Pettersen

Additional Artists:

  • Costume Design: Katherine Manfre
  • Graphic Design: Caitlin Holden of Blackbird Graphics  
  • Makeup Design: Jennifer Humphries Makeup Artistry  
  • Mask Design: Jason Gray of Sons of Plunder  
  • Photography: Larry Jerome of Gene Clem Photography

story:
At Infinity Box Theatre Project, we believe that the fundamental question of this century will be, “What does it mean to be human?”

Science is already having enormous impact on this question in two ways. First, we are learning things about the universe – and about ourselves – that call into question many longstanding assumptions about who we are. Second, this new knowledge has enabled us to make and do things that change us and our relationships with the world around us.

At Infinity Box Theatre Project, we are committed to using the power of theater to pose questions about the human consequences of science and technology. We provide a catalyst for conversation about what it means to be human in our rapidly changing world.

Thought Experiments on the Question of Being Human

Thought Experiments on the Question of Being Human is a multi-year project where each year we team 5 scientists with 5 playwrights who together create short works examining that question.

The theme for 2013 is Robots and Artificial Intelligence. Our question this year is: “How might current and possible future innovations in the fields of robotics and artificial intelligence change what it means to be human?”  We invited five scientists working with robots or AI and teamed each scientist with a local Seattle playwright. Their collaborations have led to the creation of five intriguing short plays, each of which provides a unique perspective on that question.

Each evening includes plays, followed by a scientist-led conversation, where the audience can explore the questions and issues raised by the plays about the impact robots and artificial intelligence may have on their lives.

Thought Experiments: Robots and AI is scheduled for  June 13, 14, & 15 at Town Hall, Seattle –  as Signature Program of the 2013 Seattle Science Festival..

What we will do with the money?

Simple:  Pay the rent.  As part of the Seattle Science Festival, we have kept our ticket prices very low so as many people as possible can come and participate.  If you can help us cover the rent (which is due in advance, by the way) we can use proceeds from ticket sales to pay the fine group of playwrights, directors and actors we have gathered to get these stories on stage. 

Other ways to help

Get the word out.  Tell your friends.  Send them the link.  Share it on Facebook and Twitter.  We are grateful for any help you can give us – money or otherwise.  It really makes a difference.

Facebook: facebook.com/InfinityBoxTheatreProject

Twitter: @IBTheatre

story:
What is Guamanique?

Guamanique is a nonprofit performing arts company from Puerto Rico.  Our mission is to promote Puerto Rican music, dances and traditions. We accomplish this through performances and shows designed for students, tourists and communities throughout the island.

It all started almost two decades ago, when a group of high school students, followed the lead of our founder and artistic director, Dr. Eduardo Calderon. Today, there are more than 30 active members and hundreds of young students have participated in our programs.

Internationally, we have represented Puerto Rico in festivals in 25 countries.  In these exchanges, we either perform in big metropolitan cities as well as in rural communities and villages. We participate in conferences, offer interviews to the media, take music and dance workshops and we teach Puerto Rican dances, usually to very large groups.

What is the project about?

This year, Guamanique was invited to Ecuador, to perform along with folkdance groups from 6 Latin American countries. The tour will take place from the 8th to the 16th of June, 2013.

You might ask why is this so important for you to back it. We feel it is important for us to share our cultural heritage and identity. Thanks to exchanges like this one people from every continent have been in contact with our music, thousands have entered in the rhythmic challenge of the Bomba, or joined a crowd dancing our Plena through the streets. These experiences enrich both our personal lives and our professional development as well.

We have made many fundraising activities during the past few months. But because of government cuts and lack of funding opportunities in the arts, we haven't met our goal for everyone to get onboard. At this moment, we are $5,000 short. So that's the reason why we decided to launch this campaing. We are asking you to be part of this project. We need your help to accomplish it.

So that you know, all the accommodations, meals and transportation will be provided by the host organization. We just need to raise the necessary funds to complete the costs of traveling to Ecuador.

Benefits
 
We will never be able to repay you for your support, but we came up with a few ideas to express our gratitude. Check the backers descriptions.

Plus, you'll have the great satisfaction of helping a cultural nonprofit with a serious and proven commitment with the youth.  

And one more thing, if you are in Puerto Rico or in the US, since we are a tax-exempt organization, your contribution can be deducted in your next tax returns.

We are counting with your support to make this tour to Ecuador a reality.

story:
Meraki - (Greek) - doing something with soul, creativity, or love — when you put “something of yourself” into what you’re doing, whatever it may be. 

Meraki!

Meraki! is a new, exciting piece of theatre being put on this winter.  It's a movement piece run by undergraduate drama students at NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, and completely independent.  Since there is no affialation to either NYU or a theatre company, this project is done out of the love we have for theatre, and whatever spare change we can round up in our wallets.  

The brain-child of Jenny Carlson and Andrea Angove-Volb, Meraki! is a fun new look at life through the lens of shadows and sihlouettes.  We have been diligently rehearsing since September, devevolping the piece as an ensemble.  We aren't looking to make money off of it, just simply share our love for what we do.

How you can help:

Donate, of course!  The money you donate will go towards:

  • The rental of the theatre
  • The cost of the set and screen
  • Costumes

Other ways you can help:

If money's a little tight for you at the moment, that's perfectly fine.  Spread the word about our project as much as you can!  Tell people about the show!  Come to the show and bring your friends.  We'd love to have you.

The piece will be held at:

The Drilling Company
236 West 78th Street, 3rd Floor
New York, NY   10024

December 7th-9th, 7pm.  Tickets are $5 at the door.
