story:
Short Summary

Ever walked around a neighborhood and wondered what kind of stories and histories are seething through it's buildings and streets? Would you like to see a tour without getting tired or leaving your comfy seat?

In this 13th installment of the hugely successful workshop series, STORIES HIGH, produced by Bindlestiff Studio, YOU CAN! Through a series of 10 rigorous weeks of workshops focusing on Writing, Directing, and Acting, we are pleased to present four very different short plays that were inspired by TRUE EVENTS from THE SOMA.

Bindlestiff Studio is the ONLY Filipino-American theater company in the nation which celebrates all forms of art. Your generous contributions to our production will ensure that we can mount this awesome production with success!

What We Need & What You Get

The $2,000 budget will help pay for our workshop facilitators and designers; afford our set, costumes, and props, and our administrative costs. 

We have fun perks for those who make a contribution. You'll be acknowledged in our social media outreaches and our program booklet, FREE tickets, free show merchandise, preferred seating to the show, an opportunity to meet the cast and crew on Opening Night, and credit as an Honorary Producer!

- Bindlestiff tee-shirt

- (Autographed posters)

- A pair of passes to "The Guerillas of Powell Street"

- VIP seating

- A date with Manny Cabrera

- Invitation to our Closing Night party

The Impact

Since Bindlestiff Studio is a non-profit theater space, we need your help to make sure that a gem like this in the SOMA can continue to provide AFFORDABLE, ACCESSIBLE, and MAGNIFICENT productions to the community. Since this is the 13th installment, we would love to continue and produce the 14th installment next year. With your help, WE CAN!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, WE STILL LIKE YOU!!! Here are other ways you can help. POST THIS ON YOUR FB, IG, TWIT, 4G, TEXT, CALL. ANY word of mouth will definately help us bring audiences to our seats. Make sure they come with YOU! And definately check our theater out for other shows, We would like to see you. AND WE ALWAYS APPRECIATE VOLUNTEERS!

story:
Short Summary

Who are we? JUNTOS Collaborators and passionate team members.

What is JUNTOS? We are a 501(c)3 organization that empowers individuals and inspires community building through teaching, learning, and exchanging dance with a strong focus in Central America. We seek your help to shape our hopes for our 2013-14 year!

JUNTOS facilitates free dance workshops and performances to cultivate leadership and collaboration by exchanging cultural differences. JUNTOS creates long lasting cross-cultural relationships with students from America’s top dance conservatories and low-income communities in Central America such as orphanages, centers for HIV+ children, hospitals, grade schools, retirement homes, and dance groups with lack of funding. Through advanced dance workshops and performance, participants are inspired to work for and with others and introduced to new ways of equality.

What We Need & What You Get

We seek your help while entering our 6th year! We are ambitiously planning special events and need your support to move forward!* We are asking for $4,800 from you to kick off our year. Individual support has always been key to facilitating JUNTOS activities. Your tax-deductible donation, made right here on Indiegogo, will take us one step closer to accomplishing our collective goals! With your help, we can begin to plan…

·  Fall & Spring performances in the bay area – Total costs estimated at $6,500

·  Spring performance on the East Coast – Total costs estimated at $2,500

·  International dance festival in Guatemala celebrating 5 years – Lots.

·  Research to extend our work to another country!­– Total costs estimated at $2,500

Even a small donation makes a big difference in our ability to achieve our collective goals. There are lots of rewards for donating, so check out the level that works for you Thank you so much for your help!

Our Impact

Since 2008, we’ve traveled with over 65 American students to four countries, 21 cities, 45 communities, and performed for many audiences of over 1,000. We create friendships throughout the world. We have emerged as the first and only dance collective of university students at various competitive dance conservatories dedicated to creating community across international borders. In partnering with various groups in Central America, JUNTOS has introduced an innovative method in which participants establish, maintain and strengthen relationships through dance, both national and international. Simultaneously, the company encourages and initiates growth of individual skills that create leaders and persons dedicated to serving others. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to do more? You can also help by spreading the word – share this page on Facebook, Twitter, your blog, etc!

Check out our website! juntoscollective.org

Like our Facebook! www.facebook.com/juntoscollective

story:
Help us bring our concert to life!

The culminating project of the B.F.A. Dance degree at Western Michigan University is to completely choreograph, costume, publicize, and produce the Graduating Presentations Concert that will run from Thursday, April 14th to Sunday, April 17th on the 3rd floor of the Dorothy U. Dalton Center in Studio B. The seven of us will do everything from lighting, costuming, and choreographing our pieces to handling the administrative work that goes into budgeting and promoting a concert! 

Unfortunately, we cannot hold a show without the funds to do so. We need your help!

This project is more than simply an academic requirement. To us, this project defines who we currently are as artists as we prepare to enter the professional world. We have committed ourselves over the last four years to enhance every aspect of our dance knowledge from choreography and technique to history and kinesiology. Everything we have learned up to this point has contributed to our individual artistic identities, and we are thrilled to have the opportunity to collaborate on the production of this concert for our last feat at Western Michigan University. 

We have become more than classmates; We are each others' biggest sources of support and inspiration. With your financial help, we hope to spread the passion for dance that our camaraderie brings to this concert. Please consider contributing to the next step in our careers as developing artists-- we can't do it without your support! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot personally donate, please consider sharing our campaign through social media.

THANK YOU FROM YOUR 2016 GRADUATING BFAs, 
Jordan Colovos, Sam Crouch, Annie Franklin, Sarah Jones, Devon Lloyd, Carla O'Connor, and Sarah Mills

story:
Who We Are:

East West Players (EWP) is the nation’s premier Asian American theatre organization, producing artistic works and educational programs that foster dialogue exploring Asian Pacific experiences.

La Cage Aux Folles completes EWP's milestone 50th Anniversary Season.This is the last production to be directed by our visionary Producing Artistic Director Tim Dang as he prepares to step down this summer after leading East West Players for 23 years.

What We Need:

Your donation will help us to create a resounding theatrical experience! $9,000 will help us meet production costs including:

  • Materials to build dynamic sets and thrilling costumes featuring leather, feathers, and lots and lots of sequins!
  • Rehearsal time and fees, so we can pay our talented professional designers and spectacular cast of 15 singers, dancers and actors
  • Outreach: Working in association with the Los Angeles LGBT Center, we are offering a comprehensive internship to six  LGBT youth and giving them a chance to learn, grow , excel and even transform through gaining practical skills, work experience, and exposure to  the arts
  • Thanks to our Angel, Wendy Chang, Director of the Dwight Stuart Youth Fund, we will receive $8,900 in matching funds for La Cage Aux Folles if our goal is met and every contribution will be doubled!

What You Get:

Check out the full list of perks at the side of this page!

With your donation, we are offering shout outs, print recognition, free tickets, exclusive opportunities to meet and be photographed with the cast and director,  and a one-of-a-kind memorabilia from the show. 

Other Ways:

If you’re not able to make a donation – or even if you are, and you still want to do more - there are plenty of other ways you can support us!

  • Spread the word! Share this campaign with your family and friends, and tell them why East West Players and La Cage Aux Folles matter to you!
  • Follow us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram, and share our posts to help spread the word about La Cage Aux Folles
  • Volunteer! Sign up to usher and see the show for free
  • Come and see La Cage Aux Folles! (buy tickets here!)

Special thanks to Charles Uy for shooting and editing our video.

story:
about poptart!

POPTART!  is a new play written by Krystle Phelps with original music by James Parenti, Krystle Phelps, and Patricia Phelps.  Produced by Girl Just Died and directed by Gwenevere Sisco, this piece features a rising pop star with a major chip on her shoulder, a long-suffering personal assistant, and a washed up songwriter looking for a paycheck.  Exploring themes of gender, race, and all things celebrity, POPTART!  deals with wanting to be heard ... even if you have nothing to say.

The play will run as a limited engagement this upcoming December 2 through December 5, 2015 at TADA! Theatre and we need your help!

CAST:
Monique St. Cyr as Monique
Allison Strickland* as Anna
James Parenti as James

* These Actors are appearing courtesy of Actors’ Equity Association. 

CHECK OUT OUR HEROINE'S NEW MUSIC VIDEO, "ALL OVER TOWN."


Song by James Parenti, Krystle Phelps, and Trish Phelps.  Vocals by Monique St. Cyr and music arrangement by James Parenti.  Directed by Gwenevere Sisco, cinematography by Trish Phelps, edited by Krystle Phelps and James Parenti.  Thanks to Billy Conahan, Jamal Crowelle, Maxwell Korn, Rob Santos, Brian Henderson, and Timothy Goodwin! 

our budget

For transparency, you'll find laid out below everything that's going into our budget for this production. 

$3,000.00 (actors and crew)
 $1,500.00 (6 days of theatre space)
 $1,500.00 (1 month of rehearsal space)
 $1,000.00 (set, lighting, costuming)
___________________________
$7,000.00 (total)



the perks

First and foremost, anyone that contributes towards POPTART!  will be featured and thanked in our program.  There are levels!

  • $1 - $99: You will be listed as Gold Record donor in our program.
  • $100 - $499: You will be listed as a Platinum Record donor in our program.
  • $500 and up: You will be listed as a Diamond Record donor in our program.
We've also dreamed up creative perks to thank you for helping us bring this production to the stage, which you can find to the right.

It doesn't end there! 

The first 2 people to donate $25 will also receive a $10 Starbucks gift card.  Caffeinate 1.5 times on us!

The first 5 people to donate $50 or more will also receive a $25 gift card to the Olive Garden.  Classily eat unlimited soup, salad, and breadsticks on us!


a note from the playwright

Monique is angry.  She’s sharp-witted, vindictive, and obsessed with her own celebrity. 

And you, and you, and you, you’re gonna love her...

I set out on the journey of writing this play to create a character lacking any traditional saving grace.  A brutally ambitious woman who isn’t secretly soft.  An artist who isn’t talented beyond measure.  A shitty daughter, friend, lover—you name the role and she’s sure to suck at it.

I wanted to write about a pop star.  What you see is what you get, but what you see in POPTART!  is in bright, neon, 3D.  Monique is no one’s sidekick, self-insert, or villain.  She just is.  

And that’s enough.

I cannot wait to share her story with you.

- Krystle



about girl just died

GIRL JUST DIED is a theatre production company based in NYC that is dedicated to bringing to life new, exciting, and honest work that heavily features a variety of voices.  Our creative spirit was kindled by working with Dare Lab in April 2014 to produce May Violets Spring.  What a rush to explore the inner world of Ophelia, a female character whose death most know intimately but of whose life and motivations we know almost nothing.  It's disheartening to watch voices be silenced in stories of the past, but it's even more aggravating to see theatre in a present that often manages to be even less progressive.  We want nothing more than to be part of the ongoing movement to change that standard.  Founded by James Parenti and Krystle Phelps in 2015, we're off to a running start this year with POPTART!




other ways to help get this show on the road

Spread the word!  Also have a show opening in the first week of December 2015 that you'd like to advertise in our program?  Let's swap!

story:
What is Pandora’s Circus?

Do you think you’ve heard the story…the whole story? What happens after the box is opened?

Pandora’s Circus is a Cirque Style Theater show about Pandora, who opens the box and lets all of the vengeful spirits into the world. They drag her to the Underworld, but not before hope floats as a red balloon out of the box.

Pandora finds herself in a world of never-ending night full of strange characters that seem to ignore the rules and gravity and physical limitations. Some Underworld creatures aid her in her quest to return to the world of light and others seek to do her harm. In order to return, she must overcome her fears and go through the trials she find in there.

Pandora’s Circus will spark the belief that anything is possible. There’s nothing like the thrill of live aerialists on stage twisting into fabric and dropping to inches above the ground, graceful acrobatic dances, and so much more. The show tells a timeless story in a way that could never be conveyed with words. You will be whisked away on a magical journey without ever leaving your seat.

We can’t do this without you!

It’s been a dream of mine to put together a theater show that was not only innovative and amazing, but inspiring and emotionally touching. Only through your help will this dream become a reality.

We need funds for costumes, set pieces, and if we are receive enough funding, to add in a lift system that will make our aerial performers really fly. $3,000 is the goal that would be the bear minimum to get the show off the ground. Ideally we’ll make it to $5,000 and that’s when we can add all the bells and whistles to the show!

Check out more information at www.PandorasCircus.com.

For those of you who share this page on social media, or anywhere else, you receive our heartfelt thank you and will get a warm fuzzy feeling inside.

story:
This August - the Exquisite Corpse Company is launching ODD.A.SEE: an ambitious retelling of Homer's classic about how the memories of violence haunt us and how we struggle to find the courage to go home. It is an entirely new work, which includes original music, installation art, and words in our most monumental collaboration as a company yet:

  • Four bands in residency will craft original music and help create a show that changes every performance. 
  • Five installation artists will mold enchanting new worlds in each room of the 4,500 square foot labyrinthine space. 
  • Ten ferociously talented performers will guide the audience through the story with dance, spoken text, and song. 
  • And all of this will take place in the abandoned hospital ward of Arts@Renaissance in the heart of Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

 We are a month away from opening, and are spending every moment rehearsing, designing, building and dreaming. 

Our Story...

The Exquisite Corpse Company LLC is a Brooklyn based integrated performance art company that develops new work borne of collaboration between artists of all mediums. In doing so, we create a transformative, immersive event wherein theater, film, visual installation, music, and dance collide, repel, and interweave.

This is our second year as a company. In our first year, we mounted the original production Below by Tess Howsam in the New York International Fringe Festival, and were one of nineteen chosen out of 187 plays to extend our run in the Encore! series. 

Above all, we believe in creating a community of young artists in New York who inspire and create together, and who forward our mission of making theater approachable and newly relevant to everyone.

Why We Need Your Help!

Expenses are starting to pile up, and our company fund is starting to run dry. In order to make ODD.A.SEE a reality, we need to raise $15,000.

Why so much money, you ask? 

Here is a rough breakdown:

$7100 for the space

$1500 for lighting equipment

$1700 for sound rental

$2600 for set and costume pieces

$500 for stage management equipment

$200 for advertising material

$250 for remaining rehearsal time

$75 for storage space rental

$300 for transportation costs

$500 for liability insurance

If we can raise more, it will go towards: enlarging the fund for set pieces, costumes, and equipment; extending our rental of the storage space; subsidizing our other business costs and membership fees (legal and accounting fees for our new LLC); and beefing up our fund for future productions.

Not to mention: Everything you donate is tax deductible!! Not only is that good news for your taxes, but it means that we have an external organization providing intense oversight of how every dollar is spent. In other words - you can be sure that every dollar you donate will be put to good use for the company.

How You Can Help

Every little bit helps, and we can't do this without you! Please consider donating whatever you can.

As thanks for your donation, you'll get one of these super awesome gifts (shown on the right) from our creative team.

We will build Odd.A.See from your generosity, and are extraordinarily grateful for any contribution you can make.

 

Other Ways to Help

Come see ODD.A.SEE this August and spread the word! 

Share this campaign with your family and friends on Facebook, Twitter or wherever else you make yourself known. 

We are so grateful for any and all help we can get, so thank you in advance for your generous support!

Find us on Facebook, twitter, and Instagram!

 

To You

We are supremely confident in the merits of this project, and we have put together an incredible team of collaborators-- actors, designers, musicians and crew. We know this is an ambitious undertaking but we are energized by the challenges, and excited to share this brilliant play with YOU!

 

Love and thanks from the Core Corpses,

Tess Howsam, Dana Steinhoff, Blaire O'Leary, Emma Walton, Sarah Gosses, Alejandra Lopez, Karyn Joy DeYoung, Nicole Davis, Laura Heckel, and Blake Bishton

 

...and the cast, writers, and artists of ODD.A.SEE!

Katie Medved, Laura Rose Zlatos, Lavinia Roberts, Alex Pucci, Alexandra Hellquist, Blake Bishton, Brendan Sokler, Brighid Greene, Caitlin Goldie, Katrina Day, Lee Collins, Matthew Minnicino, Rachel Long, the Harmonica Lewinskies, Roberto Bettega, the Imaginary Menagerie, Kate Douglas, the Endmen, Morgana Skelton, Alex Diamond, Casandra Rodriguez, Maura Bess McGill, Clem von Holstein, Jess T Chiang, and Ben Wendel

$500 for stage management equipment
$200 for advertising material
$250 for remaining rehearsal time
$75 for storage space rental
$300 for transportation costs
$500 for liability insurance
If we can raise more, it will go towards: enlarging the fund for set pieces, costumes, and equipment; extending our rental of the storage space; subsidizing our other business costs and membership fees (legal and accounting fees for our new LLC); and beefing up our fund for future productions.
Not to mention: Everything you donate is tax deductible!! Not only is that good news for your taxes, but it means that we have an external organization providing intense oversight of how every dollar is spent. In other words - you can be sure that every dollar you donate will be put to good use for the company.
How You Can Help
Every little bit helps, and we can't do this without you! Please consider donating whatever you can.
As thanks for your donation, you'll get one of these super awesome gifts (shown on the right) from our creative team.
We will build Odd.A.See from your generosity, and are extraordinarily grateful for any contribution you can make.
 
Other Ways to Help
Come see ODD.A.SEE this August and spread the word! 
Share this campaign with your family and friends on Facebook, Twitter or wherever else you make yourself known. 
We are so grateful for any and all help we can get, so thank you in advance for your generous support!
Find us on Facebook, twitter, and Instagram!
 
To You
We are supremely confident in the merits of this project, and we have put together an incredible team of collaborators-- actors, designers, musicians and crew. We know this is an ambitious undertaking but we are energized by the challenges, and excited to share this brilliant play with YOU!
 
Love and thanks from the Core Corpses,
Tess Howsam, Dana Steinhoff, Blaire O'Leary, Emma Walton, Sarah Gosses, Alejandra Lopez, Karyn Joy DeYoung, Nicole Davis, Laura Heckel, and Blake Bishton
 
...and the cast, writers, and artists of ODD.A.SEE!
Katie Medved, Laura Rose Zlatos, Lavinia Roberts, Alex Pucci, Alexandra Hellquist, Blake Bishton, Brendan Sokler, Brighid Greene, Caitlin Goldie, Katrina Day, Lee Collins, Matthew Minnicino, Rachel Long, the Harmonica Lewinskies, Roberto Bettega, the Imaginary Menagerie, Kate Douglas, the Endmen, Morgana Skelton, Alex Diamond, Casandra Rodriguez, Maura Bess McGill, Clem von Holstein, Jess T Chiang, and Ben Wendel

story:
Short Summary

"We have always felt that something is wrong,
The backs of our minds have been awhir.
Everything is infected by it,
Everybody knows it,
Everybody is possessed by wondering about it,
At least sometimes.

What is it?
What is wrong?
What is something?
What is is?
We don't know.
We haven't got a clue."

Thus begins Something Is Wrong, written and directed by William Rasitsan-Powell, designed by Beata Rasitsan-Powell, and produced by the fledgling Naught, A Theatre Company. We begin with difficult questions that stare us in the face and refuse to move. These are the questions that lie underneath, that hide in the shadows, that flit around our heads in the night. 

The play draws influence from the most ancient form of theatre: Greek Tragedy. We begin with a Chorus of men and women who are posessed and infected by these questions. They fight to keep their eyes open, to stare the questions in the face, but it proves to be too much for them:

"We are tired,
We have bloodied our fists on the iron door,
We have felt the ground slowly crumble beneath our feet.
We have had enough of this."

The Chorus decides that they must have been mistaken: that nothing is wrong. That they should go home and stop worrying. All of them except one, that is: Thespis, who refuses to admit that nothing is wrong. It is Thespis' determination to continue searching for answers that propels the play.

On the journey, we meet Daemon, the Chorus' protector against the pesky Thespis, and Iris, a magnetic spirit who is intrigued and mystified by the whole situation. We travel into the consuming void, to a cottage, through the desert, and to a Chinese tea-house in the search for what, if anything, is wrong, and what, if anything, we can do.

The piece integrates poetic text, dance, original music and song to create and guide us through its mysterious setting. And yes, there will be blood. 

“How hard is it, when everything encourages us to sleep, though we may look about us with conscious, clinging eyes, to wake and yet look about us as in a dream, with eyes that no longer know their function and whose gaze is turned inward.”

-Antonin Artaud, The Theatre and Its Double

At Naught, A Theatre Company, we insist that it is the work of the theatre to open these two sets of eyes, to look both inward and outward in search of answers. Something Is Wrong strives to do this. Will you help us???

What We Need & What You Get

We need $2000 in order to make this production come together. This means:

  • Building the set
  • Making the costumes
  • Renting the theatre
  • Paying for rehearsal space

We also have some amazing perks available for all you who contribute. They are listed on the right side of the page. For instance: a $75 donation gets you a beautiful picture from the production signed by the entire cast and crew!

The Impact

Theatre is about asking questions. Asking the most difficult questions that you can imagine, an staring them directly in the face as they torture and eat away at you. We ask these questions because it makes life a more visceral, more immediate experience. We ask these questions because we are not satisfied with half-living. We ask these questions because we want you to ask them too. We want you to come with us, to have the power to look into the face of the void, to trust that it will not destroy us if we hold onto each other.

We believe that theatre is a vehicle of change. And the world needs change.

Other Ways To Help

We understand that not everybody can donate, but everybody can try and get the word out! You can share this page with anybody and everybody who you think may be interested in our mandate and our production.

And last, but definitely not least, you can come and see the show!

Showtimes are as follows: 

July 31, 2013 (Opening Night): 8pm
August 1, 2013: 8pm
August 2, 2013: 8pm
August 3, 2013 (Closing Night): Matinee at 2pm and evening show at 8pm

The location is the Pia Bouman School for Ballet and Creative Movement at 6 Noble St., Toronto, ON. The closest major intersection is Queen St. W. and Dufferin St.

Reserve your tickets now by emailing naughttheatre@gmail.com and pick them up at the box office!

Hope to see you there!

 

Naught, A Theatre Company

story:
Consuming Kinetics Dance Company has been serving the St. Louis community for over three years. CKDC started as a performance ensemble and quickly grew to a large organization of many artists with shared interests. In order to fund our projects and aspirations, CKDC began offering dance classes as an independent group in August of 2012. With the efforts and support of people like you we were able to find an awesome studio to call home. In our new studio, CKDC's classes are growing but we still can't raise enough money to rent a theater to perform our works. We are proud to show off our new home, Central Studio, so we are hosting a fall concert in our studio but we have limited seating available and we hope to perform in a space that can accommodate a much larger audience by next season.
 
With the approval of our 501(c)3, CKDC will be able to solicit contributions from a number of area businesses, organizations and individuals. We need your help to raise the initial funds required for filing for this non-profit status with the IRS.
 
With your support, CKDC will raise enough funds to cover the cost of the IRS's filing fee, $850 as well as help us recover the $125 we spent on this endeavor so far!
 
The Impact of obtaining our non-profit status doesn't end within our organization. Our main goal for obtaining our non profit is to ensure that we can always produce an annual concert in a reputable venue/theater. Our dance concerts always include live collaboration with visual artists and musicians. We hope to create jobs for artists and beautiful work for our audience.
 
CKDC currently offers classes to the community age 3 - adult in all levels of experience. We also work with other non profit organizations in the St. Louis area to help them grow or make contributions for a good cause. Last year we began a relationship with UrbanFuture, a St. Louis nonprofit, providing dance classes to inner city children as part of their in-school enrichment program. We are going to be in our third year of working with The University of Missouri - St. Louis in their Relay for Life efforts, this past winter we sponsored the Fun, Fit 5&5 and we are starting a new relationship with Venus Envy of St. Louis this fall as well as continuing other annual contributions and pursing other partnerships with local organizations.

If you can't help by contributing, please help us spread the word by posting our campaign on Facebook, Twitter or sharing with your friends who love art!

story:
MY JOURNEY:

It begins... as a dedication to personal healing. 

I am NOT willing to settle for a life of anxiety, isolation and fear.

I'm called to co-create Red Tent sacred women's space.  
We share, we hear, we hold, we blossom.
My heart begins to open.
I gain tools for compassionate self-honesty.  
I gain courage to inhabit my body and every dark and light feeling with more boldness and kindness. 

My gifts are nurtured. 
I begin to trust what I know.
 I uncover inherited gifts of healing through drum, movement, story, song.
It's useful for others. 

  

I continue to bring healing to deeper layers of my own fear, anger, and sorrow that surface.

I discover these living stories trace back to my ancestors.  
I heal for them too.

                                   

AND NOW, I give thanks for my precious patchwork soul; for the intimacy I experience; and for my wild, creative passion....

...and I ask my Creator,

                  "What will you have me do now?" 

                                       

BIT BY A SPIDER...AND I SAID YES!

 My answer was the work of Alessandra Belloni and her dedication to the ancient rhythmic healing traditions, known today as Tarantella, of Southern Italy (www.alessandrabelloni.com) . This rhythmic healing tradition has been used in Italy and the Mediterranean for centuries to cure people (especially women), who suffered a form of mental depression known as 'tarantismo', attributed to the mythical bite of the tarantula. “Tarantismo” may be defined as depression, hysteria, and aggression resulting from abuse and societal oppression.
When a woman was identified as being bitten, they would call in the musicians to play for her, as she wildy moved her body, until the woman was healed through this entrancing rhythm. 

Through a series of synchronistic events, I find myself having lunch with Alessandra, and she asks me to assist with her trip to Tuscany this summer and begin my apprenticeship. 

I see two tarantulas on the ground in the basement garage. They begin to fight. One of them turns white. I walk out the door. Looks dangerous. The white one follows me and bites my left hand.

The hand I play the tamburello with, for healing, for liberation. 

 The healing work I have been doing was born out of my own creative, self-healing will. It is a good foundation. Now it is time for me to learn from the accumulated wisdom of a lineage, my Southern Italian ancestral lineage. 

 

                                           

I am fundraising so I may travel to the land of my ancestors and assist at Alessandra's 2013 Rhythm is the Cure Healing Drum and Dance intensive in Berberino, Italy on August 17-27. 

This is the initiation of my apprenticeship.

FUNDING DETAILS

Passport:$135 - ***PAID***

Tuition: $400 - ***PAID***

Airfare: $1200 - ***ALREADY BORROWED***

Ground Travel: $500

Housing and Food in Villa for week: $700

TOTAL NEED BY AUGUST 10th: $1200

 

WHAT I WILL DO WITH THIS TRAINING?

  1. I will continue my path of "healer heal thyself", practicing what I preach. 
  2. I will offer this work for those who ask. Focusing on liberating women and young girls from the shackles of generations of repression,  oppression, and trauma from abuse, by reconnecting them to the ecstatic, wildness in their bodies that will restore their weary souls. 
  3. I will continue my dedication to my local community - facilitating bi-monthly community healing rhythm and movement practices. 
  4.  I may feel called to expand and share this work in my region. 
  5. I will build up to organizing 4 annual, seasonal healing and expressive art ceremonial celebrations!
  6. I will eventually teach these rhythm and movement techniques to those behind me that wish to serve with them in their healing capacities. 

                          

                            

MY BACKGROUND:

  • BA in Cultural Anthrology and Spanish minor
  • Certified as a Holistic Health Coach.
  • 8 years of helping my husband grow organic produce and making herbal crafts for local families.
  • 6 years of co-creating and facilitating bi-monthly women's sacred community space.
  • 5 years of being a mother to Gabriel
  • 4 years of facilitating a dynamic embodiment/ community ritual practice, I call THUJA.
  • 2 years of traveling and sharing my one woman show , Into the Dark Forest where I account my healing journey with song, story, and theatrical verse. 

 

The life force of our wild, ecstatic nature that dwells within is what will restore our inner and outer landscapes. These rhythms unleash that triumphant force - for healing, for liberation. 

May your giving cycle back to you in ten fold blessings!

story:
Short Summary

The main purpose of this project is to deepen my collaboration with a number of Multiple Sclerosis Societies in the South East and to explore the movement of people affected by MS.
My most recent choreographic work has evolved around my mother's diagnosis with MS - 'You Remind Me' deals with my grief after my mother's initial diagnosis, while '12 Months On' is a portrayal of life with the disease, trying to deal with it and moving on with life at the same time.
With this new project I would like to delve deeper into my work with the MS societies. Having already established a good working relationship with several of them through my Big Dance 2012 project 'Let's face the MS and dance' I would like to return to the studio with MS patients, this time with two perspectives:
1. Continue the work from 'Let's face the MS and dance' by working on some of the specific elements that MS patients struggle with: balance, co-ordination and memory and thus helping them cope with their diagnosis and improve their relationship with their body. The aim of the workshops is to help the MS patients engage with dance in an environment where they feel safe and comfortable as this can benefit them both physically and mentally, showing them that everybody can benefit from dance, regardless of abilities.
2. Research the MS patients as I work with them - looking at their movement, listening to their experiences, understanding their bodies - and take this back to the studio to develop new movement material derived from the workshops and create a new piece of work based on this material.
Furthermore, I hope that the strong connection between the workshops and the new piece will encourage attendance from MS patients and their families, providing not only a cultural day out but also a new perspective on their illness.

Key Facts about MS

  • More than 100,000 people in the UK have multiple sclerosis (MS)
  • More women then men are diagnosed with MS
  • Multiple sclerosis is not inherited, but family members do have a slightly higher risk of developing MS 
  • It is usually diagnosed when people are in their 20s and 30s
  • MS is a disease affecting the central nervous system (the brain and spinal cord)
  • Symptoms can come and go and can vary greatly in terms of severity
  • There may be periods of relapse of varying length and severity
  • Everyone's MS is different
  • MS is not a fatal condition
  • It is neither infectious nor contagious
  • Most people diagnosed with MS will not need to use a wheelchair on a regular basis
  • At present, there is no cure for MS but this certainly doesn't mean that the symptoms of MS cannot be treated

What We Need.... 

We need to be able to raise funds to ensure that we deliver high quality workshops. Working in partnership with local MS therapy centres and branches, we must ensure the work being delivered is of benefit to all participants.

By reaching our goals I will be able to ensure that dancers are paid for their development of this work, and invite industry professionals down to our work-in-progress sharing to get the work programmed into venues to continue raising awareness of MS and the effects it has on people who are diagnosed with the disease, their family and friends.

& What You Get....

By donating to this casue, you will be contributing to the awareness raising of MS.
You will be enabling people with MS to engage in movement classes which can have a positive effect on balance and co-ordination, which in turn aids everyday living. Things we take for granted like making a cup of coffee or getting into the bath can be an exhausting experience for some people with MS, and these classes aim to give people the ability to listen to their bodies; to be able to stand up if they have taken a fall; to be able to improve co-ordination to help increase their quality of life.

The Impact

Having already produced 2 projects with people with MS, I am keen to further develop these projects (this time with funding) to ensure I can work with high quality artists who understand the importance of being able to interpret the movement material as well as the emotions of people with MS. Sensitivity to the nature of this project is key, whilst ensuring we can raise awareness of MS and the effects it has on people. We envisage that the project can develop into a touring piece of dance to be seen around the country by a large number of people. This engagement and awareness raising is fundamental in this project.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people might not be able to contribute money, but there are many other ways you can get involved in this project. You might want to dedicate some time, material or even knowledge to developing this project and helping to raise awareness about MS and th effects it has on people with it, and also their famillies.
You might also help us spread the word by sharing on twitter, facebook, a blog or website.
Maybe you know someone with MS who would like to get involved in dance classes but isn't sure how to take the first step... Well, pass on the information and they can get in touch with us, even if its just for an informal chat about the project and what we hope to achieve.

& What You Get....
By donating to this casue, you will be contributing to the awareness raising of MS.You will be enabling people with MS to engage in movement classes which can have a positive effect on balance and co-ordination, which in turn aids everyday living. Things we take for granted like making a cup of coffee or getting into the bath can be an exhausting experience for some people with MS, and these classes aim to give people the ability to listen to their bodies; to be able to stand up if they have taken a fall; to be able to improve co-ordination to help increase their quality of life.


The Impact
Having already produced 2 projects with people with MS, I am keen to further develop these projects (this time with funding) to ensure I can work with high quality artists who understand the importance of being able to interpret the movement material as well as the emotions of people with MS. Sensitivity to the nature of this project is key, whilst ensuring we can raise awareness of MS and the effects it has on people. We envisage that the project can develop into a touring piece of dance to be seen around the country by a large number of people. This engagement and awareness raising is fundamental in this project.


Other Ways You Can Help
Some people might not be able to contribute money, but there are many other ways you can get involved in this project. You might want to dedicate some time, material or even knowledge to developing this project and helping to raise awareness about MS and th effects it has on people with it, and also their famillies.You might also help us spread the word by sharing on twitter, facebook, a blog or website.Maybe you know someone with MS who would like to get involved in dance classes but isn't sure how to take the first step... Well, pass on the information and they can get in touch with us, even if its just for an informal chat about the project and what we hope to achieve.

story:
THE QUESTION:

What makes a "classic"?

This fall, The Brewing Dept. is tackling two projects with Shakespeare at their core. Though they approach their source texts in radically different ways, these projects share a common goal: changing how we watch, perform, and think about the classics.

We're half way through our work this fall, and we can't wait to share what's next - find out more below!


WHAT WE'VE DONE:

(Director's Notes on) Othello

Director Tom Kapusta needed you to help him edit the text of Othello for a contemporary production of Shakespeare's great tragedy. Through a series of blog posts on The Brewing Dept.'s website, Tom shared his ideas on Othello, his process for creating a performance, and his reasoning behind how he edited the text.  It's not too late to join in the conversation by visiting us here on our blog - and definitely comment to let him know what you think!

The project culminated in a public reading with a full cast on October 26th at The Alchemical Theatre Laboratory.  We were thrilled so many of you could come, and we look forward to the future of the project with TBD!


WHAT'S STILL TO COME:

HamletGhosts

As the second half of TBD's fall programming, we're excited to present HamletGhosts, an electrifying blend of pop culture and Shakespeare that tears apart Hamlet, text, and theater itself.

Through a series of vignettes, the cast of HamletGhosts takes a look at Shakespeare’s Hamlet and then makes something else.  Director Cody Holliday Haefner’s radical vision examines the legacy of Shakespeare in our society; mixing Hamlet with Lady Gaga, Yahoo answers, and personal narratives in a piece that forces the audience to question their own complicity in the acts of madness and violence played out in front of them.  

The performance will take place on November 20th at Dixon Place, but you can get a look at the rehearsals through our HamletGhosts web series (which you can be a part of - check out our perks!) HERE!


WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP:

We're absolutely thrilled to have been able to cover the costs of mounting our reading of Othello last month - but we're only half way done!  Help us enable these artists and their unique visions by donating to help cover basic consts like:

  • Rehearsal Space
  • Performance Venues
  • Props and Costumes
As an added benefit, your donations help us continue our work as a company.  The Brewing Dept. annually provides its artists with a general liability policy and volunteer accident insurance, protecting them and giving them access to performance and rehearsal spaces they might not have otherwise!  This is on top of other yearly expenses The Brewing Dept. incurs, such as:
    • Website hosting fees
    • Marketing and publicity materials
    • Even non-profit status for our fundraising efforts!


      HOW ELSE YOU CAN HELP US:

      Come see the shows!

      The Othello reading was a huge success! Thank you all for your attendance.

      HamletGhosts will be presented at Dixon Place on November 20th; you can purchase your $12 ADVANCE TICKETS HERE!

story:
The Dead man's carnival is more than an evenings entertainment. We are a community focal point that creates a time and place for the impossible to breath. The show has become a cornerstone of Milwaukee's counter culture arts scene. 

With your help we will be able to continue to produce our monthly "First Friday Variety Shows" at the Historic Miramar Theater. We would also like to expand our pool of available talent by touring surrounding Mid-west cities. Playing one part cultural ambassadors as well as reaching out for recruitment scouting. 

We are one of the last real deal Live Music Vaudeville Shows in the country. Over the last couple years we have featured many top national variety acts, world champions, as well as up and coming local talent.

story:
Here's the story.

**please see updates on our indiegogo goal below!**

My name is Paton Ashbrook and I'm an actor training at The Juilliard School in NYC.

I first encountered The Winstons last summer at the Hangar Theatre in Ithaca, NY. Andrea Ciannavei, a graduate from Juilliard’s playwriting program, was commissioned to write a new play for 5 very specific actors in the company, myself included, for the Hangar Pilot Reading Series. Amazingly, Andrea crafted an extraordinary piece of political theatre in mere weeks that involves five women not just talking about what they want, but actually making it happen right then and there in front of you. Under Louisa Proske's direction, I was blown away, as was the audience that received the reading; there were reactions from utter shock all the way to a determination for change; some people were even horrified at their own unrealized and surprisingly sexist responses to five women being the driving force of this piece.

(from L-R: Andrea Ciannavei, Olivia Washinging, Kullan Sinclair Edberg, Paton Ashbrook, Jeena Yi, Alanna Smith at the Hanger Theatre, NY).

While extremely political, this piece also has five women not complaining about their boyfriends or their pants size; instead, they are doing some very compelling, active, and alarming things all by themselves… something the commercial world rarely sees.

Cut to: Last fall at Juilliard. I performed a monologue from The Winstons for the Drama Division and got even more positive responses and questions about how one could find out more about the play. I decided then and there that I wanted to produce a workshop of this play at Juilliard as a Student Initiated Project.

With Louisa and Andrea on board, and myself acting as producer and actor, I'm also lucky to be working with an incredibly talented mix of actors trained at Juilliard and Columbia: Jeena Yi, Carolyn Michelle, Gwen Ellis, and Sarah Annette Hunt.

I believe in this play and it's message and want to help develop it anyway I can. This play has the potential to enrich the community as a whole, empower women, and raise questions about where we want to be headed as citizens in this country and the world. 

The workshop is the first step.

Now we just need the funds to make it happen.

What We Need & What You Get

Photography by Raffe Lazarian www.raffephoto.us  https://www.facebook.com/raffe.lazarian

***

We've reached our goal!!! Thank you so much to everyone donating and spreading the word!

Whatever funds we continue to receive will go to increasing our production value (more necessary costumes and props, yay!) and hopefully I'll be able to provide "thank you" stipends to my artistic team! 

***

As a student buried in a mountain of debt, I cannot afford to pay out of pocket for this production so we need your help!

To produce this workshop we need:

  • Basic lighting equipment rented from Juilliard: $ 210
  • Props: $200
  • Costumes: $50
  • Marketing (flyers, programs, indiegogo site fees): $190
  • Script printing (vital, as there will be rewrites): $100
  • Misc. (water, talkback catering, etc): $250

Total basic estimated budget: $1000

This workshop has to happen whether we meet our goal on this site or not! All funds received will go straight to the production which starts rehearsals August 25th and has two performances September 14th, 2014.

The Impact

Photography by Raffe Lazarian www.raffephoto.us  https://www.facebook.com/raffe.lazarian

There is a change happening in the world. The demand for respect and equality that Americans have been fighting for years and years is gaining more voices. Sometimes though, it doesn't seem like it’s enough. There are days where it’s utterly terrifying being a woman in this world, even in this country. Not only women’s rights, but the right to a middle class, the right to earn a fair wage and not live in a hierarchical class system seems like it’s under attack. The things this country fought to free itself from at its inception have been creeping back in, now even more aggressively. Women have less access to safe healthcare, police brutalize Occupy Wall Street protesters in the middle of the night, and suddenly a person needs two full time jobs to get by.

“We are the movers and shakers/ Of the world forever, it seems.”

As a woman and as an American that has been fortunate enough to have access to a lot of opportunities, I want to take advantage of what’s been given to me and contribute what I can. After all, it’s an artist’s responsibility to see the community as it is, and explore the insides. 

How can we help?

We can volunteer, we can spread the word, we can vote, and we can make waves with art.

Risks & Challenges

(Paton Ashbrook directing her short film, "In A Box")

While I have film production experience, I've never produced theatre before. There are many technicalities and methods that I'm stepping into for the first time and it's a little overwhelming.

Luckily I have amazing support from a team of fantastic, talented artists that are helping me every step of the way: Andrea Ciannavei, writer extraordinare, Louisa Proske who will be returning to direct, my fabulous cast of fierce females (alliteration!) from Juilliard and Columbia, The Juilliard School, and YOU!

Other Ways You Can Help

Photography by Raffe Lazarian www.raffephoto.us  https://www.facebook.com/raffe.lazarian

Times are tough financially-- (another reason we want to mount this production!)-- so we understand if you're unable to donate money at the moment...

What can you do instead? A lot!

SHARE!

Please share our campaign with your friends! Facebook, twitter, email, snailmail, whatever you want-- every little bit helps get us closer to our goal! 

Indiegogo has handy little share tools on this very page, please feel free to post them anywhere and everywhere!

Come see us!

Rehearsal for the Hangar Pilot Reading Series

If you're in NYC, you may be able to get a seat to see the show! 

Note: Our seating is extremely limited and not guaranteed. 

Please send ticket requests and/or feedback to: 

thewinstonsplay@gmail.com


THANK YOU!

story:
Help Canada's "national treasure" go international!

Canadian Contemporary Dance Theatre is an award-winning contemporary repertory company of dancers under 20 years of age. Hailed "a national treasure" by Toronto's Globe & Mail, CCDT members experience the life of professional dancers, including weekly classes in ballet and modern, extensive repertoire training and work with celebrated international choreographers in the creation of original dance works.

This summer, CCDT has the honour of being one of only 11 international groups selected to participate in the Commonwealth Youth Dance Festival 2014. The CYDF will celebrate the best of youth dance from across the Commonwealth from July 10-12, 2014, bringing dancers together for three days of workshops and performances in Glasgow, Scotland.

CCDT will be taking six dancers to perform one of the most thrilling dances in the company's repertoire: Colin Connor's ARENA.

In order to make this exciting tour a reality, we need your help!


What Your Help Means

An international tour has significant expenses, which have proven harder to come by in the changing economy and lack of arts funding in Canada.

Your contributions to this campaign will go toward:

- Round-trip airfare for 6 dancers and 3 directors ($1,314 per person)

- Festival room and board ($185 per person)

- Fulfillment of six exquisite young artists' dreams!

Our goal is to raise at least 50% of our total expenses, or $7,500. Please help us reach our target!


Crossing Oceans to Make Our Mark

After 12 years of national touring, the Commonwealth Youth Dance Festival 2014 offers CCDT its first unique international opportunity since Singapore and Malaysia in 2002.  CYDF is the dream platform for winning recognition in a new part of the globe, helping the company and its dancers to establish important international relationships for their future.  Your generous donations will put CCDT back on the map where it belongs – proudly representing Canada beyond our borders!

Colin Connor (ARENA choreographer, centre) rehearses the dancers at CCDT. Clockwise around the circle from left: Daniela Jezerinac, Nicholas Ruscica, Laura Carella, Calder White, Emily Barton, and Frances Samson.


It doesn't stop there... there are other ways to help!

Whether or not you can contribute, please help spread the word!

We all love our Internet -- Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, or other social media, and tell your friends and family!  Your donations are going towards a great cause, and we will be forever thankful!

story:
Dancing In Dublin: Modern Dance Summer Program

My name is Yvonne Winborne and I am a dance minor at the Pennsylvania State University.  I am excited to announce that I have been given the opportunity this summer to study dance in Dublin, Ireland while acquiring credits I need to complete my dance minor program!  The program is 4 weeks long from May 10-June 10, 2013. 

I have been dancing my whole life ever since I was a little girl.  Growing up I danced at my church and a small dance school in Philadelphia before I came to Penn State.  My freshman year I auditioned for the dance program and was accepted.  As my college career is slowing coming to an end (one more year to go!), I am trying to check different things off of my college bucket list.  One of my items on my list was to leave my mark at Penn State, and just this past year I believe that this has been accomplished by starting my own dance organization, AMBITIONS, my sophomore year with three of my fellow dancers and friends.  Over the past year we have grown tremendously and have received much support from the Penn State campus.  Also on my list is to go study abroad doing something I love, and with your help soon I'll be able to check this off my list too!

  

Why I Want to Go To Dublin: 

  • To gain a once-in-a-lifetime experience overseas

  • To develop a greater cultural appreciation for the different aspects of dance

  • To push myself as a dancer to think outside of all that I have learned thus far

 

What Is My Contribution Going To?

  • Penn State Tuition (6 credits): $6,604

  • Round Trip Airfare: $1,000

  • Meals: $340

  • Books: $50

  • Passport: $135

  • Personal Expenses: $500

  • Total=$8,629

I applied for two scholarships and unfortunately didn't receive either.  I am looking for other scholarships and grants, but most likely I will have to fundraise and take out loans.  Even if you can only contribute a small amount, every little bit helps!  Even if I don't reach my goal, any and all contributions are appreciated!!!  If you can contribute to my campaign, the preferred method of payment is PayPal. 

*Also, check out the perks on the right side of the page for your contributions!*

Why Should You Contribute?

Growing up, I was never really able to attend dance school or take serious lessons continuously because of financial hardships.  Nevertheless, I never gave up on my passion and this is why I jump at every opportunity I get to learn more and become a better dancer. Opportunities like this don't happen very often and I would hate to have to give up my spot because of my financial situation.  I believe that when you have a dream for your passion, you should never let anything stop you from believing.  No matter what my future holds, I will always pursue dance.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are able to make a contribution, THANK YOU SO MUCH! If not there are other ways you can help me this summer!

  • Share my campaign within your networks

  • Pray for my safety and traveling mercies

  • Pray that God will bless me with funds

 

*CHECK OUT SOME VIDEOS AND PICTURES OF MY DANCE JOURNEY IN COLLEGE IN MY GALLERY!

story:
Short Summary

Coming in May, 2014!

25,000 Posts considers the journey of one man over a 13-year period at the dawn of the 21st century. Set in Seattle, its central character works a day job as a real estate sign poster while dreaming of bigger things. Not immune to historic changes in the nature of work, family and real estate, our hero ventures forth, sometimes obliviously, sometimes inventively, in stubborn pursuit of his birthright: the American dream.

"25,000 Posts breaks new ground for me on a couple of fronts. It’s the first play I’ve written that is not primarily a work of fiction. It’s also my first foray into long form solo performance. Consisting of 39 short monologues, the play is partly memoir, partly training manual, and partly things that have been said to me over the past thirteen years. My goal is to present my audience with a puzzle to solve, and an engaging, truthful and fun evening of theatre."
- Jim Lapan, playwright and performer.

What We Need & What You Get

Our audience will enjoy a professional, one-of-a-kind, intimate theatre experience, and affordable ticket prices. Your support will take our production over the top!

$2,500 will cover our production team stipends.
$3,000 will cover our venue expenses.
$5,500 will do both!

We have a variety of fun, interactive perks, including signed posters, complimentary tickets, backstage passes and a command performance!

The Impact

25,000 Posts is the story of one American dream and its peculiar path through the beginning of the 21st century. Audiences will see themselves in this play, both individually and collectively. We want them to laugh, think, and enjoy a quality evening of live professional theatre for $20.

Other Ways You Can Help

Lots of ways to participate. Financial support is essential, but a plug or post on your social media of choice will  help us get there too.
story_txt:
Short SummaryComing in May, 2014!25,000 Posts considers
the journey of one man over a 13-year period at the dawn of the 21st
century. Set in Seattle, its central character works a day job as a real estate
sign poster while dreaming of bigger things. Not immune to historic changes in
the nature of work, family and real estate, our hero ventures forth, sometimes
obliviously, sometimes inventively, in stubborn pursuit of his birthright: the
American dream.
"25,000 Posts breaks new ground for me on a couple of fronts.  It’s the first play I’ve written that is not primarily
 a work of fiction. It’s also my first foray into long form solo 
performance. Consisting of 39 short monologues, the play is partly 
memoir, partly training manual, and partly things that have been said to
 me over the past thirteen years.  My goal is to present my audience 
with a puzzle to solve, and an engaging, truthful and fun evening of 
theatre." - Jim Lapan, playwright and performer.What We Need & What You GetOur audience will enjoy a professional, one-of-a-kind, intimate theatre experience, and affordable ticket prices. Your support will take our production over the top!$2,500 will cover our production team stipends.$3,000 will cover our venue expenses.$5,500 will do both!We have a variety of fun, interactive perks, including signed posters, complimentary tickets, backstage passes and a command performance!The Impact25,000 Posts is the story of one American dream and its peculiar path through the beginning of the 21st century. Audiences will see themselves in this play, both individually and collectively. We want them to laugh, think, and enjoy a quality evening of live professional theatre for $20.Other Ways You Can HelpLots of ways to participate. Financial support is essential, but a plug or post on your social media of choice will  help us get there too.

story:
Stone Soup Theatre Project is committed to building stronger communities and safer neighborhoods by providing access to affordable and relevant theatre, transferrable skills through theatre education, and by taking the stage onto the streets of North East Chicago.

Stone Soup is Growing!

2013 was an amazing year for Stone Soup Theatre Project.  We hit several service benchmarks that we are thrilled to share with you:

  • Our production of TAMER OR HORSES was Reader Recommended.
  • Through your donations we were able to keep ticket prices at $5 (instead of $40) to allow ALL members of our community to enjoy and grow through theatre.
  • Education Director, Hannah Gallagher, provided FREE weekly theatre classes to over 200 at risk Chicago youth!  Theatre education is vital because students gain increased confidence and transferable skills that carry them through school and into the workplace.
  • We united community members and non-profit organizations through weekly talkback sessions after performances of TAMER OF HORSES.
  • We continued to build partnerships with Ceasefire and ONE Northside through our outreach department.  

In 2014 we are:

  • Launching our very first independent Summer Camp - FREE of charge to our participants.
  • Debuting RUN CHRIS RUN, an original work based on the memoir of former Ceasefire Violence Interrupter, valued community member, and friend to Stone Soup, Chris Patterson.
  • Offering FREE community outreach performances during peak violence hours over the summer in order to provide community members and youth a constructive and safe place to be.
  • Obtaining our very own office and rehearsal space!
  • Continuing to aid ONE Northside through our participation in the BAN THE BOX campaign and other Anti Violence Coalition actions.
  • Changing the lives of people in our neighborhoods and continuing to impact Chicago as a force for change!

Stone Soup Theatre Project strongly believes in the power of community, which is why we turn to crowd-funding sources like Indiegogo.  Much like in the folk tale we're named after, we know that if everyone (ourselves included) pitches in what they can, amazing things can be accomplished.  

Help us build a stronger foundation in 2014 to enable the growth our communities are asking for.

Your donations to Stone Soup Theatre Project change lives. Thank you for all you do!

Where's all that money going?

Our goal will cover the entirety of what we need for 2014:

Run Chris Run--$8,550

  •  $700- Production (Royalties, Set, Lights, Sound)
  •  $5,400- Space (Hourly rate: $150)
  •  $1,250- Production Team (Designers, Director, Stage Manager)
  •  $1,200- Performance Stipends 

2014 Summer Class (20 Students) -- $3,250

  • $2,022: Teacher compensation (2 Instructors)
  • $420: Operational Costs (Background checks for teachers and space rental for 6 weeks)
  • $308: Material Costs (Scripts, journals, & camp shirts)
  • $500: Final Student Performance (Set and props, costumes, souvenir programs, & royalties)

    *If an additional $1,100 is raised we can take the students to a performance at Chicago Shakespeare (bus and admission to show) 

Why Stone Soup Theatre Project?

Theatre is transformative.  Participation in theatre and theatre education can offer increased confidence, better verbal and non-verbal communication skills, higher reading comprehension, and prepare children and adults to work as part of a team.  Theatre can bridge the gap between ideas and action, and help start communications on important issues.  Every founding member of Stone Soup Theatre Project knew firsthand the kind of positive impact theatre has on the lives of those involved; we'd lived it, and knew how important our art is.

However, in a city so full of amazing art, we saw a lack of connection between our neighborhoods and theatre.  Tickets were too expensive, and theatre was still presented to the artists and erudite (or specifically to children).  We recognized that a huge portion of our community who would benefit from participation in our art was being ignored.  So we started Stone Soup Theatre Project, not as a "community theatre," but "theatre FOR the community."

Other Ways You Can Help

Every bit helps. Please consider donating even a "latte" to Stone Soup, but if you're unable to, please:

  • Make some noise on behalf of Stone Soup Theatre Project!  Tweet about us! Tell your friends on Facebook! Let people know why YOU believe theatre is important for Chicago.  And use the hashtag #StoneSoup2014!
  • And of course, please use IndieGoGo's "share" tools to let others about our fundraising campaign!
  • Follow Stone Soup Theatre Project on Facebook and Twitter to keep in touch!
Thank you, thank you, THANK YOU!

story:
Matt Penny a.k.a. Frank, the Mind-reading Hotdog


Over the years I've been an actor, magician, musician, filmmaker, animator, stand-up comedian, playwright, director and part time Karma-sutra model.  I've performed as a living statue on the street and played in bands in pubs. 

Mainly though, I'm a cleaner!

In hindsight, I really feel that I tried to do too much.  I was Jack of all and master of none, so last year I decided to concentrate on the two things that have been constant all my life.  Magic and playing the piano.

As far as the piano goes I have been a pushing a piano around the Perth Cultural Centre for most of the year, sometimes playing soundtracks for Charlie Chaplin movies on the big screen and other times just playing because its a beautiful day.  I love it and I'm getting better and better at it.

Before arriving in Perth I was resident magician in TGI Fridays in Covent Garden and Planet Hollywood in Leicester Square.  As a child I always had a fascination in magic and performed shows for friends and family.

Since arriving in Perth I have performed magic at countless cooperate functions, restaurants and birthday parties but my preference is to create stage shows.  Here's the list so far...

The Magic Matt Show @ The Blue Room Theatre (2 week season)

Spirit Fingers @ The Blue Room Theatre (nominated peoples choice, Blue Room Awards). (3 week season).

Magic Matt and the Naked Assistant @ Fringe World

Magic Matt Fully Loaded @ Fringe World

Magic Matt's Magic Slam x 3 (a magic competition that always sells out)

In 2013 Micro Magic won 'Peoples Choice for multi media' at Fringe World.

In 2014 'Experiments in Mind-reading and Crowd Cohesion' was nominated for best Cabaret act at Fringe World. 


For the past couple of years I have been studying mind-reading.  At the last Perth Fringe World I performed my first mind-reading show ('Experiments in Mind-reading and Crowd Cohesion') and it was a great success.  Over 400 people came and watched, it was nominated for the best cabaret award and it really ignited my passion for magic again.  After 15 years of performing the same kind of stuff it was fantastic to be doing new stuff and having the audience actually gasp in amazement.

But, like all things, I needed an angle.   I had a few ideas and I asked friends (you know who you are) for more ideas and then one day it happened.  I hit the jackpot.

FRANK, THE MIND-READING HOTDOG

I've checked the internet.  There are no other mind-reading hotdogs in the world!!!  I've cornered the market. 

The mind-reading I've been studying is pretty phenomenal.  It often freaks me out as well as the audience.  The beauty of having a hot dog perform mentalism is that we can all have some fun with it!

Please help me take Frank on tour.  I've never asked for donations before and, hopefully, I'll never have to again.  I'm just looking for some starting capitol to get the ball rolling.  Once it's moving I'm confident that I can keep it moving. 

I'm hoping to take the show around the world next year but I will be starting with...

Perth Fringe World (Feb 2014) 

Auckland Fringe (Feb 2014)

Adelaide Fringe (March 2014)

Dunedin Fringe (March 2014)

Things that cost money are applications, air fares, accommodation and food.  This is what you would be contributing towards.

Hopefully I'll be able to bring Frank to a town near you and I actually thank you personally for your help.

So, if you enjoy a good show, please contribute, even the smallest donation helps.  Please share this campaign with your friends.  I'm sure they would love giving money to some random hotdog that they don't even know and can't even eat!


Remember, this show's a real wiener!!!

story:
Synopsis

On April 6, 1903, the city of Kishinev, the capital of the Russian province of Bessarabia erupted in violence. A horrific pogrom was organized, targeting the Jewish population of Kishinev. After three days of violence, 49 Jews were dead, 500 were wounded, 1300 homes and businesses were destroyed and 2000 families were left homeless.

The young Hebrew poet, Haim NahmanBialik went to Kishinev to talk to survivors and report on the pogrom. Bialik wrote one of his most famous poems, ‘In The City Of Slaughter’ in response to the Kishinev pogrom, using searing, powerful imagery to describe the horror that descended upon the Jewish residents of the city.

Eighty one years later, Delhi, the capital of the largest democracy in the world, India, was witness to a horror of even greater proportions. On October 31, 1984, Indira Gandhi, the Prime Minister of India was shot dead by her Sikh bodyguards. In retaliation, an orgy of murder, rape and arson was unleashed upon the Sikh residents of Delhi in which more than 3000 lost their lives.

The poem, ‘Kultar’s Mime’, written by a young Sikh poet, drew upon eyewitness accounts of the Delhi pogrom to describe the sufferings of the Sikhs of Delhi, through the eyes of a group of young survivors.

There are uncanny similarities between the Kishinev and Delhi pogroms. Both targeted minority communities with violence following libel, innuendo and propaganda, designed to stoke fear and hatred.

Kultar’s Mime, the play, synthesizes the sufferings of innocent victims of organized violence, separated by thousands of miles, numerous years and insurmountable differences of religion, language and culture. Drawing upon the raw imagery of both poems, it tells a story of human suffering and courage, reminding us that in the end all innocent victims are the same, regardless of which God they worship and what tongues they speak.

The play is set in New York City. A collective of young Jewish artists, influenced by Bialik’s ‘In The City of Slaughter’ decides to commemorate the Kishinev Pogrom by organizing an art exhibition in which they intend to display paintings about the pogrom accompanied by a reading of the poem. As they get together and revisit Bialik’s poem, it occurs to them that it would be very powerful to honor the suffering of the innocent victims of Kishinev by shining the spotlight on other similar instances of organized violence that the world has largely forgotten. They decide to focus on the anti-Sikh pogrom of 1984 in Delhi and make it the subject of their exhibition, using words from the poem to augment the impact of the paintings they have created about the Delhi pogrom.

The Sikh Research Institute has partnered with Sarbpreet Singh and J.Mehr Kaur, the playwrights to produce ‘Kultar’s Mime’, which will be staged in Boston in September 2014 and NYC, NJ, Ottawa and Toronto in October 2014. All performances will be open to the public and no admission will be charged. An ensemble cast of professional Boston area actors has been assembled and rehearsals have started. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to get the cast and crew to Delhi! You will get the satisfaction of knowing that your contribution has sent a group of young actors halfway across the world in an act of great compassion to tell the stories of young children who were brutalized thirty years ago. Strike a blow against the mindless violence that continues to be heaped on innocents all over the world by helping bring this story to life.

The Concept

Kultar’s Mime is an immersive theater experience, which draws upon poetry, painting and music to tell the story of four young children who were victims of the 1984 Delhi massacre.

The dialog draws heavily upon the poem of the same name, which was inspired by three works that appeared after the tragedy. The first was a booklet titled ‘Who are the Guilty’, a report commissioned by the People’s Union for Civil Liberties (PUCL), a civil rights organization in India, which painstakingly documented the terrible crimes that were committed in Delhi after the assassination of Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. The second work was an article by Madhu Kishwar titled ‘Gangster Rule’, published in the Indian progressive magazine Manushi, which intrepidly documented the events of 1984 in sharp contrast with most mainstream media in India, which had been tightly muzzled by the government. The third was a paper by anthropologist Dr.Veena Das, titled ‘Voices of Children’, published in Daedalus, which told the stories of young children whose lives had been devastated by the violence. The play draws upon several of these stories.

The backdrop for the storytelling in the play is provided by eight original paintings by Evanleigh Davis, which represent her response to the poem. The paintings depict the children whose stories are told as well as key incidents and persons who feature in the narrative.

Traditional melodies from both the Gurmat Sangeet and Indian Classical traditions are employed in support of the narrative.

The events of 1984 are relatively recent, but they have inspired an artistic response, mostly in the form of feature films and documentaries. Kultar’s Mime, the play, is one of the first attempts to tell the story of 1984 using theater as the medium.

The production team aspires to take the show to Delhi in October 2014 after staging it in various North American cities.

story:
National Asian Artists Project (NAAP) presents OLIVER!

Over the last 4 years NAAP has presented Oklahoma, Carousel and Hello Dolly as part of their Re-Discover Series. This year we move across the pond to the London of Charles Dickens with the production of OLIVER! 

The aim of NAAP is to showcase the work of Asian-American theatre artists through performance, outreach and educational programming. The Re-Discover series is one of the ways we fulfill this mission.

OLIVER! has a cast of 65 members made up of 20 children, 25 professional actors and 20 members of the NAAP Broadway Community Chorus. This production will be fully staged, with sets, props, costumes, the works! As a result it is monumental undertaking and we need your support to help make it a reality. 

We need your support!

We need to raise a minimum of $10,000 in order to help cover the expenses associated with this production such as the theatre and rehearsal space, costumes, set, production crew and of course our actors.

We are offering a variety of benefits based on the giving level. Some of these benefits include: 

  • Shout Out on NAAP's Facebook page
  • Shout Out on NAAP's Twitter account
  • Acknowledgement on the NAAP website
  • Signed OLIVER! postcard from Baayork Lee
  • Signed OLIVER! poster from Baayork Lee & cast
  • Tickets to Opening Night performance
  • Passes to the Opening Night Cast Party
  • and more ...

Your Support Matters

The work of NAAP is critical to the success of many Asian-American performers as it provided the opportunity for those performers to play roles that would otherwise not be available to them. This helps gives them the experience and confidence to succeed!

These projects are also critical to the success of our Educational Outreach programs. NAAP is able to introduce children to the world of musical theatre not only in a classroom setting but on the stage and in front of audiences. These opportunities have inspired many children to continue to pursue involvement in the performing arts. For others it has opened their eyes to a world that would otherwise gone unnoticed.

Please help us continue our pursuit to give a voice to our Asian-American community.

Tickets to Opening Night performance
Passes to the Opening Night Cast Party
and more ...
Your Support MattersThe work of NAAP is critical to the success of many Asian-American performers as it provided the opportunity for those performers to play roles that would otherwise not be available to them. This helps gives them the experience and confidence to succeed!These projects are also critical to the success of our Educational Outreach programs. NAAP is able to introduce children to the world of musical theatre not only in a classroom setting but on the stage and in front of audiences. These opportunities have inspired many children to continue to pursue involvement in the performing arts. For others it has opened their eyes to a world that would otherwise gone unnoticed.Please help us continue our pursuit to give a voice to our Asian-American community.

story:
Bravo tells the story of a troupe of misfit children who are taught to sing and dance so they may become “immaculate." Through it’s innovative score and compelling narrative, it captures the trials, joys, and sacrifices every child must go through during the struggle between becoming the person they want to be, or conforming to what society expects of them.


July 31st at 8pm

August 1 at 8pm 

August 2 at 2pm & 8pm

August 3 at 2pm & 6:30pm

For tickets, please visit: 
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/bravo-a-new-musical...
