Joignez-vous à huit danseurs exceptionnels et une équipe de concepteurs talentueux en soutenant la nouvelle création de Cas Public, Symphonie dramatique. 
SYMPHONIE DRAMATIQUE

Symphonie dramatique, nouvelle création d’Hélène Blackburn et Pierre Lecours, revisitera avec mordant le mythique couple de Roméo et Juliette. Cette adaptation, pensée pour tous les spectateurs, prendra prétexte de ce chef-d'œuvre romantique de William Shakespeare pour évoquer la séduction, le désir, le déchaînement des passions, la mort. Éloge de l’impossible et du combat qu’il faut livrer pour accomplir sa destinée, cette pièce puissante et sobre donnera un éclairage nouveau sur l'histoire d'amour la plus célèbre de tous les temps.

CAS PUBLIC
Fondée en 1989 par la chorégraphe Hélène Blackburn, Cas Public est une compagnie de danse contemporaine qui se distingue par une recherche novatrice ciblant différents publics. Chacune des créations qui ont ponctué l'évolution de Cas Public atteste la poursuite de l'excellence dans le renouvellement des codes gestuels. La réputation de la compagnie s’est construite grâce à la qualité exceptionnelle de ses œuvres reconnues pour leur fougue et leur prouesse et par une présence assidue sur la scène nationale et internationale.
Symphonie dramatique sera présenté en première au printemps 2014 au Québec et en France. Ce projet est un des plus ambitieux de la compagnie et votre appui fera toute la différence.

story:
Dear Friends and Supporters of Sylvani,
You have helped her come so far!  We are humbled and grateful for all you have given, because we simply could not do this alone. To give to finance a dream is to say you believe in something, in somebody, and we know that every single one of you has said that in your gift to Sylvani. So thank you!

We are getting ready now to ask for funds again. Sylvani will be 17 at the end of March, and this is probably her second to last summer doing intensives, while also preparing seriously to audition for either her first professional trainee, studio company, or apprentice position.

While she did audition for a few other intensives, she only seriously has considered returning to Joffrey or Oregon Ballet Theater, or, possibly, Texas Ballet Theater, and this is still a bit of a quandary.  There are good reasons for each of them, she has been to each of them, each is affiliated with a company she could potentially dance for one day, and each of them will give her some level of tuition scholarship/financial aid..meaning there is some level of interest in Sylvani.

Ultimately, Sylvani hopes to dance for the Joffrey Ballet as a professional, but at this point, we are looking at her best path to reach that goal. It may not be to return to Joffrey this summer for their intensive, but to instead go to the smaller OBT for their full 6 weeks, because she will be in their top level and receive more personal attention, while at Joffrey, she is likely to be in their second level in a larger class.

OBT has a second company, OBT2, that dancers must attend at least 4 weeks of the summer intensive to be considered for. The time overlap of the two programs does not allow Sylvani to do this while at the 5 week Joffrey program.

We are going to look into whether it is possible for her to change to Joffrey's later 3-week program, which would allow Sylvani to attend OBT's first 4 weeks, while still remaining under the eyes of Joffrey.
If this is not possible, then Sylvani has decided that going to OBT's full 6-week program and then returning to Joffrey a year from now, at age 18, when she will be in their top pre-professional level and eligible to become a Trainee, is her best option for training, cost, and her ultimate chance at a professional career in ballet.



This past summer at Joffrey was an incredible experience for her. Sylvani learned to be truly at home in the Big City--loving Chicago and everything about dancing in the Joffrey Tower. She learned so much! Then, because of a scholarship and a bit of other help, she was able to also attend the final two weeks of Oregon Ballet Theater's summer intensive in Portland, OR (two hours from home and with grandparents able to house and transport her). 
Sylvani saw immense improvement from both intensives, and was honored to dance the lead role in "Snow White" this fall over Thanksgiving weekend--requiring her to dance in every scene, partner with different "dwarves" as well as her "Prince", and truly take on a demanding acting as well as dance role. She danced every single day from right after school to after 8 pm, and on weekends sometimes both days too!  
It is now time to gear up for winter audition season, and it costs about $500 just to make the trip to Seattle for the audition weekend that includes Joffrey, as she is hoping to receive a scholarship. 

For Sylvani, Ballet is Love...

Sylvani has the chance to go to Joffrey Ballet School in Chicago - Help Realize Her Dreams!!!

Synopsis-

("Ballet Speak" for the Short Version)

Sylvani has been studying ballet since she was just over 3, and now, at age 16, is nearing her dream of one day dancing professionally!  Sylvani's favorite ballet company is The Joffrey Ballet...she was inspired by her main teacher and his friend, both of whom danced with Joffrey in the 70's. Sylvani fell in love with the company's combination of Contemporary and Classical ballet that speak to her sense of wanting to make change in the world with her art.

 

This summer, Sylvani has the chance to go to Chicago, for Joffrey's International Summer Dance Intensive--5 weeks of dancing every day in the Joffrey Tower, where the company dancers themselves will be taking class!  Joffrey accepts students by audition only. There were 14 audition sites all over the US as well as Paris and London. Sylvani and her friends traveled to Seattle for auditions held at Pacific Northwest Ballet.

Out of over 1000 students auditioning nationwide, Sylvani was one of 150 accepted into their top summer program, and also waitlisted for the year-round Joffrey Trainee program!  The summer program is taught by Joffrey School Artistic Directors Alexei Kremnev and Anna Reznik , and the Artistic Director of the Joffrey Ballet, Ashley Wheater, as well as a number of current dancers with the company and their regular teaching faculty.




Joffrey Ballet is where she wants most to go, though she auditioned for and was accepted to several programs.  Sylvani hopes to dance with Joffrey one day--and that day is not too far off!  Her main teachers and mentors here at Oregon Ballet Academy have told her since she loves Joffrey so much, this is the year she needs to go there, because at age 16, this helps her make the connection for when she is ready to become a Trainee in the next year or two.


For a young aspiring professional dancer, this is not only important training, but also a major opportunity!  We have everything we need to help her, except the money! 

  • The total costs of the Joffrey International Summer Dance Intensive are $7425.

  • With scholarships, savings, and air miles, we've gotten it down to $4675.  

  • It "takes a village" to raise a dancer! We're asking for $3675 here on Indiegogo, because Sylvani has applied for more scholarships, so we hope to have about $1000 from them. (UPDATE: Sylvani won the Anthony Quinn Foundation Scholarship, for high school students in the Arts needing pre-professional training while still in high school--out of over 550 applicants,they chose about 15 in all areas of the Arts. Sylvani was one of them, and won $800)


Sylvani has come so far since she began! 

Will you please Help Sylvani Dance to the Joffrey Ballet Company by contributing and sharing her campaign?


Read the Full Ballet...

(And see some video of Sylvani dancing)

...Here's Sylvani's Story:

"If someone asked me why I spend so many hours at the studio, working so hard to perfect what may seem like miniscule details, I would ask if they knew what it felt like to be in love.

I am committed to it for life. It gives me joy to dance, and, I want to use dance to convey messages to the world. People listen to art, it touches their souls and it changes people.  I love ballet, and even that doesn’t quite cover it. It is actually a part of me, and that is only cliché because so many people say it.  It is true. Some people dance to pray. For me, it is how I connect with whatever spiritual power there may be in the world: It’s how we connect with each other. When we dance together, all grudges and biases are forgotten. I say all this at risk of sounding a little bit crazy, but in contrast, it seems ridiculous that something like a lack of money could stand in the way of all this."

Ballet is Dreams

(What all this training has done so far..)

Visions of Sugarplums                                               

When Sylvani first saw "The Nutcracker" at 3 years old, she dreamed of being the Sugar Plum Fairy, and wanted to be a ballerina. Her grandparents generously offered to pay for ballet lessons, and off she went!  Sylvani got much of her dance talent from her Grandma Barbara, and much of her Romanian beauty from her Grandma Liliane. See more about them on Sylvani's earlier campaigns, Help Sylvani Dance, and Help Sylvani Dance 2.0.

But unlike most little ballerinas, who put away their tutus a few years later for other things, Sylvani kept dancing, working harder and harder for that dream. She kept growing into a stronger dancer, and her dream grew stronger too!

A year ago, at age 14, she got to put on the sparkling pink costume of the Sugar Plum Fairy as one of a triple cast of students to be chosen for this role! Her very first ballet dream had come true!

   

                     

This is Grandpa Ed, who was able to come see Sylvani dance one time...as the Sugar Plum Fairy. That was the last visit Sylvani had with her Grandpa Ed, as he passed away a year ago. April 17 was his "yarzheit" (one year passing). Grandpa Ed still is with Sylvani--he loved his "Short Stuff" and supported her dream.

Dreaming of Swans

In Sylvani's very first performance on stage, she was a Baby Swan.

  When Sylvani was 6, she told me she was going to dance Odette/Odile in "Swan Lake".There was something about how she said this that let me know, this was serious!  Sylvani KNEW what she wanted to do with her life and she was GOING to make it happen!


This past Thanksgiving, that HUGE dream came true!

Sylvani was chosen as one of a triple cast at Oregon Ballet Academy to dance the role of Odette/Odile, the complex double role traditionally danced by the same dancer in "Swan Lake", choreographed by John Grensback.

Here is a clip from the Prologue, where the maiden Odette is cursed by an evil sorcerer to be a swan, and where, as the Swan Queen, she meets and falls in love with Prince Seigfried . (danced by Nathan Rowell)

   

Here is a clip from the grand ball where Odile fools the Prince into believing she is Odette.
   


It was a thrill for Sylvani to be able to perform these roles at only 15, and taught her so much!

                  

As challenging as it is to believe in ballet dreams, with all the things that can get in the way...as hard as the work is...as many times one might simply take an easier road...Sylvani has never waivered, her dreams do seem to come true, and she is more determined than ever to continue on this path to wherever it takes her.

Now Sylvani Dreams of Joffrey Ballet...

The Artistic Director John Grensback, of Oregon Ballet Academy, where she trains nearly every day, and his friend Carl Corry, who is guest faculty once per year, danced with the Joffrey Ballet in the 70's and 80's. Together, they have inspired Sylvani, and she watches whatever she can of Joffrey on YouTube. 

There are so many ballet companies, and one never really knows where one might go. But Joffrey is the one she's talked of for years now.  She loves Joffrey's mix of Contemporary and Classical Ballet. She hopes to dance with Joffrey one day. Both of these former Joffrey dancers have said she has a chance of doing exactly that, and that THIS is the summer she should go there to begin to be seen by them!

Ballet is Training...Lots of Training.

Sylvani is turning 16 now. She has been studying ballet for 12 years. Every week during the school year, Sylvani takes class after school every day and on Saturdays 20 or more hours per week, in ballet technique, pointe, pas de deux, as well as tap, modern, jazz improv, Pilates and other dance forms.  She gets so much from Oregon Ballet Academy! And she manages to still get good grades, and have time with good friends. 

But serious ballet students also must use their summers wisely. While other high school students take summer vacations, those who want a professional ballet career go to summer intensives with ballet companies or major schools  

They improve their skills and strength, make contacts in the dance world, and learn more what it is to be a professional dancer. They then go back to the dorm and hang out with other young dancers all evening.  All week long, all day long, every day, several weeks. It's "full immersion" in a way that just isn't possible during the school year.


Last summer, thanks to help from so many of you, Sylvani went to Texas Ballet Theater in Dallas-Ft. Worth, for 5 weeks. There, she trained with former Houston Ballet Principals Kathryn Warakomsky and Tim O'Keefe,

             

and met famous Artistic Director and Choreographer, Ben Stevenson. These teachers are all former colleagues of John Grensback, Sylvani's Director and main ballet teacher in Oregon, who was Principal Dancer at Houston Ballet in the 80's. Other students from her home studio were there, and they all came back showing improvement and new bonds from having been immersed together. This bond and the intense work they did in Texas together helped them dance "Swan Lake" as choreographed by Mr. Grensback. We definitely saw Sylvani's growth when she returned from Texas!

   


Ballet is Auditions!

Every winter, ballet companies and pre-professional schools hold audition tours in major cities around the US and other countries. Since we live in a small city, we had to travel to Portland or Seattle for auditions, so we had to plan carefully which programs Sylvani would audition for.  Not everyone gets in.  Auditions are like taking a "master class" with a top professional or even the Artistic Director of a company or school. Because the student is also "auditioning the program" to see if it feels like a good fit, we tried to get Sylvani to as many auditions as possible,

Sylvani auditioned for many programs this year, including Joffrey Ballet Company, Bolshoi Ballet Academy, Ballet West, Oregon Ballet Theatre, University of North Carolina School of the Arts, Walnut Hill, Northwest Ballet Intensive, City Ballet of San Francisco,and Suzanne Farrell.  Some of these companies and programs offer year-round trainee, pre-professional, or second company programs to older high school students, with their summer intensive often being the "audition" for these. In some cases, Sylvani is considering these year-round programs for later in her training.

Joffrey has three different summer programs, and the audition was conducted by the academy's Artistic Director, Alexei Kremnev, at Pacific Northwest Ballet's facility in Seattle.  The studio they used has large windows to the hallway, so many parents watched...other parents told me that he was watching Sylvani quite often!

There were 60 students in that audition in Seattle, and I learned that at many of the 14 national and international auditions, there were 100-200 dancers auditioning!


Out of over 1000 students auditioning nationwide, Sylvani was one of 150 accepted into their top summer program, and also offered the opportunity for the year-round Joffrey Trainee program!  The summer program is taught by Joffrey School Artistic Directors Alexei Kremnev and Anna Reznik , and the Artistic Director of the Joffrey Ballet, Ashley Wheater, as well as a number of current dancers with the company and their regular teaching faculty. Taking class

with current dancers, as well as those who have been soloists and principals for major companies, learning sometimes slightly different approaches to "trouble spots", being around them for impromptu learning moments, getting to spend time in the environment where they work...this helps a young student so much!

So Why Joffrey?  Out of all the options, all the wonderful programs, trying to choose really came down to what Sylvani wants most...and that is Joffrey Ballet! Now is the time for her to go find out what they are like in person!


Ballet Training costs $$$$

We are asking your help, because together, we can make a Ballerina!

I'm raising a family on a single, community college classified income.  It covers our bills, barely, but I've had to help with medical bills and other costs for two older daughters, one of whom is in college (on scholarships and grants mostly), and all costs for Sylvani's father, who has a learning disability and hasn't been able to find steady work.  Sylvani's incredibly generous grandparents (my parents) pay for all her regular ballet lessons, which I could never afford on my own. Sylvani's Grandpa Ed and Grandma Liliane gave her love and her beautiful look, and watch over her as she dances, may their memory be for a blessing.

    


I squeeze out money for ballet supplies, the endless pointe shoes, ballet slippers, tights, and leotards, as well as extra classes. All Sylvani ever asks for as birthday and holiday gifts are leotards and pointe shoes, or to go see a ballet. There simply isn't extra money lying around to send a talented daughter to these expensive summer ballet intensives, but they are necessary for her progress and training. 

We are doing all we can, but this ballerina on a mission needs your help!

Joffrey's cost for their 5-week International Summer Intensive is: 

  • Tuition: $2500
  • Room and Board: $3150
  • Activities Fee: $275
  • The total travel expenses are estimated at $1000, 
  • Pointe shoes, 5-7 pairs, leotards and tights for the required uniform, $500

    Total - $7425!!!

Here are Subtractions from that amount: 

  • Joffrey gave Sylvani a 50% tuition scholarship!  - $1250
  • Don earned and I saved $1000 for this summer:  - $1000
  • Using miles, we've reduced the travel expenses:  - $500

This puts us at $4675

Scholarships: Sylvani has applied for two outside scholarships, which support students still in high school who need pre-professional training. We are hopeful, and she is a finalist for one of them, so we are reducing the amount on this campaign by $1000.

So we need to work together to raise $3675! 

If we raise more than we need and she gets a scholarship, any extra will go into a fund for more training, private coaching while at Joffrey, and an additional two weeks at Oregon Ballet Theatre in Portland, OR at the end of the summer (she's already gotten a 50% scholarship for that, and her grandparents will house her!)

If she doesn't get a scholarship, we may ask for more here, but we will also hold garage sales, rent out a room, whatever it takes...Sylvani needs this training! We need to Help Sylvani Dance to Joffrey!

One day, you will see her on a stage and know that you helped her get there! 

So, if you can contribute any amount,
she will send you her thanks in so many ways...check out the "perks" she's offering. Those pointe shoes she's holding here>>>  She'll sign one and mail it to you.

Or a photo or poster of her in that fabulous
jump at the beach.


And always, always...she will think with gratitude of all the people who have helped her get this far and keep supporting her as she grows.  


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can make a contribution of money, but you can still help Sylvani dance! 

  • You can share using the Indiegogo tools at the top of the campaign! Indiegogo tracks how many "shares" using these tools generate visits, and that increases Sylvani's "Go Go Factor" to put her campaign at the top of the search engine!
  • Crowdfunding works when we get a CROWD together, so even if you can't contribute money, if you can get 5 people who can then you are helping in a big way!
  • Send all your loving thoughts, your comments on the comment page, your vision of seeing her ON a stage one day as a professional dancer!

...Thank You for Helping Sylvani Dance!

This past Thanksgiving, that HUGE dream came true! Sylvani was chosen as one of a triple cast at Oregon Ballet Academy to dance the role of Odette/Odile, the complex double role 
traditionally danced by the same dancer in "Swan Lake", choreographed by John Grensback.
Here is a clip from the Prologue, where the maiden Odette is cursed by an evil sorcerer to be a swan, and where, as the Swan Queen, she meets and falls in love with Prince Seigfried . (danced by Nathan Rowell)
    
Here is a clip from the grand ball where Odile fools the Prince into believing she is Odette.    It was a thrill for Sylvani to be able to perform these roles at only 15, and taught her so much!
                   
As challenging as it is to believe in ballet dreams, with all the things that can get in the way...as hard as the work is...as many times one might simply take an easier road...Sylvani has never waivered, her dreams do seem to come true, and she is more determined than ever to continue on this path to wherever it takes her.

Now Sylvani Dreams of Joffrey Ballet...








The Artistic Director John Grensback, of Oregon Ballet Academy, where she trains nearly every day, and his friend Carl Corry, who is guest faculty once per year, danced with the Joffrey Ballet in the 70's and 80's. Together, they have inspired Sylvani, and she watches whatever she can of Joffrey on YouTube.  
There are so many ballet companies, and one never really knows where one might go. But Joffrey is the one she's talked of for years now.  She loves Joffrey's mix of Contemporary and Classical Ballet. She hopes to dance with Joffrey one day. Both of these former Joffrey dancers have said she has a chance of doing exactly that, and that THIS is the summer she should go there to begin to be seen by them! 
Ballet is Training...Lots of Training.
Sylvani is turning 16 now. She has been studying ballet for 12 years. Every week during the school year, Sylvani takes class after school every day and on Saturdays 20 or more hours per week, in ballet technique, pointe, pas de deux, as well as tap, modern, jazz improv, Pilates and other dance forms.  She gets so much from Oregon Ballet Academy! And she manages to still get good grades, and have time with good friends.  
But serious ballet students also must use their summers wisely. While other high school students take summer vacations, those who want a professional ballet career go to summer intensives with ballet companies or major schools   

They improve their skills and strength, make contacts in the dance world, and learn more what it is to be a professional dancer. They then go back to the dorm and hang out with other young dancers all evening.  All week long, all day long, every day, several weeks. It's "full immersion" in a way that just isn't possible during the school year.

Last summer, thanks to help from so many of you, Sylvani went to Texas Ballet Theater in Dallas-Ft. Worth, for 5 weeks. There, she trained with former Houston Ballet Principals Kathryn Warakomsky and Tim O'Keefe, 

              and met famous Artistic Director and Choreographer, Ben Stevenson. These teachers are all former colleagues of John Grensback, Sylvani's Director and main ballet teacher in Oregon, who was Principal Dancer at Houston Ballet in the 80's. Other students from her home studio were there, and they all came back showing improvement and new bonds from having been immersed together. This bond and the intense work they did in Texas together helped them dance "Swan Lake" as choreographed by Mr. Grensback. We definitely saw Sylvani's growth when she returned from Texas!     

Ballet is Auditions!



Every winter, ballet companies and pre-professional schools hold audition tours in major cities around the US and other countries. Since we live in a small city, we had to travel to Portland or Seattle for auditions, so we had to plan carefully which programs Sylvani would audition for.  Not everyone gets in.  Auditions are like taking a "master class" with a top professional or even the Artistic Director of a company or school. Because the student is also "auditioning the program" to see if it feels like a good fit, we tried to get Sylvani to as many auditions as possible, Sylvani auditioned for many programs this year, including Joffrey Ballet Company, Bolshoi Ballet Academy, Ballet West, Oregon Ballet Theatre, University of North Carolina School of the Arts, Walnut Hill, Northwest Ballet Intensive, City Ballet of San Francisco,and Suzanne Farrell.  Some of these companies and programs offer year-round trainee, pre-professional, or second company programs to older high school students, with their summer intensive often being the "audition" for these. In some cases, Sylvani is considering these year-round programs for later in her training. 
Joffrey has three different summer programs, and the audition was conducted by the academy's Artistic Director, Alexei Kremnev, at Pacific Northwest Ballet's facility in Seattle.  The studio they used has large windows to the hallway, so many parents watched...other parents told me that he was watching Sylvani quite often!
There were 60 students in that audition in Seattle, and I learned that at many of the 14 national and international auditions, there were 100-200 dancers auditioning! 

Out of over 1000 students auditioning nationwide, Sylvani was one of 150 accepted into their top summer program, and also offered the opportunity for the year-round Joffrey Trainee program!  The summer program is taught by Joffrey School Artistic Directors Alexei Kremnev and Anna Reznik , and the Artistic Director of the Joffrey Ballet, Ashley Wheater, as well as a number of current dancers with the company and their regular teaching faculty. Taking class 
with current dancers, as well as those who have been soloists and principals for major companies, learning sometimes slightly different approaches to "trouble spots", being around them for impromptu learning moments, getting to spend time in the environment where they work...this helps a young student so much! So Why Joffrey?  Out of all the options, all the wonderful programs, trying to choose really came down to what Sylvani wants most...and that is Joffrey Ballet! Now is the time for her to go find out what they are like in person! 




Ballet Training costs $$$$ 

We are asking your help, because together, we can make a Ballerina!
I'm raising a family on a single, community college classified income.  It covers our bills, barely, but I've had to help with medical bills and other costs for two older daughters, one of whom is in college (on scholarships and grants mostly), and all costs for Sylvani's father, who has a learning disability and hasn't been able to find steady work.  Sylvani's incredibly generous grandparents (my parents) pay for all her regular ballet lessons, which I could never afford on my own. Sylvani's Grandpa Ed and Grandma Liliane gave her love and her beautiful look, and watch over her as she dances, may their memory be for a blessing.
     

I squeeze out money for ballet supplies, the endless pointe shoes, ballet slippers, tights, and leotards, as well as extra classes. All Sylvani ever asks for as birthday and holiday gifts are leotards and pointe shoes, or to go see a ballet. There simply isn't extra money lying around to send a talented daughter to these expensive summer ballet intensives, but they are necessary for her progress and training.  
We are doing all we can, but this ballerina on a mission needs your help!

Joffrey's cost for their 5-week International Summer Intensive is: 


Tuition: $2500
Room and Board: $3150
Activities Fee: $275
The total travel expenses are estimated at $1000, 

Pointe shoes, 5-7 pairs, leotards and tights for the required uniform, $500Total - $7425!!!



Here are Subtractions from that amount: 


Joffrey gave Sylvani a 50% tuition scholarship!  - $1250
Don earned and I saved $1000 for this summer:  - $1000
Using miles, we've reduced the travel expenses:  - $500

This puts us at $4675

Scholarships: Sylvani has applied for two outside scholarships, which support students still in high school who need pre-professional training. We are hopeful, and she is a finalist for one of them, so we are reducing the amount on this campaign by $1000. 


So we need to work together to raise $3675! 


If we raise more than we need and she gets a scholarship, any extra will go into a fund for more training, private coaching while at Joffrey, and an additional two weeks at Oregon Ballet Theatre in Portland, OR at the end of the summer (she's already gotten a 50% scholarship for that, and her grandparents will house her!)
If she doesn't get a scholarship, we may ask for more here, but we will also hold garage sales, rent out a room, whatever it takes...Sylvani needs this training! We need to Help Sylvani Dance to Joffrey! 
One day, you will see her on a stage and know that you helped her get there! 
So, if you can contribute any amount, she will send you her thanks in so many ways...check out the "perks" she's offering. Those pointe shoes she's holding here>>>  She'll sign one and mail it to you.
Or a photo or poster of her in that fabulous jump at the beach.



And always, always...she will think with gratitude of all the people who have helped her get this far and keep supporting her as she grows.  

Other Ways You Can Help
 We understand that not everyone can make a contribution of money, but you can still help Sylvani dance! 
 You can share using the Indiegogo tools at the top of the campaign! Indiegogo tracks how many "shares" using these tools generate visits, and that increases Sylvani's "Go Go Factor" to put her campaign at the top of the search engine!

Crowdfunding works when we get a CROWD together, so even if you can't contribute money, if you can get 5 people who can then you are helping in a big way!
Send all your loving thoughts, your comments on the comment page, your vision of seeing her ON a stage one day as a professional dancer! 
 

 ...Thank You for Helping Sylvani Dance!

story:
THE TEMPLE

or, 

LEBENSRAUM

The Brick Theatre, Brooklyn
February 18th - 21st
February 24th - 28th
All performances at 7:30pm

THE MISSION

You're inside the sunken, pulverized body of the German-commissioned submarine, U-401, after fighting like hell for a country you're not sure you believe in anymore. It's the Spring of 1943. The world is at war above your head, but you're 200 meters below the surface of the ocean. 2 million pascals of force squeeze the vessel around you, conspiring to crush you beyond all recognition. You're surrounded by your dead fellow crewmen. The battery is dying. The oxygen is running out.

And there's a monster on board with you.

The Temple, or Lebensraum, marks playwright Nat Cassidy's return to the world of H.P. Lovecraft after his one-man show, I Am Providence, which won the New York Innovative Theatre Award for Outstanding Solo Performance in 2011, and which Tor.com called: 
"[T]he most delightful thing we have ever seen anyone pull off on a stage, anywhere, ever ... An unexpectedly brilliant mediation on the use and function of horror, on H.P. Lovecraft himself, on the supernatural, on storytelling, on death, on hope. ... Creepy and magical enough to do old H.P. proud. ... I'm still thinking about it, days later."

Updating Lovecraft's original story, which details the increasingly supernatural horrors experienced aboard a sunken submarine, to the middle of WWII (specifically, a time known as the "Black Spring" on account of the sudden and cataclysmic reversal of fortune experienced by Germany's once unstoppable U-Boat force), The Temple is also based on the logs and memoirs of the few U-Boat captains and crewmen that survived a war with an almost 80% casualty rate for German submariners. The play examines the severe tensions between the Nazi Party and the Kriesgmarine (the German Navy), the insanity of WWII and Naziism, and the engulfing madness one man experiences when put in the position of absolute power.

Please note: there will be a specific moment during the performance after which no audience members will be allowed out of the theatre. Ample warning will be given, and after that, there will be no turning back.

(c) David Saavedra
A print of this incredible painting can be yours for $75!

THE VESSEL

The Temple is thrilled and honored to be a part of the Brick Theater's first Resident Artist Program (BRAP). What does this mean? Basically, we get the theatre all to ourselves for two whole weeks. And what we plan to do with that freedom is pretty simple.

We're gonna build a submarine inside The Brick.

I mean, the theatrical approximation of a submarine, but still. Our plans involve reorienting the seating arrangement, building guardrails and hanging battens, even a periscope - doing all we can to give the audience as close to an authentic experience as possible ... while, of course, maintaining the level of comfort and escapability necessary to, y'know, enjoy a play.

But this means we need your help!

The money raised from this fundraising campaign will go almost exclusively towards paying our actors and our designers, all of whom have a hell of a job before them. Lights, sets, sound, costumes, gore, you name it. But we've got an extraordinary team and are about as excited as can possibly be to bring this incredibly unique and powerful adventure to you!

One of the costumes, rendered by our brilliant costumer, Ben Philipp.
So, please, check out our perks and consider donating. Any and all help is so hugely appreciated!! Even if it's just spreading the word!

Pictured: Matthew Trumbull as Heinrich

THE CREW

Arthur Aulisi (Kommandant Klenze): When Arthur is not working on a Nat Cassidy play he's been known to work with companies which include Soho Rep, New Dramatists, E.S.T. and, most recently, Flux Theatre Ensemble. He's a regular participant in Off the Hook (a youth playwrighting program in Red Hook), an ensemble member of Laurie Stanton’s Sound Diet (a radio program taped before live audiences) and a resident artist of Rabbit Hole Ensemble. Arthur was named a newyorktheater.com Person of the Year for his contribution to independent theatre.

John Blaylock (Muller) most recently appeared as Robert in The Gallery Players production of PROOF. Other roles include Disraeli Levering in the Metropolitan Playhouse production of BOTH YOUR HOUSES directed by Michael Hardart, Mr. Faruzo in A WOMAN AT THE FUNERALS by Elena Balyberdina, produced by Good People Mgmt. Group and directed by Ben Sargent, Danforth in The Gallery Players production of THE CRUCIBLE directed by Heather Siobhan Curran and Fr. Tommy DiCamillo (aka "Fr. D") in the White Fence Productions presentation of HOLY CHILD by Joe Lauinger directed by Sue Glausen. John is recreating the role of Fr. D in BLOOD & GRAVY, a web series written by Mr. Lauinger, produced by White Fence Productions, and based on the characters introduced in HOLY CHILD. The first episodes will be released later this year (https://www.backstage.com/JohnBlaylock/).

Tristan Colton (Zinner): Most recent credits are Edmund in King Lear and John Wilkes Booth in This Prison Where I Live with Titan Theatre Company (Resident Actor). Also with Titan: Henry V, Romeo and Juliet. Other recent credits: Hamlet and A Midsummer Night’s Dream with Hyperion Theatre Company (Associate Artistic Director) in NYC and Italy, Cactus Flower at New Theatre in Kansas City, Levittown Off-Broadway with the Cliplight Theater (NY Times Critic’s Pick), and several seasons with the Shakespeare Theatre of New Jersey. Other favorite credits: An Infinite Ache, This Is Our Youth, Down the Road (Edinburgh Fringe Festival), and the title roles in Hamlet and Henry V. You can also see him in several television commercials and on ABC’s What Would You Do? Education: BFA-SUNY Purchase. Check out tristancolton.com

John Gardner (Bohm) has been living and working in New York City for the better part of two decades—but never before on a submersible. Past performances have included LEAVING IKEA with the Artful Conspirators, I GOOGLE MYSELF with Theatre Askew, and MACBETH with Oberon Theatre Ensemble. He most recently taught Christopher Walken to swing a sword on Peter Pan Live! It went pretty much exactly like you’d imagine it would. He’s thrilled to find himself working with such a fantastic group, and with such a singular playwright.

Eric Gilde (Raab) most recently appeared in Shakespeare at the Manor's production of Midsummer Night's Dream. New York credits include As You Like It (Theaterlab), The Nosemaker’s Apprentice (The Brick), The Tempest (Porpentine), Edgewise (Cherry Lane Studio), and Wedding Pictures (EST). He’s also been a part of readings workshops at The Public, Primary Stages, The Lark, and Youngblood, among others. Regionally, Eric has performed at The Repertory Theatre of St. Louis, Pioneer Theatre Company, Virginia Stage, Syracuse Stage, The Kitchen, and The Edinburgh Fringe Festival. He holds a BA and an MFA from Yale University, and is the co-Artistic Director of Happy Few Theatre Company.

Matthew Trumbull (Heinrich) is honored to be in Nat Cassidy's THE TEMPLE at the Brick Theater, where he was onstage in summer 2014 as Faust to Nat's Mephistopheles in August Schulenburg's adaptation of FAUST for Adaptive Arts Theater Company. He is currently starring in Untitled Theater Company #61's THE VELVET ORATORIO by Edward Einhorn and Henry Akona at Bohemian National Hall. In addition to the Brick, he has been seen in productions with numerous indie theater companies in New York, including Flux Theatre Ensemble, Gideon Productions, Retro Productions, Blue Coyote Theater Group, Boomerang Theatre Company, and Metropolitan Playhouse, as well and written and starred in the award-winning solo play THE ZEBRA SHIRT OF LONELY CHILDREN. Later in 2015, Matthew will be acting in the feature film THE SPIKE. He is a 2014 inductee into the Indie Theater Hall of Fame.

Nat Cassidy (writer/director) is one of the New York theatre scene's premiere playwrights of horror and suspense. His scripts include: Any Day Now (winner, NYIT Award winner; ESPADrills 2014, directed by Moritz von Stuelpnagel); Charon (commissioned by The Kennedy Center);The Reckoning of Kit & Little Boots (NYIT Award winner); The Eternal Husband; Old Familiar Faces (NYIT Award nominee); Songs of Love: A Theatrical Mixtape; Goldsboro; Pierce; At the Breakaway; and The Demon Hunter.  Critics have called Cassidy's work "mesmerizing ... one of the creepiest [plays] I've ever seen" (StageBuzz), "brilliant ... remarkable" (The Washington Times), "amazing, unforgettable [and] absolutely electrifying" (Bloomberg Radio), "anyone who appreciates theater that aims at both the head and the gut will appreciate [this play]. And it will haunt you for days to come" (Tulsa World).
MozzleStead (co-producer) is  a company that breaks with traditional studio values and explores the innovative characters, stories and ideas that have shaped the world. Upcoming projects Motion Picture: Chisholm by Montserrat Mendez and Armistead Johnson.  Television: The Dark Lady by John Hundson, Upgrade by August Schulenburg  Plays: Thoroughly Stupid Things  by Montserrat Mendez, The Temple by Nat Cassidy. 
Stephanie Cox-Williams (Gore) is an Actress, SFX/Gore Designer, Director, Producer and Fight Choreographer for independent theater and film.  Some Special/Gore FX credits include: Theatre – Bat Boy (NJIT), R+J+Z (OHA at the Stonington Opera House),  The Cheater’s Club (The Amoralists),Frankenstein Upstairs (Gideon Productions), Man Who Laughs (Stolen Chair Theater Company), Brew of the Dead II-Octoberflesh (Dysfunctional Theater), The Tower, Motherboard  and Death Valley(Antimatter Collective), The Blood Brother’s Present…Anthologies, The Little One (Nosedive Productions); Film – They Will Out Live Us All (AGottaandTwoShearersFilms), Assistant Effects/Make-up Zombies: A Living History (History Channel), named "Queen of Gore" by the NY Press in 2009 and the “Tom Savini of Off-Off Broadway” by the NY Times 2011. She has received a BA in Theatre, a Musical Theatre Conservatory degree and a Masters of Art. She is a Master Mason of the Brick Theatre and was named A Person of the Year by nytheatre.com.
Sarah Lahue (SM) moved to New York City from Albany in 2013. Since then she has had the pleasure of stage managing shows for Boomerang Theatre Company, Retro Productions, and Happy Few Theatre Company as well as for The Secret Theatre's New Voices Project. Most recently she could be found in the booth for Dead End Dummy, presented by Coney Island USA in association with La MaMa ETC.

Ben Philipp (Costumes) has designed costumes for Retro Production's: The Tender Trap, Benefactors, and A Day in the Death of Joe Egg. Carrion Productions: Behind All Lines and Following Anne. The Straddler Productions: The Waste Land, Trousers, Too Far Gone Out in the Middle of Nowhere, and most recently a Straddler Film adaptation of Richard the Third: Long Island Richard. By day, Ben works as a Costume Coordinator for Film and Television. Selected projects include: HBO’s Boardwalk Empire, Too Big To Fail, USA’s White Collar, ABC’s Pan Am, NBC’s The Michael J. Fox Show, and Killer Film’s Kill Your Darlings. Ben was raised on submarines.  His father was the Captain of the USS Trepang SSN-674, he studied military history in school, and spent 2 summers working as the costume designer for World War II reenactments aboard the USS Lexington CV-16 Aircraft Carrier Museum in Corpus Christi, TX.  bpcostume.tumblr.com

Jeanne E. Travis (Sound) is a composer, sound designer and stage manager(AEA). Recent SD credits: Asymmetric,Frankenstein Upstairs, The Honeycomb Trilogy: Advance Man, Blast Radius, Sovereign (Gideon Productions), Rantoul and Die, Enter at Forrest Lawn (The Amoralists), The Whaleship Essex (Hudson Guild), Luft Gangster (Nylon Fusion), BEARS (59E59) As SM:Alice in Slasherland (Vampire Cowboys), Final Analysis (Pershing Square Signature Center),Spectral Scriabin (Lincoln Center), Methtacular! (Kef Productions) Upcoming projects 2015: Woyzeck (The New Ohio), Leave Me Green (The Gym at Judson),Six Rounds of Vengeance by Qui Nguyen (Vampire Cowboys). 
Sandy (Saundra) Yaklin (Set Design) is a freelance scenic designer, art director & fabricator. She is the resident designer for Gideon Productions and runs The Sand Box, a shop/rehearsal space in Queens, and the Sh.I.T. List (shit-list.biz), a website for trading theater goods. Recent projects include The Gotham Awards (stage set tech direction); "Song of Two Suns" (art direction); The Paper Store" (scenic film design); "The Understudy" (set design); "The FamilyPlay" (technical direction/co-design); "Dark Water" (technical direction); "Richard 3" (set design); "Freak Me" (art direction); "Frankenstein Upstairs" (set design, IT Award nomination-Outstanding Play Premiere), and "Advance Man" (set design, IT Award-Outstanding Play Premiere). You can see her portfolio at bad-sandy.com.
Morgan Zipf-Meister (Lights) is a native of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania who has been designing, acting, and directing in New York for over 10 years.  She has lit the stage for many theater companies including Dreamscape, Old Kent Road, and Piper Mckenzie.  Most recently she had the pleasure of lighting 3 or the 4 installments of "The Blood Brothers Present Bedlam Nightmares" including the critically well-received  final installment "Execution Day."  
... and more to be announced!

Later in 2015, Matthew will be acting in the feature film THE SPIKE. He is a 2014 inductee into the Indie Theater Hall of Fame.


Nat Cassidy (writer/director) is one of the New York theatre scene's premiere playwrights of horror and suspense. His scripts include: Any Day Now (winner, NYIT Award winner; ESPADrills 2014, directed by Moritz von Stuelpnagel); Charon (commissioned by The Kennedy Center);The Reckoning of Kit & Little Boots (NYIT Award winner); The Eternal Husband; Old Familiar Faces (NYIT Award nominee); Songs of Love: A Theatrical Mixtape; Goldsboro; Pierce; At the Breakaway; and The Demon Hunter.  Critics have called Cassidy's work "mesmerizing ... one of the creepiest [plays] I've ever seen" (StageBuzz), "brilliant ... remarkable" (The Washington Times), "amazing, unforgettable [and] absolutely electrifying" (Bloomberg Radio), "anyone who appreciates theater that aims at both the head and the gut will appreciate [this play]. And it will haunt you for days to come" (Tulsa World).


MozzleStead (co-producer) is  a company that breaks with traditional studio values and explores the innovative characters, stories and ideas that have shaped the world. Upcoming projects Motion Picture: Chisholm by Montserrat Mendez and Armistead Johnson.  Television: The Dark Lady by John Hundson, Upgrade by August Schulenburg  Plays: Thoroughly Stupid Things  by Montserrat Mendez, The Temple by Nat Cassidy. 

Stephanie Cox-Williams (Gore) is an Actress, SFX/Gore Designer, Director, Producer and Fight Choreographer for independent theater and film.  Some Special/Gore FX credits include: Theatre – Bat Boy (NJIT), R+J+Z (OHA at the Stonington Opera House),  The Cheater’s Club (The Amoralists),Frankenstein Upstairs (Gideon Productions), Man Who Laughs (Stolen Chair Theater Company), Brew of the Dead II-Octoberflesh (Dysfunctional Theater), The Tower, Motherboard  and Death Valley(Antimatter Collective), The Blood Brother’s Present…Anthologies, The Little One (Nosedive Productions); Film – They Will Out Live Us All (AGottaandTwoShearersFilms), Assistant Effects/Make-up Zombies: A Living History (History Channel), named "Queen of Gore" by the NY Press in 2009 and the “Tom Savini of Off-Off Broadway” by the NY Times 2011. She has received a BA in Theatre, a Musical Theatre Conservatory degree and a Masters of Art. She is a Master Mason of the Brick Theatre and was named A Person of the Year by nytheatre.com.
Sarah Lahue (SM) moved to New York City from Albany in 2013. Since then she has had the pleasure of stage managing shows for Boomerang Theatre Company, Retro Productions, and Happy Few Theatre Company as well as for The Secret Theatre's New Voices Project. Most recently she could be found in the booth for Dead End Dummy, presented by Coney Island USA in association with La MaMa ETC.
Ben Philipp (Costumes) has designed costumes for Retro Production's: The Tender Trap, Benefactors, and A Day in the Death of Joe Egg. Carrion Productions: Behind All Lines and Following Anne. The Straddler Productions: The Waste Land, Trousers, Too Far Gone Out in the Middle of Nowhere, and most recently a Straddler Film adaptation of Richard the Third: Long Island Richard. By day, Ben works as a Costume Coordinator for Film and Television. Selected projects include: HBO’s Boardwalk Empire, Too Big To Fail, USA’s White Collar, ABC’s Pan Am, NBC’s The Michael J. Fox Show, and Killer Film’s Kill Your Darlings. Ben was raised on submarines.  His father was the Captain of the USS Trepang SSN-674, he studied military history in school, and spent 2 summers working as the costume designer for World War II reenactments aboard the USS Lexington CV-16 Aircraft Carrier Museum in Corpus Christi, TX.  bpcostume.tumblr.com

Jeanne E. Travis (Sound) is a composer, sound designer and stage manager(AEA). Recent SD credits: Asymmetric,Frankenstein Upstairs, The Honeycomb Trilogy: Advance Man, Blast Radius, Sovereign (Gideon Productions), Rantoul and Die, Enter at Forrest Lawn (The Amoralists), The Whaleship Essex (Hudson Guild), Luft Gangster (Nylon Fusion), BEARS (59E59) As SM:Alice in Slasherland (Vampire Cowboys), Final Analysis (Pershing Square Signature Center),Spectral Scriabin (Lincoln Center), Methtacular! (Kef Productions) Upcoming projects 2015: Woyzeck (The New Ohio), Leave Me Green (The Gym at Judson),Six Rounds of Vengeance by Qui Nguyen (Vampire Cowboys). 


Sandy (Saundra) Yaklin (Set Design) is a freelance scenic designer, art director & fabricator. She is the resident designer for Gideon Productions and runs The Sand Box, a shop/rehearsal space in Queens, and the Sh.I.T. List (shit-list.biz), a website for trading theater goods. Recent projects include The Gotham Awards (stage set tech direction); "Song of Two Suns" (art direction); The Paper Store" (scenic film design); "The Understudy" (set design); "The FamilyPlay" (technical direction/co-design); "Dark Water" (technical direction); "Richard 3" (set design); "Freak Me" (art direction); "Frankenstein Upstairs" (set design, IT Award nomination-Outstanding Play Premiere), and "Advance Man" (set design, IT Award-Outstanding Play Premiere). You can see her portfolio at bad-sandy.com.


Morgan Zipf-Meister (Lights) is a native of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania who has been designing, acting, and directing in New York for over 10 years.  She has lit the stage for many theater companies including Dreamscape, Old Kent Road, and Piper Mckenzie.  Most recently she had the pleasure of lighting 3 or the 4 installments of "The Blood Brothers Present Bedlam Nightmares" including the critically well-received  final installment "Execution Day."  


... and more to be announced!

story:
More Than a History Lesson

Beth Judah, a family-oriented conservative synagogue in Ventnor, New Jersey, is preparing for our 8th annual production of Number the Stars.  Set in Denmark during World War II, this musical adaptation of Lois Lowery’s Newberry Award winning middle grade novel tells the story of a brave family’s sacrifice to save their Jewish friends as the Nazis take control of the country.  Each year, Beth Judah invites local schools to experience this poignant story and explore its themes of courage, friendship, prejudice, family, and history.

Contributions will allow Beth Judah to subsidize performances for schools who no longer have the resources to cover the nominal ticket price.  In doing so, we will offer many local students their first live theater experience, while teaching the importance of tolerance and personalizing the horror of the Holocaust.

Sharing the Message of Tolerance

Under pressure from budget cuts, our local schools are having difficulties bringing their students to see the show, or bringing us to their school to present the show there, even with our discounted student and teacher ticket prices.  We are therefore seeking $3,600 in contributions, which will allow us to offer scholarship funds so that students may continue to benefit from this wonderful experience regardless of their school’s budget situation. 

We are offering exclusive gifts to contributors, including a cast t-shirt, normally available only to cast and crew members; autographed pictures of the talented Number the Stars cast; and a DVD of the production, including performances by both Cast “A” and Cast “B.”  With a donation of $360, you will become an honorary cast member, receiving the t-shirt, autographed picture, and DVD of both Cast “A” and Cast “B” performances.  In addition, you’ll have the satisfaction of helping us share Number the Stars with students who would otherwise not be able to see this important show.

A Lasting Impression

In the past seven years, approximately 11,000 students have come to see Number the Stars at Congregation Beth Judah.  For many students, the show marks their first live theater experience, their first visit to a synagogue, or both.  Students and teachers alike have reported that the experience was as enjoyable as it was educational.  Teachers who have brought their classrooms regularly comment on the helpfulness of the lesson plans that we provide, as well as the impact that the show and synagogue visit has had on tolerance education.  A number of schools make it a point to return each year, bringing a new group of children to benefit from Number the Stars. 

In addition to its benefits as entertainment and as a teaching/learning tool, our production of Number the Stars brings another complimentary benefit to our audience.  Our venue for the show is Congregation Beth Judah, a Conservative synagogue in Ventnor, New Jersey.  For many of the students who come to see the show, this event marks the first time that they have seen or been inside a synagogue, and we have found over the years that this expansion of student horizons is beneficial to the development of tolerance for others.

Students who have the opportunity to see Number the Stars may remember new historical facts, such as the role played by Danish Christians in saving their Jewish friends and neighbors.  They may recall seeing the Ark which holds Congregation Beth Judah’s Torah scrolls.  They may find themselves humming some of the catchy tunes from the production’s memorable musical numbers.  Whatever the lasting impression of their visit to the show, they will undoubtedly remain touched by the story of a girl their age who finds the courage to stand up for a friend in need.

Support Comes in Many Forms

Although we seek financial contributions to share Number the Stars, we are also grateful for other forms of support.  You can help support our message of tolerance by:

·  Attending the show at Congregation Beth Judah on Wednesday, May 21, or Thursday, May 22.  For tickets, call 609-822-7116, x101;

·  Tell your friends and family members about Number the Stars;

·  Share our event on Facebook and Indiegogo.

For more information on Number the Stars at Congregation Beth Judah, contact Rabbi Aaron Gaber at 609-822-7116 x101.

story:
Our Situation

We - Alejandra Vieira "the writer and director", Nazaret Ortiz "the actress" and Pamela Puglianini "the executive producer" - are the creators of this new play originally written for this especific project. 

Before talking about the play itself, we would like to introduce you to our situation: In Lima, doing theatre is very difficult, there's not enough education, not enough fundings and not enough public, BUT that's starting to change little by little. We are a part of the people who are betting for this change. 

We want to dedicate our lifes for making more quality theatre in our City and why not? in our country. That's why we've studied these, and for our Final Project we are making these play that demands our own money for it. This why we need your help. 



Our project

Now the juicy part...

"The Perfect Couple" was born in Alejandra's mind, in order to laugh about (so we don't start crying) something we cannot believe it's still happening in our society: inequity in gender roles and objetification of women in relationships. This brings a lot of trouble for women: we get harrased in the streets, bullied, not taken seriously enough for todays economics, raped, beaten and even killed. According to the OMS report of 2010, Lima is the 3rd region in Latinoamerica with the most violence to women portrayed in stadistics. 

So, this comedy shows us a couple- Susan and Benito- that are recently engaged and decide to visit Benito's parents which are, as we call, rich and conservative. So, as it's revealed that their about to lose their apartment, Susan sees herself in the obligation of earning their blessings. That's why they rehearse the meeting with them, until they start to notice that the apple doesn't fall away from the tree, and maybe she's not rehearsing just for that night...

So, does love always win? Or should ourselves be priorized over it?

The play will be presented in a Theatre called "Miraflores Theatre-Auditorium" in  Larco 1150. Lima. Peru.

Dates: 25th, 27th, and  30th of June, and  7th, 14th and 21th  of July. 8 p.m.
If we can, we would love to extend this season. 


What can we do with your help

So... In order to make this play happen, we need to cover certain expenses: 

- Escenography
- Utilery
- Clothes
- Make up and hair styling
- The theatre rent (which it will cost us about 100 dollars per night)
- A place for rehearsals. 
- Paying for the actor, assistants, technicians and designers
- Transportation
- Logistics (phone calls, print, bus, food for rehearsals, taxis, etc.)
- Press and publicity. 

Our budget is about 4000 dollars, which we're trying to cover with our own money, but being a student is not money we have in our pockets daily. That's why we need your help to try and lower the cost in half. 

What do we need you to do now?

- Helping us finish our carreer, and that way, bringing more prepared artists to peruvian's theatre circle. 
- Helping us talk about this specific topic, which we think is very important for our society's growth and evolution. 
- And finally, helping us make the very first play of what it would be our theatre company. 



You could also help

By telling others about our project and how important it would be for us and for our culture to colaborate.
